Despite a warning in February by the European Union, which wants to negotiate a global accord on air service with Washington, several member countries, including Belgium, Luxembourg and Austria, and some nonmembers, like Switzerland and Iceland, have reached preliminary agreement to phase out restrictive treaties that have governed air travel. The others -- Denmark, Sweden, Finland and Norway -- are expected to do so this month.

title: 4 Months After Robbery, Bike Shop Is Still Picking Up Pieces
description: In his mind, Gerald Browne still smells the acrid odor of gunpowder and hears his silent goodbyes to unseen loved ones. Roy Beatong jolts awake at night, shaken and sweating.

title:
CLASSICAL MUSIC;
A Brash Opera Holds a Mirror To Gay Life In America
description: THE DAY AFTER THE premiere of "Harvey Milk" last January, the staff of the Houston Grand Opera seemed to be breathing a collective sigh of relief. Not that the quality of the production had ever been in doubt, but the threat of anti-"Harvey" demonstrations by right-wing activists had set the company on edge. Although extra security had been arranged, no protest had materialized.

title: Ideas & Trends; Put On Your Best Chest -- It's Time To Preen
description: THE greatest difference between us and the rest of the animal kingdom, declared Clairee Belcher, the cheeky elder stateswoman in "Steel Magnolias," is "our ability to accessorize." Ah, but Ms. Belcher might well have noted another outstanding trait specific to our species: breasts. We are the only mammal whose mammaries stay permanently enlarged whether or not the glands are dispensing milk.

title: A Golden Moment At the Oscars
description: ALTHOUGH Lizzy Gardiner won an Oscar on Monday night for the outfits she designed for the film "The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert," her best costume may be the one she wore to accept the award.

title: Balkan Spring
description: Spring in the Balkans is a bitter season. Milder weather means renewed fighting as mountain passes reopen and troops move out from winter encampments to resume a war without end. This year the Bosnian Army has initiated combat, nudging back Serbian positions in northern and central Bosnia. The Serbs have responded by shelling civilians in at least three of the six refugee-swollen cities under the nominal protection of the United Nations Security Council. As a result, the four-month cease-fire that Jimmy Carter brokered at the end of last year is unraveling weeks ahead of schedule.

title: Computer Chat About a Subject Many See Too Taboo
description: In an age when relationships between professors and students have led to charges of sexual harassment, Prof. BARRY M. DANK is taking an unconventional stand: He defends romances between the two.

title: It's 'The Gap' Once You're Hired, But Job Hunters Must Spiff It Up
description: IN the depths of Sherry Yerkey's closet is a dowdy blue skirt that she wore recently. But she won't wear it again anytime soon.

title:
ART;
Showcase for Printmaking Techniques at a New Hostos Gallery
description: HEMINGWAY'S phrase "a clean, well-lighted place" is a fine, apt description of the new art gallery at Hostos Community College, which is currently having its second exhibition.

title: Defense a Key For U.C.L.A.
description: It was the Oklahoma State Cowboys who came to the Final Four with the reputation of in-your-face defense that kindled memories of Hank Iba and a bygone era. The top-ranked U.C.L.A. Bruins, meanwhile, were considered thoroughbreds who would rather outrace their opponents than suffocate them.

title: An Old Japanese Custom
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Be Lulled by Easy Loans
description: MY pen moves slowly across the blank check, as I savor the moment of accomplishment. Date: March 1, 1995. Pay to the Order of Chemical Bank. Eighty-Seven and . . . 28/100 Dollars. Exclamation point.

title: Mallory Prestlien, Steven Cangialosi
description: Mallory Anne Prestlien, a television producer, was married yesterday to Steven Donato Cangialosi, a sports anchor and reporter. The Rev. James Reynolds performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Child in Richmond Hill, Queens.

title:
The View From: Scarsdale;
Sisyphean Conflict Grows Over a Mountain of Compost
description: IT is 1995 and composting has an image as environmentally friendly and politically correct. So it at first seems ironic that a group of citizens is protesting the presence of a compost operation in a residential neighborhood here, asserting that it not only creates intolerable odors but also releases unhealthy mold spores into the air and exposes residents to dangerous chemicals used as deodorizers.

title: Resuscitating Noah and Refloating the Ark
description: IT'S not the end of the world that "Two by Two," the Richard Rodgers musical about a year in the life of Noah, from the ages of 600 to 601, has had no major revival in a quarter of a century. And it isn't likely that anyone thirsts for a reinvention, a reconstruction or any of those R-words that nowadays prescribe new ways to do old shows.

title: LONG ILSAND JOURNAL
description: Beleaguered Mascot

title: Body Bags at 11
description: SIRENS BLEAT, BODIES float, suspects cringe, victims weep. Celebrities preen and promote. Anchors chat and emote. It's local news time: normally 30 minutes of hell and blather, ads and promos, weather and sports, starting at 9, 10 or 11 -- local television's most profitable time of night and its most disheartening use of the air.

title: Segue to Women Who Weren't Born Yesterday
description: Jessica Lange has been through it all, from King Kong to Blanche DuBois, from depending on the gentleness of apes to depending on the kindness of strangers.

title: The Ultimate Insider
description: JOE ALSOP'S COLD WARA Study of Journalistic Influence and Intrigue.By Edwin M. Yoder Jr.220 pp. Chapel Hill:University of North Carolina Press. $24.95.

title: Artist-Teacher in Two Shows
description: A PREGNANT woman telephoned Linda Perlmutter the other day to sign up for art classes. "Not for her," Mrs. Perlmutter said. "She knows there's a long waiting list. She wanted to sign up an unborn child."

title: Advocacy Group Seeks Money for Libraries
description: ADVOCATES for the Westchester Library System have had a hard time recently fitting themselves into the profile of the reader cozily engrossed in a book.

title: Grab That Rake, Tackle Those Weeds
description: ROCUSES have bloomed. So have the snowdrops. Early tulips and the first daffodils are beginning to show their colors.

title: Investigators at Fulton Fish Market Search for Arson's Motive
description: Investigators looking into a fire at the Fulton Fish Market searched there yesterday for records that they hoped might lead them to the arsonists who set it.

title: In Short/Baseball
description: Think of it as a long seventh-inning stretch, with publishers doing their bit to occupy your time until the next batter is up. This season's lineup of baseball books includes fiction, biography and history, so no reader should feel the need to go on strike.THE NEW YORK YANQUIS By Bill Granger.Arcade/Little, Brown, $21.95.

title: March 26-April 1; On the Road in Hillaryland
description: HERE in the shadows of Mount Everest this weekend, the burning questions are these: Will the world see America's No. 1 Democratic woman on that Republican icon, the elephant? And when Hillary Rodham Clinton sets out on a safari, who will win -- the First Lady or the tiger?

title: Owners Prepare to Take Players Back
description: Baseball's replacement players were sent down to the minor leagues yesterday as the team owners prepared to take back the striking major leaguers and get a new season under way.

title: Just Superheroes Sticking Up for the Homestead
description: Alice in Wonderland A revival of the 1948 French-British-American film at the Museum of Modern Art, 7 West 53d Street, Manhattan, April 7 at 6 P.M. and April 8 at 2 P.M. Stephen Murray, Pamela Brown, Carol Marsh Directed by Dallas Bower with animation by Lou Bunin No rating 96 minutes

title: Sandra Lithgow, Pedro Ramirez
description: Dr. Sandra Denise Lithgow, a resident in internal medicine at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, is to be married today to Dr. Pedro Ramirez, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology there. The Rev. William J. Bradley is to perform the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of Our Lady of Mercy in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: New Jersey Couple Win a U.S. Bridge Title
description: A major title was awarded here to a New Jersey couple at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals on Friday, 18 hours after the event was concluded.

title: Alan Hugh Nadel, Karen Anne Rich
description: Karen Anne Rich, an associate at the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, is to be married this evening to Alan Hugh Nadel, a commodities trader. Rabbi Martin Rozenberg is to officiate at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Business Best Sellers
description: HARDCOVER 1. THE BEARDSTOWN LADIES' COMMON-SENSE INVESTMENT GUIDE (Godin/Hyperion, $19.95.) Tips for successful investing from 16 Illinois women.

title: Casino Seek Out Minorities And Women
description: The Casino Control Act requires casinos to spend at least 15 percent of their budget for goods and services with companies led by women and minorities. In 1993, only four casinos met that goal. Last year, all 12 did.

title: A Pink Oscar Week; 'Paging Dr. Freud!'
description: UPTOWN -- Some people are tired of O. J. Simpson. Some are tired of the Internet or mesclun. Marian McEvoy, the snappy editor in chief of Elle Decor magazine, is tired of black.

title: Variety of Materials To Frame Pictures
description: Mat boards [ "Home Clinic, "Picture Frames' 2 Sides: Esthetic and Utilitarian," Feb. 5 ] come in several varieties and are not necessarily cardboard. There are three basic types of mats, paper, acid-free museum grade and cotton-rag museum grade. The article points out that corrugated cardboard should not be used as a backing board to mount art work. This is also true of the mat that will be lying on top of the art.

title: LEGAL IMMIGRANTS IN RECORD NUMBERS WANT CITIZENSHIP
description: The number of legal immigrants applying to become United States citizens has nearly doubled in the last year, an increase that one immigration official described as "an unprecedented surge" stemming partly from recent initiatives passed in California and in Congress that would deny many benefits to noncitizens.

title:
THE WORLD;
Learning When to Wear Gloves
description: Many Americans have gone to Haiti over the years, determined to have some impact on a land notoriously resistant to change, where greed, poverty and fear are endemic. Raymond W. Kelly, a former New York City police commissioner, is one of the latest to try.

title: From Songbird to Sportscaster
description: THE phone lines were on fire, and Suzyn Waldman was in her element answering sports questions from callers about the dilemma of the day: why Pat Riley, coach of the New York Knicks, had openly criticized his team.

title: Factions Scramble to Contain Fighting on Israel-Lebanon Border
description: Israel, Lebanon and their allies struggled today to keep new border fighting from spinning out of control, even as they warned that they were ready to launch fresh military attacks if provoked.

title: The End Is Near for Alexander's Abstract Mural on Route 4
description: Whether they love it or hate it, shoppers and commuters who regularly pass Alexander's here have come to regard its huge abstract impressionist mural as a kind of landmark.

title: Death of a Rapper: A Legacy Built on the Gangster Image
description: ERIC WRIGHT, THE multimillion-selling rapper known as Eazy-E, took on a sad new celebrity last Sunday night, when he became the first hip-hop star to die of AIDS. Ten days earlier, Wright had released a statement that revealed his condition, announced that he had "seven children by six different mothers" and said he wanted his young fans to "learn about what's real when it comes to AIDS." But Wright's career can't be summed up in his cause of death.

title: Stanley Cain, Ecologist, 92, Led the Field
description: Stanley A. Cain, a pioneering conservationist who helped develop the science of ecology and served as an assistant secretary of the Interior Department in the 1960's, died yesterday at a nursing home in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 92.

title: Buy Space on a Park Bench?
description: Township council members want to raise money, but they would rather not raise taxes, at least not much. So they are weighing a plan to sell advertising space on park benches, tennis courts, fences, municipal vehicles, even trash cans. S T & L Advertising, a township-based firm that has been working with the council, says selling ads could bring in $225,000 a year. The council will review bid specifications next Monday. DAVID STOUT

title: Kaufman & Broad Home Corp.(KBH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Swan Lake Has Its Odette
description: In the early hours of March 26, as one of the town's mute swans sat guarding her eggs on her lakeside nest, she was clubbed with a baseball bat. Then her head was severed with a crosscut saw and thrown into the lake. Two men who live in a nearby motel and a 14-year-old boy have been charged.

title: Anderson Imagines Staying
description: Likening himself to one of the game's great small players, Kenny Anderson said today that he sees himself staying in New Jersey beyond the 1995-1996 season.

title: The Baseball Truce
description: Just when it seemed the highlight of the summer sports season might be videotape of Michael Jordan's return to basketball, Major League Baseball has been forced to snap out of its stupefying labor dispute. The resumption of baseball, even for an abbreviated season that may make 15-game winners the paradigm of pitching excellence, is cheering news for baseball fans, many of whom feared a summertime choice between lawn mowing and watching hapless replacement players.

title: Unhappy Trails: A Clash of Nature Lovers; Hikers Claim Mountain Bikers Are Disturbing the Peace but Bikers Won't Backpedal
description: The mountain bikers gathering at Mianus River Park were from all over, but they had one thing in common besides their fat-tired bicycles. They loved the quiet trails in the park, 215 acres of undisturbed woods in the heart of busy Fairfield County.

title: DANCE
description: A Choreographer Analyzes The Nature of Virtuosity Tere O'Connor Dance Bessie Schonberg Theater

title: Success in Film A Mixed Blessing In the Theater
description: Movie success doesn't come cheap, the price sometimes being the loss of family, friends, even the face one was born with. In the case of Ralph Fiennes, the cost has been a certain credibility, at least in the local press.

title: Eating Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: Amway Asia Pacific Ltd.  (AAP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Year-ago results are pro forma, to include certain adjustments that give effect to a reorganization which led to the company's initial public offering in December 1993.

title: No Headline
description: "The players are back, the game is back and we are very happy about that." -- BUD SELIG, acting baseball commissioner. [ A1:6 ]

title: Hillary Clinton Meets Man Who Gave Her 2 L's
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has practiced law, raised a daughter and tried to change one-seventh of the American economy by reshaping health care. But in the last 24 hours she has ridden a bull elephant with Secret Service radio escort, and met the man responsible for making her a Hillary with two l's.

title: Mercer Intl.(MERCS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included one-time German government supplement of $ 27,133,000, or $ 2.41 a share, related to acquisition of Zellstoff Und Papierfabrik Rosenthal GmbH, and a gain of $ 638,000, or 6 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.c-Included extraordinary item in the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $ 2,801,000, or 27 cents a share, on extinguishment of debt, in the year.

title: At Knight-Ridder, a Struggle of Illness, Not Power. . .
description: It may never be easy for corporate executives to give up power.

title: Bridge
description: Two Californian experts won the Open Pairs title at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here on Saturday night. Evan Bailey and John Strauch, both of San Diego, who have been playing together for nearly a quarter of a century, led after the qualifying stage on Friday and held on to win their first national championship by just four match points.

title: Patents; Which Companies Had the Most Patents in 1994? It Depends on Which Set of Statistics You Believe
description: WHEN trying to make sense of the rankings released last week of top holders of United States patents issued in 1994, perhaps it is wise to keep in mind Samuel Clemens's admonition that there are "lies, damned lies and statistics."

title: Symbols of Policy Ills, Public High Rises Fall
description: They once represented the promise of urban renewal. But today, two buildings in the Christopher Columbus Homes here were turned to dust, a symbol of well-intentioned housing policies turned bad.

title: Conner's Boat Stays Alive, on The Water
description: The burden of losing shifted from the protest room to the race course today for Dennis Conner and his waning America's Cup campaign. But like a sudden cloud break on an overcast day, the 52-year-old Conner pulled out a victory when he least expected it.

title: Highway Into Scenic Byway
description: The image of New Jersey for many drivers is one of refineries and smoke-belching stacks. So state officials are trying to register Route 29, which meanders along the Delaware River for 35 miles from Trenton into Frenchtown, as the state's first road in the Federal Scenic Byways program. Officials say the road, almost free of billboards, would need only minor landscaping and better signs directing tourists to parks and historic sites to be "scenic."

title: Oliver Rea, 71, Theatrical Producer
description: Oliver Rea, a theatrical producer who was a co-founder of the Tyrone Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 71.

title: Chambers Development Co.  (CDV.A,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charges for unusual items of $ 14.2 million, or 21 cents a share, mainly related to the estimated effect of a charge related to the settlement of shareholder litigation of $ 5.3 million and terminated projects, asset impairments, asset divestitures and a contractual commitment loss totaling $ 8.9 million, in both the quarter and year. The year also included charges for unusual items of $ 88.3 million, or $ 1.32 a share, and a recorded $ 74.1 million for the estimated effect of the shareholder litigation settlement.c-Included a charge for unusual items of $ 5.5 million, or 8 cents a share, for losses on planned asset divestitures, contractual commitments, asset impairments and abandoned projects, partially offset by gains on asset divestitures, in the quarter and year. The year also included an after-tax net credit for unusual items of $ 5.9 million, or 9 cents a share.d-Net incomeThe company said the latest fourth quarter also included charges totaling $ 1.9 million, or 3 cents a share, including a present value charge of $ 2.3 million from the company's adoption of FAS 116 relating to the company's six-year program to make charitable contributions of $ 500,000 a year, and expenses of $ 2.3 million with respect to current and anticipated refinancing of the company's lending agreements. Such charges were offset by an income tax benefit of $ 4.3 million attributable to prior years.(Loss)

title: DANCE
description: A Skilled Young Company With Paul Taylor Style Taylor 2 Symphony Space

title: The Man Who Would Save NY for NYNEX
description: Ivan G. Seidenberg still regularly drops in on his pals at the old New York Telephone garage on Bronx River Avenue, where he started in 1966 as a cable-splicer's helper, fresh out of Evander Childs High School. Now that he's head of the whole company, Nynex, such visits could easily seem like the calculated effort of a chief executive to bond with his troops.

title: More on Baseball
description: NOBODY WINS -- With the possibility of another disruption eventually, there is only a loser -- the fan. Dave Anderson, Page C1. FEW FANS CHEER -- As one sandlot player put it, "They're already taken the joy out of the season and opening day." Page C2. AN EDGE FOR YANKS -- The Yankees have 12 players signed, including many regulars and two starting pitchers. Page C4. METS' HELLO AND GOODBYE -- The regulars are eager to return while replacements depart with a $5,000-per-man bonus. Page C4.

title: U.S. Gives Russia Secret Data on Iran to Discourage Atom Deal
description: The Clinton Administration has taken the unusual step of providing Russian officials with American intelligence on Iran in hopes of persuading them to drop Russia's project to build nuclear reactors in Iran.

title: Abroad at Home; Never Again
description: On April 6, 1992, Serbian forces besieged the capital of Bosnia, Sarajevo. It seemed grotesque, then, that a city known for its relaxed charm, its easy mix of Muslims and Serbs, Croats and Jews, should be under attack by virulent nationalism. Surely such anachronistic savagery could not go on for long. The world would not allow it.

title: Kenneth Gay, 83, Curator of Poetry
description: Kenneth Gay, who was the curator of the Poetry Collection of the State University College at Buffalo for 10 years and a longtime friend and assistant to the writer Robert Graves, died on March 26 in Palma, Mallorca. He was 83.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Seagram Said to Be Close To Selling Du Pont Shares

title: Amid Technicals, Fouls And Ejections, a Victor
description: Today's Knicks-Nets feud featured the trash-talking and posturing that both teams feel compelled to engage in.

title: A New Mirror on Roosevelt's Moods in the War
description: CLOSEST COMPANION The Unknown Story of the Intimate Friendship Between Franklin Roosevelt and Margaret Suckley Edited and Annotated by Geoffrey C. Ward Illustrated. 444 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $24.95.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Friday about a proposed purchase by the Parker Hannifin Corporation misstated the assets that will be acquired. Parker Hannifin is buying the assets of the Figgie International Inc.'s power systems division in Rockford, Ill., for an unspecified amount of cash; it is not buying Figgie.

title: Underwriting on Wall Street Remained Sluggish in Quarter
description: Beset by layoffs and losses, Wall Street has been hoping that its bread-and-butter business -- the underwriting of stocks and bonds -- may finally have hit bottom.

title: Manhattan Business Districts Lift Quality of Life at Small Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebroadcasting of 'My So-Called Life'
description: While fans of the ABC drama "My So-Called Life" wait to learn whether the show will be renewed, the 19 episodes that have appeared on ABC Television will be shown on MTV, the rock-music cable television network, starting next Monday. MTV will broadcast them from 7 to 8 P.M. on consecutive weeknights under a one-time licensing agreement with ABC.

title: Falcon Holding Group L.P. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss from the write-off of loan costs on retired debt of $ 4,760,000.

title: POP
description: A Little Rusty But Still Relevant Bush Tetras The Knitting Factory

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. What Barkley Message? David Robinson hit two free throws with 20.7 seconds remaining and the San Antonio Spurs overcame Charles Barkley's season-high 45 points to win their 11th straight game yesterday, beating the visiting Phoenix Suns by 109-106. The Spurs improved to 52-18, the best record in the Western Conference, and extended their lead over Utah in the Midwest to 1 1/2 games. "I sent them a message today," Barkley said.

title: W. J. Villaume, 80, Lutheran Minister
description: The Rev. Dr. William J. Villaume, a Lutheran minister who pursued prominent parallel careers as pastor, educator and national religious administrator, died last Monday at his home in Corpus Christi, Tex. He was 80.

title: Many Haitians Fearful Despite U.N. Presence
description: Despite the new United Nations mission of establishing a "safe and stable environment" in Haiti, there is growing nervousness among its people about the future. The unease stems from an increase in crime and the lack of any immediate and widespread economic relief nearly six months after Jean-Bertrand Aristide was restored as President.

title: What to Expect This Week
description: SENATE -- The Senate is to vote today on a resolution filed by the Republican majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, to cut off debate on an income tax measure. A Democratic effort to prolong debate on that bill has blocked Senate action on midyear budget cuts, which are known as rescissions.

title: Different Paths, Pressures For Tonight's Final Two
description: The journeys they have made, and the burdens that have accumulated along the way, began decades apart.

title: Critic-Turned-Conductor Finds A Mission in Handel's Operas
description: A promise to present all 37 of Handel's operas is a little like taking out a long-term mortgage. One makes the appointed payments and hopes to be around for the last one. Will Crutchfield, who tonight begins this project at the Manhattan School of Music with "Deidamia," thinks the idea of "all" is necessary. "To understand Verdi or Wagner you have to know everything they wrote," he said between rehearsals last week. "Handel is the same."

title: U.S. Gives Russia Secret Data on Iran to Discourage Atom Deal; Perry Favors Aid
description: Secretary of Defense Perry said today that American aid to Russian military conversion programs should continue, despite the fierce opposition by the United States to the Russian plan to build nuclear reactors for Iran.

title: The Schubertiade, Bravely Evolving
description: The Schubertiade project at the 92d Street Y, once aimed in a straight line toward the Schubert bicentenary in 1997, has taken detours and shortcuts, but it perseveres. The original idea was to lay out in chronological order the entire work of the short-lived but amazingly busy composer. This has been abandoned in favor of annual mix-and-match concerts like the first of three this season held on Saturday night.

title: In Frail State, Knudsen Taps A Rescue Pro
description: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation, struggling with the worst crisis in its 83-year history, yesterday named Robert S. Miller Jr. as its new chairman.

title: Welfare Reform Will Fix a Mindless System
description: To the Editor:

title: Gingrich Is Seeking To Restore Gay Ban In Military Services
description: The Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, said today that Congress would reopen the issue of homosexuals in the military and would seek to undo President Clinton's two-year-old policy, known as "don't ask, don't tell, don't pursue."

title: Equity Offerings Expected for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible-debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Losing Hope of Regaining Senate, Democrats Focus on House
description: Many leading Democrats have all but given up hope of regaining control of the Senate in 1996 and are concentrating on persuading wavering House members to run again in the hope of recapturing that chamber.

title: DANCE
description: Perchance to Dream, Or Bicker, or Scramble Colloquium Contemporary Dance Exchange Merce Cunningham Studio

title: For Connecticut Women, a Perfect Ending
description: Yes, the Connecticut women's basketball team played many weaker teams while Tennessee played one tough team after another this season. Yes, Tennessee had more depth, more physical explosiveness. Yes, Tennessee had the sport's most celebrated coach in Pat Head Summitt. And yes, her team had one chance after another to put Connecticut away today in the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: 8 Are Killed in Gaza Explosion Seen as Hamas Bomb Accident
description: At least eight people were killed today when a bomb blew up in a Gaza City neighborhood that is reputed to be a stronghold of Hamas, the militant Palestinian group, the Palestinian police said.

title: Withholding Care From Patients: Boston Case Asks, Who Decides?
description: A Massachusetts doctor's refusal to take extraordinary steps to keep alive a comatose patient suffering from irreversible brain damage has intensified the debate over whether physicians or family members should determine when further treatment is futile.

title: Market Place; Kodak, taking the digital plunge, will line up with computer giants.
description: DESPITE misgivings by some analysts, the stock market appears to be applauding Eastman Kodak's decision to plunge into digital photography using alliances with some of the big players in the computer world.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9 DISCONTENT IN EGYPT

title: Let's Take New Look At Pesticide Hazards
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing; On both sides of the political spectrum, the battle over censorship of books continues to rage.
description: IT must be a backlash against the backlash against the backlash against the "anything goes" mood of the 1960's. Whatever the case, personal politics and books are tangling more than ever these days, eliciting cries of censorship from one side or the other, or both.

title: BASEBALL OWNERS QUIT FIGHT; OPENING DAY IS SET FOR APRIL 26
description: Major league baseball owners, faced with no viable alternative, today accepted the players' offer to return to work, ending the longest work stoppage in professional sports history on the day the 1995 season was supposed to open.

title: Welfare Reform Will Fix a Mindless System; Surviving in America
description: To the Editor:

title: From Byrne to Basilone Arena?
description: A bridge, a statue and a high school football field now honor John Basilone, a Raritan native who was a Marines Corps hero on Guadalcanal and on Iwo Jima, where he was killed.

title: Burkhardt & Christy Sells Equity Interests
description: Burkhardt & Christy in New York has sold equity interests to two top executives and has been renamed Burkhardt Christy MacDougall Mitchell. The terms were not disclosed.

title: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; Dreamworks' founders seem incapable of thinking ugly, which is the only way their venture will succeed.
description: A SPECIAL-EFFECTS Oscar should go to the reality-distortion field that surrounds the latest mad coupling of Hollywood and the technology elite.

title: S. A. Cain, 92, Conservationist And Ecology Pioneer, Is Dead
description: Stanley A. Cain, a pioneering conservationist who helped develop the science of ecology and served as an assistant secretary of the Interior Department in the 1960's, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 92.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the smuggling of fuel from Albania to Yugoslavia misstated the volume of the illegal trade estimated by international monitors. They said the smuggling had reached nearly 1 million liters a day at times, about 264,000 gallons, not 1 million gallons.

title: DANCE
description: Woman or Goddess Facing the Underworld Nancy Zendora St. Marks Danspace

title: CHRONICLE
description: George Armstrong Custer's personal battle flag, his campaign shirt and other artifacts -- including arrows pulled from his brother's body -- will be auctioned in San Francisco tomorrow.

title: Seagram Is Believed To Be Close to Sale Of Du Pont Shares
description: The Seagram Company is close to a deal to sell its nearly 25 percent stake in E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company back to the company for nearly $10 billion in cash, several people familiar with the negotiations said last night.

title: Joining Forces, Police Officers Don't Miss a Beat
description: At the stroke of a new day yesterday, Robert Zink, a boyishly good-looking former high school linebacker, got a new identity.

title: Gibson Greetings Inc.(GIBG,NNM) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income(Loss)The latest year's results included total financing and derivative transaction expenses of $ 8,193,000, compared with $ 12,477,000 in 1993.The net loss for 1994 also reflected a pretax charge of $ 16 million from write-offs associated with the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing of F&M Distributors Inc., a major customer, and a $ 1.7 million pretax charge for severance costs associated with efforts to improve the profitability of corporate headquarters and the greeting card division.Prior year results have been restated to reflect the accrual of unrealized net losses on derivative transactions.

title: American Greetings Corp.(AGREA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 17,182,000, or 23 cents a share.

title: Benefit for Danspace Features Meredith Monk
description: Meredith Monk and the cast of "Stomp!" will be the featured performers in a benefit on April 25 at 7 P.M. for the Danspace Project, which produces dance performances at St. Mark's Church. Robert Crane, vice president of the Joyce Mertz-Gilmore Foundation, will be honored for his leadership in cultural philanthropy. Tickets for the event, which will take place at the church (Second Avenue and 10th Street, East Village), start at $150 and include cocktails, dinner and the performance. Information: (212) 674-8112.

title: Mets Happy To Finally Be Bound For Camp
description: Bret Saberhagen will be on the mound here Monday, throwing a baseball for the first time since Aug. 10. Rico Brogna will bring his bats, and hit in a cage, with the hopes that he can open the 1995 season with the same eye-opening performance he had during his truncated rookie year. And, after weeks of sitting home while the replacement Mets drove to Thomas J. White Stadium, Todd Hundley can hop in his truck and drive the 10 miles there himself.

title: Boy's Death Is Linked to Bacterial Meningitis
description: An 8-year-old Queens boy died yesterday of what authorities are calling a likely case of bacterial meningitis, a highly contagious disease that has recently appeared in the United States in a new, aggressive strain.

title: Essay; Newt's 100th
description: As King Louis XVIII re-entered Paris on a fine June day in 1815, after the defeat of Napoleon Bonaparte, the Count of Chambord bowed in welcome and coined a phrase: "A hundred days have elapsed, sire, since the fatal moment when your Majesty was forced to quit your capital in the midst of tears."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Big-name advertisers like Nestle and Nike make big changes on accounts totaling $200 million.
description: MARCH went out like a lion on Madison Avenue, as advertisers like AT&T, F.T.D., Mobil, Nestle and Nike made changes late last week on advertising, media and interactive accounts with billings estimated at more than $200 million.

title: Paris Journal; Notre Dame's Organ and Computer Are No Duet
description: After spending $2.2 million to bring the celebrated 19th-century pipe organ in Notre Dame Cathedral into the computer age and announcing success with great fanfare in December 1992, the French Ministry of Culture has a problem: the modern technology is not working.

title: Dressing Up a Sitcom Idea With Metaphoric Accessories
description: Whatever Doug Wright's "Watbanaland" lacks (charm, credible characters, any certainty of tone), it definitely has symbols to burn.

title: Edwards (A.G.) Inc.(AGE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Tuberculosis Resurgent
description: Health professionals are losing the struggle to control tuberculosis, an infectious disease that will kill some three million people this year, mostly in poor nations but increasingly in wealthy societies as well. The woefully underfinanced campaign has had only scattered successes around the world. Worse yet, skimpy or misdirected programs in many countries may inadvertently be spreading the disease, thus doing more harm than good.

title: Is Bell Atlantic in Nynex's Future?
description: Is Nynex destined to be acquired by Bell Atlantic?

title: A New Definition of Friendly Rivalry
description: The Net reserve center Jayson Williams was asked to describe what went down today between the Knicks and the Nets, why two franchises from opposite ends of the league cannot seem to get along on the floor, how they always end up behaving, well, the way Rick Mahorn usually behaves.

title: A Walk Down 150 Years Of Faith and Tradition
description: From its massive limestone facade to its soaring sanctuary, the synagogue of Congregation Emanu-El is a place of superlatives. But even within the grandeur of the world's largest synagogue, perhaps nothing soars higher or runs deeper than the dreams and faith of its founders.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: Sports of The Times; As Always, the Huskies Can Rely on Lobo
description: REBECCA LOBO's parents hadn't spoken with her before the game, the game yesterday afternoon that would decide the N.C.A.A. women's national basketball championship between Connecticut and Tennessee.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a report in a medical journal -- questioned by some experts -- that a baby infected with the AIDS virus cast off the infection by the age of 1 misstated the number of times the virus was cultured from the baby. It was found in two tests, not four.

title: Hewlett-Packard to Enter Home Computer Market
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company plans to announce today its first entry into the market for home computers, with three lines of aggressively priced multimedia Pentium machines that it plans to sell through consumer electronics stores. And the Compaq Computer Corporation, in what could be a pre-emptive strike against its new competitor, will announce new features for its best-selling Presario machines.

title: Pledge of Protection Halts Hutu Flight From Burundi
description: Tens of thousands of Rwandans fleeing refugee camps in Burundi halted their flight today after their leaders became convinced that the Tanzanian Government would not open its borders and that the Burundian Army would protect them, United Nations officials said.

title: DANCE
description: Weaving Bodily Structures Amid Mounting Tension Annabella Gonzalez Dance Theater Theater of the Riverside Church

title: For Slain Singer's Father, Memories and Questions
description: Abraham Quintanilla still sees his daughter not as the 23-year-old Tejano music star who was gunned down on Friday but as a little girl, twirling to the sound of her own voice on the lawn behind their home in a modest neighborhood.

title: Fire in an Engine Forces Passengers Down Emergency Chutes at Kennedy
description: The tail engine of a Caribbean-bound American Airlines jet caught fire on a taxiway at Kennedy International Airport yesterday and, while the flames were quickly extinguished, the aircraft was halted, emergency chutes were deployed and all 108 passengers and crew members were safely evacuated onto the tarmac.

title: A Mellower Graham Parker
description: Some of the Graham Parker fans who packed Tramps on Friday night may have been wondering: Where's the bile? Since 1976, when his first album appeared, Mr. Parker has built a dedicated following with songs that lash out at hypocrisy and smugness. He arrived just before punk-rock as part of England's pub-rock movement, which valued the craftsmanship of 1960's soul, folk-rock and country music; his rage never tore apart his songs. And through most of the last two decades, he has been articulately snarling at everyone from estranged lovers to unthinking consumers.

title: For Stocks, Winners Outnumbered the Losers by 2 to 1 in This Year's First Quarter
description: After a dismal 1994, investors may have needed a reason to party. So far this year, they certainly have, celebrating the least bit of good news by sending the stock market to new highs and individual issues soaring in the first quarter. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 companies, which serves as a general proxy for the market, rose 9 percent in the first three months of 1995, compared with a loss of 1.3 percent last year.

title: Sports of the Times; Arkansas-U.C.L.A.: A Championship That Deserves the Name
description: BASICALLY, the Final Four boils down to this for me: The attraction is not the fanfare, not the idea of "being there." I like championship things. Basketball, men's or women's; tennis, men's or women's. Marbles. Double Dutch. Championship instances thrill me: the best competing for high stakes in world-class, no-tomorrow-type situations.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY JET CATCHES FIRE AT KENNEDY

title: Yankees in Good Shape For Start of Real Games
description: Buck Showalter did not want to waste a minute of possible preparation time. Before he knew the details of today's ownership meetings in Chicago, Showalter said he hoped the real Yankees would work out informally Monday and Tuesday in Florida and then have a supervised workout with the coaching staff Wednesday.

title: First Union Settles With U.S. Over Loans
description: The First Union Mortgage Corporation will pay the Justice Department $6.3 million to settle claims that its employees falsified information on borrowers' forms for mortgages guaranteed by the Department of Veterans Affairs.

title: Finish Line Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Familiar Attitudes on Gay Life Paint a Clear-Eyed Portrait
description: Most gay men can probably complete the sentence fragment that is the title of "The Only Thing Worse You Could Have Told Me. . . .," Dan Butler's very funny, very moving one-man show.

title: Police See Link to Sheik In 6 Arrests
description: The police in the Philippines have arrested six Arab men linked to the accused ringleader of the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center in New York, and seized a cache of weapons and explosives from their Manila apartments, the police announced today.

title: Trump Walks a Tightrope In Plan to Sell Casino Stock
description: In recent years Donald J. Trump has announced his return from the financial troubles that denied him the enormous yacht, the Boeing 727 and the helicopter he so adored. But a close reading of the documents he released last week as part of his plan to sell stock in his least troubled gambling casino shows the financial tightrope he is walking.

title: An Old Sport Has Seen the Future, and Its Name Is Ernie Els
description: On the beach in Montego Bay, Ernie Els assumed the position. His powerful legs were bent slightly at the knees and his thick arms hung, natural and relaxed, from wide shoulders, like pythons from a tree limb. It is the classic athletic posture, and from it Els could spring up for a rebound, take on a pulling guard, drive a fastball, stop a penalty kick, hit a 120 mile-an-hour tennis serve or -- as was the case on this afternoon -- smash a cricket ball.

title: New York City Tourism
description: By all indications, 1994 was a banner year for tourism in New York City. The weak dollar, an improving economy and big events like soccer World Cup and the Gay Games healped attract almost 25 million visitors to the city. Travel experts also credit the continuing decline in crime and the reduction in the tax for hotel rooms for the surge in tourism. The combined city and state tax fell to 13.25 percent plus $2 a room from 19.25 percent plus $2 on Dec. 1. But hotels and travel agents began to see an increase in bookings months earlier, when the cuts were announced.

title: Raritan Ferry Site Inspected
description: Months ago, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said it was considering passenger ferry service to Manhattan from the Edison docks along the Raritan River. Last week, the authority's supervisor of ferry service, Donald J. Lilioa, inspected the docks.

title: Put the Judges Back in Justice
description: Boiling water must be handled with care. Every day millions of Americans nonetheless heat water past 212 degrees and make coffee with it. Many then get into their cars, hot coffee in hand. Some may burn themselves.

title: Accounts
description: * Lechmere, Woburn, Mass., has kept Houston Effler Herstek Favat, Boston, on its account after a review conducted by the retail chain's new parent, Montgomery Ward. The billings were estimated at $10 million. Houston Effler retained the account after a creative shootout with David Cravit/CME, Chicago, the Ward agency.

title: Lady Huskies Win It All, and Girls Across Connecticut Cheer
description: It was a typical gathering of basketball fanatics, with tortilla chips and bean dip, a mammoth television broadcasting the game and feverish fans whooping their devotion.

title: Edisto Resources Corp.(EDS,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income attributable to common stock was $ 88,000. Figures included a charge of $ 1.7 million for equity in the loss of the company's affiliate, Convest Energy Corp., and restructuring charges of $ 2.7 million associated with opening and closing offices.c-Reflected income from continuing operations. Share earnings were 55 cents a share after a 4-cents-a-share loss from discontinued operations. Net income attributable to common stock was $ 7,151,000.The latest year's results included a gain from sale of oil and gas properties of $ 4.7 million, a loss from discontinued operations of $ 500,000, a charge of $ 1.7 million for equity in the loss of the affiliate, Convest Energy, and restructuring charges of $ 2.7 million. The company recorded an added charge of $ 1.2 million due to the recalculation of its depreciation, depletion and amortization for 1994 based on its reserves at year-end.d-Reflected income from continuing operations. Net income was 17 cents a share after a 6 cents-a-share loss from discontinued operations. Net income attributable to common stock was $ 2,178,000.The 1993 year figures are not applicable because the company emerged from bankruptcy on June 29, 1993.

title: Bon Voyage for a Bottle
description: Seven months ago, six New Jersey boys and girls lamenting the end of their summer vacation in North Carolina put their greetings, names and addresses into a plastic bottle and heaved it into the Atlantic.

title: Sports of The Times; There's No Winner, Only a Big Loser
description: FOR all the rhetoric from the owners and the players regarding their treaty to open the baseball season on April 26, the bottom line of this laborious labor dispute is that there is still no bottom line.

title: Poor Town Finds an Angel in a White Coat
description: The old man swore he saw angels.

title: To Our Readers
description: Starting today, as a service to readers seeking to focus on particular companies, articles inBusiness Day will use bold type for the first mention of each parent company. Because the Company Index on the second business page lists parent companies, the prominent typography will simplify searching for references cited there.

title: Health Systems Accepts Offer From Wellpoint For $1.8 Billion
description: Fending off a hostile takeover bid by California Blue Shield, Wellpoint Health Networks and Health Systems International signed a definitive agreement over the weekend under which Wellpoint would acquire Health Systems for $1.8 billion, people close to the accord said yesterday.

title: 'Dateline NBC' Stands Tall in Ratings While Rival News Magazines Slump
description: NBC gave a party last week to celebrate the third anniversary of its news magazine, "Dateline NBC," partly to show off an elaborate new $1 million set, and partly just to revel in the fact that the program is still around.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: When Determination Guides a Performance The Lark Quartet Weill Recital Hall

title: Goran Capital reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Throngs of Boat People to Be Sent Home to Vietnam Soon
description: Governments throughout Southeast Asia are to begin sending Vietnamese boat people home within weeks, with the United Nations breaking tradition to help in the effort to push tens of thousands of the migrants back to Vietnam by the end of the year, diplomats and United Nations officials say.

title: Senate Takes Up Change in Civil Suits
description: The differences between the Republican majorities in the two houses of Congress will be thrown into sharp relief this week when the Senate takes up the high-stakes battle over whether to change fundamentally the nation's system for resolving civil disputes in court.

title: Walker Signs With Giants
description: The Giants and Herschel Walker agreed on a contract yesterday that will return the running back to Giants Stadium, according to Pat Hanlon, Giants director of public relations. Terms of the contract were not disclosed. The team will hold a news conference at Giants Stadium today to announce the signing.

title: Toxic Logic in Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The actor DENNIS FRANZ , a star of "N.Y.P.D. Blue," married his girlfriend of 13 years in a private ceremony on Saturday. It was the first marriage for Mr. Franz, 50, and the second for his girlfriend, JOANIE ZECK , 47.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The principles established at the Nuremberg war-crimes trials have done little to prevent crimes against humanity in the 50 years since, one of the former prosecutors says.

title: Aegon N.V. (AEG,N) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized gains on shares and real estate of $ 93 million in the latest year and $ 75 million in 1993.Aegon said that the per common share earnings in 1993 have been adjusted for share dividend.Revenue represented total revenues.Results are in U.S. dollars; average rate was $ 1 equaled NLG 1.82 (1993: $ 1 equaled NLG 1.856).

title: Washington Memo; Tax Cut Edges Out Deficit As G.O.P.'s Guiding Tenet
description: There is considerable evidence in public opinion polls that Americans put a greater priority on balancing the budget than cutting taxes. At the same time, there is considerable anxiety among Republican lawmakers that their promise to produce a balanced budget by the year 2002 will be substantially complicated by their pledge to also provide nearly $200 billion in tax cuts over the next five years.

title: Campbell Mithun Loses Executive
description: Pat Burnham, an executive vice president and executive creative director at Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., will leave that agency, where he has worked for six months, to join McKinney & Silver in Raleigh, N.C., as executive vice president and creative director.

title: Buffs
description: Ruth Rauch loves the theater, loves it so much, she told a Times reporter recently, that she goes to something like 200 shows a year. Ms. Rauch, then, has put in some pretty bad evenings on some pretty hard chairs. Never mind. "It just makes me feel good," Ms. Rauch says. Ms. Rauch is a buff.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week: MONDAY Central Vt Pub Svc Oxford Inds Inc TUESDAY Pacific Enterprises THURSDAY Amer Wtr Wks Inc General Pub Utils Corp Grace W R & Co Sun Inc FRIDAY NY St Elec & Gas Corp US West Inc

title: Compaq Computer Will Use Nexgen Chips
description: In an effort to cut its dependence on chips from the Intel Corporation, the Compaq Computer Corporation is planning to use processors from closely held Nexgen Inc. in future personal computers.

title: Trying to Cut Welfare the Ohio Way
description: When Gov. George V. Voinovich of Ohio proposed deep cuts in welfare benefits for able-bodied adults four years ago, he predicted that many recipients would finally get off the dole and find a job. Welfare advocates, meanwhile, spun doomsday scenarios about large increases in homelessness, crime and even death on the streets.

title: Canada Flouts Sea Law in Fish Dispute
description: To the Editor:

title: Ballet Director Appointed
description: Roy Kaiser has been appointed artistic director of the Pennsylvania Ballet. Mr. Kaiser, a longtime dancer with the company, was named acting director in June 1994 after Christopher d'Amboise resigned as the head of the financially troubled company. Mr. Kaiser's appointment, by unanimous vote of the board, is effective immediately.

title: Kodak Reviewing For New Campaign
description: The Eastman Kodak Company is beginning a review for a new worldwide corporate brand advertising campaign, separate from ads for the company's products. The billings were not disclosed.

title: School for Assassins, or Aid to Latin Democracy?
description: To its supporters, it is a school to teach professionalism to Latin American soldiers and to strengthen fledgling democracies. To its most severe critics, it is an academy of assassins.

title: Arrests in Manila Tied to Bomb Suspect
description: The police in the Philippines have arrested six Arab men they say are linked to the accused ringleader of the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center, and seized a cache of weapons and explosives from their Manila apartments.

title: A Park Called Megan's Place
description: Megan Kanka's terrible death gave rise to a law named after her. Now she will be remembered in a happier way. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will break ground tomorrow for a park to be named after her.

title: Great American Management & Investment Inc.(GAMI,NSC) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 24,000,000, or $ 2.14 a share, and an extraordinary charge of $ 16,300,000, or $ 1.45 a share, on early retirement of debt.c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 87,300,000, or $ 7.87 a share; an extraordinary charge on early retirement of debt of $ 14,200,000, or $ 1.28 a share, and a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 5,100,000, or 46 cents a share.Year-ago results are restated to reflect Lapp Insulator Co. as a continuing operation. The company had reported Lapp Insulator as discontinued, but determined it could maximize the unit's value by retaining and restructuring it.The latest year's income from continuing operations included a pretax gain of $ 61 million on sale of a 30 percent stake in Falcon Building Products Inc., and a $ 28.6 million charge on the restructuring of operations of Lapp Insulator.Year-ago year's loss from continuing operations included a $ 48.9 million pretax gain on sale of Vigoro Corp. common shares and $ 31.2 million in pretax charges on litigation and related costs.(Loss)

title: Tribal Shootout: Rival Factions Behind Conflict
description: Once the most feared warriors along the Niagara frontier, the Senecas, like other Indian tribes in America, had long suffered hard times. Then, in the last half-dozen years, quirks in the laws of the white men who had taken their forests and fields showered tens of millions of dollars on their bleak reservation, with the possibility of even more to come.

title: OPENING DAY IS SET FOR APRIL 26; Replacements Ambling Back To Anonymity
description: They ambled across the marble floors of the hotel lobby in their suits and ties this morning, still acting like members of the New York Yankees yet still wondering where their charter plane was headed. The Yankees had not officially told their replacement players where they were flying.

title: The Rangers' Cup Defense, May Fail Before Playoffs
description: Having suffered what is possibly the beginning of another losing streak, the Rangers headed today to Florida. There, they will prepare to face a team that is playing at their level.

title: Mischief on Mexico
description: Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York is recklessly threatening to block the Administration from providing Mexico loans and loan guarantees. The threat by the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee could be enough to scare off skittish foreign investors, driving the peso lower and worsening Mexico's recession. If Mr. D'Amato got his way, and Congress cut off the loans, the Mexican economy could collapse.

title: Presbyterians, in Peace Forum, Tell Their Fears of Dublin
description: A delegation of Presbyterian ministers came to Dublin last month and told a group of people what many Protestants detest about this overwhelmingly Roman Catholic country.

title: An Ailey Ensemble Pays Tribute to Its Leader
description: Unlike Hollywood, the dance world has never promoted the myth of careers by chance. Being discovered at a soda fountain, Lana Turner style, is not the way dancers rise out of the ranks.

title: Oshawa Group reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included a charge of $ 7.2 million, or 11 cents a share, for a staff restructuring program, in the quarter and year.The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges with the ticker symbol OSH.A.The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Shares Secrets on Iran

title: Where Business Meets Bare Chests
description: The women had come from around the world to whoop at men in feather loincloths and to revel in fantasies.

title: Worries About Military Readiness Grow
description: The Pentagon is spending less on new weapons and equipment than at any time in nearly 50 years, prompting many lawmakers and senior officers to warn that the Clinton Administration may soon jeopardize combat readiness.

title: Kenya Acts to Curb Its Opponents and Press
description: Recent actions by Kenya's Government have been perceived by Western diplomats as the most serious crackdown on the opposition and the press since multiparty elections in 1992.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Prize Winner Explores Some Art-Song Rarities Theresa Santiago, Soprano Alice Tully Hall

title: . . . and a Protector of Profits Takes the Helm
description: In his first week as chief executive of one of the country's biggest newspaper companies, P. Anthony Ridder was asked what his era at Knight-Ridder Inc. might someday be known for.

title: Rhode Island Is Moving To Protect Homosexuals
description: While anti-discrimination laws are being challenged elsewhere, Rhode Island is bucking the national trend by advancing a bill that would grant protection to homosexuals in employment, housing, public accommodations and credit.

title: Will Edney Or Beck Lead the Charge?
description: Tyus Edney, the U.C.L.A. point guard, and the Arkansas floor leader, Corey Beck, were no-shows for a news conference this afternoon at the Kingdome. Edney was receiving treatment on a sprained right wrist. Beck was resting with a minor case of asthma.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday Personal Income . . . Feb. New-Car Sales . . . March

title: There Is Little Joy Among the Fans
description: In the dust and dirt of a city playground, pure baseball is played without hot dogs, heroes or joyless thoughts of major league squabbles.

title: Mubarak's Challenge
description: President Hosni Mubarak's visit to Washington in the coming week will take place as he is being confronted at home with rising discontent and mounting accusations of human rights abuses, governmental corruption and mismanagement that are driving away foreign investors.

title: Trans World Airlines Inc.(TWA,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 2,005,000.c-Net income, which included extraordinary gains of $ 902,657,000 in the quarter and $ 1,075,581,000 in the year.Trans World Airlines said it reduced its operating loss in 1994 by $ 179.6 million from a year ago to $ 104.4 million, excluding nonrecurring charges in 1994 of $ 175.1 million.As reported, these special charges principally relate to T.W.A.'s recognition of impairment of the value of certain international routes and certain other assets, a write-off of purchase deposits and capitalized interest related to future aircraft deliveries, severance payments, and a charge for payments due to employees represented by the I.A.M. under a 1992 labor agreement.Reflecting these nonrecurring charges, T.W.A.'s operating loss for the latest fourth quarter was $ 216 million, compared with an operating loss of $ 119.7 million in the year-ago period.The company said net income of $ 623.8 million reported in 1993 was attributable to T.W.A.'s emergence from bankruptcy on Nov. 3, 1993, including fresh start accounting adjustments which resulted in income, as reorganization items, of $ 268.1 million, extraordinary gains of $ 1.08 billion from the discharge and cancellation of debt, and pension settlement expense of $ 342.4 million.Revenue is total operating revenues.

title: Owners End a Battle, But the War Isn't Over
description: As Bud Selig tried to walk away at last from the most ignominious chapter in the history of sports labor relations, a lone voice called out to baseball's harried interim commissioner with some unsolicited advice yesterday.

title: Schneider Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 18
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Editor Named for Revived House & Garden
description: Leaping from a battered ship to a venerable vessel being raised from the magazine graveyard, Dominique Browning was named yesterday as editor in chief of Conde Nast's House & Garden, which is to be revived in September 1996.

title: No Headline
description: "My hypothesis is that it's like a diamond in the center of the earth, just one single crystal." -- DR. RONALD E. COHEN, a geophysicist, describing the earth's inner core. [ C1:5 ]

title: In a Preliminary Farewell, Poignant Songs of Loss
description: The sounds of the words "verlorne Gluck" seemed to have a special weight in Elly Ameling's recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night. Meaning "lost happiness," they appear in Goethe's text for Schubert's "Erster Verlust," or "First Loss." But as they emerged in this finely wrought performance, the vowels seemed to deepen and darken, so the word "Gluck," coming at the end of a phrase, seemed ripe with fulfillment, invoking a memory laden with past pleasure.

title: Purcell Unstaged, the Better to Be Heard
description: In an ideal world like the one envisioned by Purcell at the end of "King Arthur," William Christie would have been able to conduct this supple, sensuous score in the fully staged production that he led in Paris a few months ago. That acclaimed staging came complete with Graham Vick's vision of battling armies and floating spirits, and a restored version of John Dryden's text. As it turned out, only a concert version could be financially justified during Mr. Christie's weeklong visit to the Brooklyn Academy of Music with his group, Les Arts Florissants.

title: For Conner And Koch, Sailoff Is Last Hope
description: The way Dennis Conner figures it, his boat, Stars & Stripes, has a 50-50 chance of beating Bill Koch's Mighty Mary in the sailoff Tuesday for a berth in the America's Cup defense finals.

title: Senator Can't Stop Elephants
description: The issue before the Senate today was simple: whether to allow the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus to offer a free event on the grounds of the Capitol featuring "circus elephants and performers."

title: Israel's Not to Blame For Stalling Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League YANKEES -- Assigned Mark Carper, Frank Eufemia, Guillermo Hernandez, Dave Pavlas, Daryl Smith, John Sutherland and Kent Wallace, pitchers; Scott Epps, catcher; Matt Stark, first baseman; and Rich Barnwell, Bubba Carpenter, Lew Hill and Paul Thoutsis, outfielders, to Columbus of the International League; Tom Carter and Joe Long, pitchers; Roger Burnett, Kevin Riggs and Brian Turner, infielders; and Alex Cabreja and Steve Phillips, outfielders, to Norwich of the Eastern League; and Al Drumheller and Blaise Kozeniewski, pitchers; and Shane Spencer, outfielder, to Tampa of the Florida State League.

title: The 2 Sides Agree on Back-to-Work Plans
description: They went through nearly eight months of a strike without reaching agreement, but on the first day after the strike ended, lawyers for the players and owners reached one yesterday. They completed the back-to-work agreement, creating a timetable for on-field games and off-field mechanics.

title: Picking a Wallet to Unfold
description: Everyone agrees that the state needs to refinance the trust fund for road and transit improvements. But how? Should the money come from the state's gasoline tax? Or from a surcharge on motor vehicle registration? Those questions occupied a joint session of the Senate and Assembly appropriations committees yesterday. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman wants to extend the registration surcharge, which costs car owners an average of $22.50 a year. Senator Bill Haines, a Burlington Republican and chairman of the Senate Transportation Committee, favors using 9 cents from the state's gas tax of 10.5 cents a gallon, because some of that money would come from out-of-state drivers. "It's a fairer system," he said.

title: Explosive Is Dismantled at Halfway House
description: The New York City police yesterday dismantled a small, partly completed explosive device found in a halfway house for teen-agers on Staten Island, the police said.

title: Devils Trade Fetisov
description: Vyacheslav Fetisov, who pioneered the exodus of hockey players from Russia to the National Hockey League, was traded to the Detroit Red Wings yesterday by the New Jersey Devils, who brought the heralded defenseman to the United States six years ago.

title: Woolworth Goes Outside for President
description: Again turning to the outside for leadership in its turnaround efforts, the Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that it had named Dale W. Hilpert, chairman and chief executive of Payless Shoesource, as its president and chief operating officer.

title: On My Mind; Cover-Up Chronology
description: The evidence is now in -- not all of it yet, but enough to prove that the U.S. Government knew a year in advance that Mexico was headed for financial disaster. The chronology shows that the Administration used the year to keep the information secret and feed the American public a false, knowingly deceptive line about the strengths of the Mexican economy.

title: Budget Talks Deadlocked as Blame Flies
description: Negotiations over a new state budget remained deadlocked today as Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders spent the afternoon blaming each other for the impasse.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC., Greensboro, N.C., the textile maker, said its denim division signed a tentative agreement with India's Mafatlal Industries, a unit of Arvind Mafatlal Group, to manufacturer and market denim in India. CINCINNATI BELL INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC., Cincinnati, a subsidiary of Cincinnati Bell Inc., bought X International, an English company that provides software and services for telecommunication companies. DOSKOCIL COS., Oklahoma City, which produces and sells branded and processed food products, said it had changed its name to Foodbrands America to reflect the company's diverse offerings of perishable food products. MANHATTAN BAGEL CO., Eatontown, N.J., plans to acquire I. & J. Bagels Inc., a California bakery and retail chain, through a stock swap valued at up to $16.9 million.

title: 2 Troopers Indicted In Hit-Run Cover-Up
description: Two New York State troopers have been indicted in a scheme to cover up evidence in a 1993 hit-and-run accident where the driver was another trooper's brother, the Westchester County District Attorney said.

title: I'm O.K., You're Nowhere Near O.K.
description: IT'S ALL THE RAGE Crime and Culture By Wendy Kaminer 292 pages. Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $22.

title: New President Of Wesleyan Is an Alumnus
description: Douglas J. Bennet Jr., Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs and a former head of National Public Radio and the United States Agency for International Development, will be elected on Friday as the next president of Wesleyan University, officials at the university in Middletown, Conn., said yesterday.

title: By Design; Movie Star Handbags
description: For years, it was the shoulder bag that women preferred. Then it was the backpack, which is still practical when hands need to be free to carry other things. But women are rediscovering the traditional handbag, the one that is literally carried in the hand. It looks good for dress-up occasions and doesn't mar the line of a tailored jacket or a delicate dress.

title: Market Place; As competition heats up, big utilities hunt for acquisitions.
description: RICHARD B. PRIORY, the president and chief operating officer of the Duke Power Company, the huge utility covering much of North Carolina, is loaded for bear.

title: Fire Guts a Town's Only School
description: A smoky fire destroyed this town's only school last night, forcing the evacuation of 15 families who live across the street from the school, injuring four firefighters and leaving 130 pre-kindergarten through eighth-grade pupils without a place to attend classes today.

title: MDS Health Group reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Talisman Energy reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 24,884,000 in the latest year and $ 24,273,000 in 1993.The company said production reached record levels in 1994, due mainly to the acquisition of Bow Valley Energy Inc. and the first full year of production from the former Encor properties. Results for Bow Valley have been included from the acquisition date of Aug. 1, 1994.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: INSIDE
description: An Unanticipated Proposal

title: Postal Service To Expand Roster
description: The United States Postal Service said yesterday that it was seeking to add two or more shops that specialize in sales promotion and direct marketing to its agency roster, which until now has been limited to units of Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York.

title: Raytheon Offers $2.3 Billion for E-Systems
description: The Raytheon Company said today that it had agreed to pay $2.3 billion in cash to acquire E-Systems Inc., a military contractor that builds top-secret spying equipment and other advanced electronic gear.

title: Helene Curtis Industries Inc.(HC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 1,351,000, or 14 cents a share.

title: Japan's Ito Applies for Reinstatement
description: The former world figure skating champion MIDIRO ITO has applied for reinstatement that would make her eligible for future world championships and the 1998 Winter Olympics in her native Japan. However, the biggest surprise on the list released yesterday by the International Skating Union was the omission of last year's Olympic gold medalist, OKSANA BAIUL of Ukraine.

title: Mets Make Franco an Offer
description: The Mets took the first step toward re-signing John Franco, their free-agent closer, today when General Manager Joe McIlvaine offered him a two-year deal worth just over $2 million a season. Franco has interest from a handful of other clubs, including the Orioles. But Franco said today that he is most interested in returning to the Mets.

title: Southwestern Public Service Co.(SPS,N) reports earnings for 12mos to Dec 28
description: b-Before preferred dividends of $ 4,878,000.c-Before preferred dividends of $ 5,261,000.

title: Rite Aid Corp.(RAD,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 4
description: b-Net lossc-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 23,744,000, or 27 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 16,920,000, or 19 cents a share, in the year.(Loss)Rite Aid's year-ago quarter loss included a pretax provision of $ 149,196,000 for restructuring.The last-in, first-out (LIFO) method of valuing inventory reduced net income by 5 cents a share in the latest fourth quarter, and by 1 cent a share, in the year-ago period. The LIFO method of valuing inventory reduced net income by 11 cents a share in the latest year, and by 7 cents a share in the prior year.The company said that excluding the restructuring charges, it would have reported income from continuing operations of $ 42,965,000, or 49 cents a share, for its year-ago quarter. For its prior year, the company said it would have recorded income from continuing operations of $ 116.8 million, or $ 1.33 a share, excluding the provision.The latest periods included 14 weeks for the quarter and 53 weeks for the year, compared with 13 weeks and 52 weeks for year-ago periods, respectively.

title: State Troopers Are Indicted In a Cover-Up
description: Two state troopers have been indicted in a scheme to cover up evidence in a 1993 hit-and-run accident where the fleeing driver was the brother of another trooper, the Westchester County District Attorney said today.

title: Almost Anything Goes in Birth Science in Italy
description: First there were the "granny moms," a series of women who had babies in their 50's, even in their 60's. Then there was the case in January of baby Elisabetta, who was supposedly conceived from an egg taken from a woman who had died two years before and carried to term by her father's sister.

title: Telemundo Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary gain of $ 130,482,000 due to retirement of debt associated with its Chapter 11 proceedings, in the quarter and year.c-Net lossThe share earnings were not applicable as company adopted fresh start reporting as of Dec. 31, 1994, after recapitalization.

title: Bittersweet Success; The Failure of Replacement Baseball Is a Labor Victory, and an Exception
description: In the 1920's and 1930's, deployment of club-swinging company goons stirred sympathy for striking workers and made the American labor movement an institution in the nation's mainstream. In the eight-month baseball strike that ended on Sunday, management deployed the club of the 1980's and 1990's, the permanent replacement worker.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Italy

title: PACIFIC PHYSICIAN TO GET TEAM HEALTH IN STOCK SWAP
description: Pacific Physician Services Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Team Health Group Inc. for about $52.4 million in stock. Team Health, based in Knoxville, Tenn., a provider of physician staffing and management services for hospital emergency and radiology departments, had revenue of $66 million for the fiscal year ended July 31. Pacific Physician, a health care management company in Redlands, Calif., said that it would issue 3.1 million new common shares in exchange for all the outstanding securities of privately held Team Health.

title: Clinton Edges Congress in Amount of Television Coverage, Study Says
description: Contrary to conventional wisdom, the Clinton Administration has received more coverage on the three major television networks during the first three months of 1995 than the new Republican-controlled Congress has received, according to a new survey.

title: Bassett Furniture Industries Inc.(BSET,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 510,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Digital Commerce column in Business Day yesterday, about alliances between technology companies and Hollywood, misstated the size of a recent investment in Dreamworks SKG by Paul Allen, a co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation. It was $500 million, not $500,000.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Madison Avenue hails baseball's return, but don't try to increase those fees just yet, sports fans.
description: ONE of the loudest sighs of relief at the end of the longest, most bitter strike in baseball history is emanating from Madison Avenue, which spends an estimated $1 billion annually on sponsoring everything from broadcasts of games to the signs that festoon stadiums.

title: Singapore Maintains Guilt of Executed Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: Francisco Moncion, 76, a Charter Member of New York City Ballet
description: Francisco Moncion, a charter member of the New York City Ballet who danced its leading roles for nearly 40 years, died on Saturday at his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 76.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARVIN GAYE 3D became a father on Saturday, the 11th anniversary of the death of his father, the soul singer, The Associated Press reported.

title: EchoStar Communications Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: EchoStar Communications said the amortization of original issue discount associated with its sale of $ 624 million of Senior Secured Notes in June 1994 hurt net income for the period.The company said the amortization of original issue discount and other interest expense totaled, net of amounts capitalized, about $ 21.4 million for the year ended Dec. 31.EchoStar also said it partially offset the effects of the amortization by investing the proceeds of its bond offering and other funds in interest-bearing securities, which generated about $ 8.4 million of income for the year ended Dec. 31.

title: Bronfman Sees More Hope In Films Than Chemicals
description: News that the spirits and beverage company Seagram wants to sell its 25 percent stake in Du Pont for nearly $10 billion may be a good move for Du Pont investors, who showed their interest yesterday by nudging up the chemical company's shares 50 cents.

title: George Darling, 89; Ecologist Studied Effects of A-Bomb
description: George Bapst Darling, a Yale University ecologist who studied the long-term radiation effects of the American atomic bombing of Japan, died on Thursday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 89.

title: A Bigger Danger Than Iran
description: Russia's unwillingness to cancel the sale of light-water nuclear reactors to Iran, which it made clear yesterday, raises long-term security concerns for the Middle East. But any significant United States cutbacks in aid to Russia in reprisal would raise the prospect of even greater dangers.

title: Full Inquiry Into Death Of a Girl, 4
description: The New York State Health Department said yesterday that it was beginning a full-scale investigation into the death of a 4-year-old girl who bled to death four days after undergoing a tonsillectomy last month.

title: Rating Is Cut For Prudential
description: The rating of the Prudential Insurance Company of America was reduced a notch, to "excellent" from "superior," because of weak earnings and lawsuits resulting from improper sales practices at its securities and insurance subsidiaries, the A. M. Best Company said yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Fabric Softener Sheets

title: TORCHMARK TO SELL ENERGY SUBSIDIARY FOR $115 MILLION
