Cherry Corp.(CHERB,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a gain of $ 1,542,000, or 17 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Year-ago periods were restated to reflect a stock dividend in July 1994.

title: Union Lists Those Who Did Not Back Strike
description: Nearly 300 players who once played in the major leagues and were members of the union served the 27 clubs as replacement players during the strike-stricken exhibition schedule, lists compiled by the union show.

title: Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MERRILL LYNCH CUTS CHRYSLER EARNINGS ESTIMATES
description: Chrysler Corporation's earnings estimates for this year and next were cut yesterday by a Merrill Lynch & Company analyst because of higher marketing costs and continued competitive pressures. The auto analyst Harvey Heinbach also put Chrysler's stock under review after last week's $55-a-share, or $20.5 billion, takeover proposal from the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian and Lee A. Iacocca, former Chrysler chairman. Chrysler said last week that the company was not for sale. Chrysler shares closed yesterday up 12.5 cents, at $48.

title: MCA Considers An Affiliation With Spielberg
description: MCA Inc. has confirmed that it is considering an affiliation with Steven Spielberg and David Geffen, two founding partners of the Dreamworks SKG studio, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: Valmont Industries(VALM,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Hat Trick for Turgeon Pierre Turgeon, continuing his strong play since joining the Canadiens, scored three goals last night, lifting Montreal to a 5-2 victory over visiting Washington. The victory moved Montreal within 2 points of the Rangers and Whalers, who are tied for the eighth and final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference. The Canadiens have seven games remaining. Turgeon, acquired in a trade with the Islanders on April 5, scored on a power play in the first period. He also connected twice in the third period, including an empty-net goal with 21 seconds remaining. Since being acquired by the Canadiens, Turgeon has scored eight goals in eight games. (AP)

title: A Good Listener Who Writes Plays On Social Justice
description: Emily Mann specializes in "theater of testimony," a phrase she borrows from the South African director Barney Simon. In her plays, real-life characters act as witnesses to dramatic events in their own lives. In her new play, "Having Our Say," Ms. Mann offers an essential example of her approach, as testimony is delivered by those indomitable centenarian sisters, Sadie and Bessie Delany.

title: Franklin Electric Co.(FELE,NNMX) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
description: Franklin Electric said costs and expenses increased to $ 57,119,000 in the latest first quarter from $ 45,809,000 in year-ago period, as the company acquired Oil Dynamics and put more money into its international operations.

title: Knicks Look Like Pretenders Instead of Contenders
description: The Knicks had plenty of excuses available if things didn't go as well as expected against the Milwaukee Bucks last night at Madison Square Garden. There was the emotional challenge of trying to rebound from a disappointing defeat at Chicago on Sunday afternoon, and there also was the fatigue factor of playing their fourth game in five days.

title: Metro-Richelieu reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 11
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GEN/RX INC., Fort Collins, Colo., a veterinary drug company, acquired Apotex Inc.'s human injectable pharmaceutical division for 15.4 million Gen/Rx common shares, worth about $32.7 million. MEDALLIANCE INC., Brentwood, Tenn., a medical diagnostic service company, completed the sale of 15 outpatient diagnostic imaging centers to Health Images Inc., Atlanta, for about $73 million.

title: Johnson Controls Inc.(JCI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
What Will a Dollar Buy? A Ticket to See the Mets
description: In a bid to lure fans back to the ball park, the Mets announced a promotional package today that includes half-priced refreshments during the month of May and $1 tickets for two games on opening weekend at Shea Stadium.

title: Draft Could Turn Carter Into a Top Rookie
description: The busted brown La-Z-Boy in the living room and the pile of empty pizza boxes and beverage bottles leaning against the kitchen wall of Ki-Jana Carter's apartment complement his contemporary American college decor.

title: PNC Bank Corp.(PNC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Coastal Bancorp, Portland, Me., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell $60 million of senior notes.

title: O'Sullivan Corp.(OSL,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a loss of $ 226,823, or 1 cent a share, from discontinued operations.

title: Man Who Killed Parents Flees
description: A man who killed his parents 15 years ago was on the loose yesterday after walking off the grounds of the Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital. Manalapan police officials said William Jennings, 39, was last seen on Saturday. A spokeswoman for the State Department of Human Services said that Mr. Jennings had grounds privileges that permitted him to walk unattended on hospital property. The police said he used a deer rifle on Easter Sunday in 1980 to kill his parents, then called to his sister: "I've just shot and killed Mom and Dad. Call the relatives and tell them I've done it." He was found not guilty by reason of insanity.

title: MGIC Investment (MTG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Where Brancusi's Independent Road Led
description: It was a measure of Constantin Brancusi's ambition that he walked most of the way from Romania to Paris in 1904 to complete his art studies here. Three years later, at the age of 30, the sculptor's career seemed to look up when he joined the studio of the French master Auguste Rodin. But after just one month, he walked out.

title: Quietly and Without Crowds, China Buries Elder Statesman
description: In a ceremony bereft of public participation, Communist Party leaders attended the cremation and burial today of Chen Yun, the powerful conservative patriarch who died a week ago.

title: Tennant Co.(TANT,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Leader Financial Corp.(LFCT,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $ 1.3 million, or 12 cents per share, from certain real estate activities.c-Included pretax gain of $ 2.2 million, or 12 cents per share, for sale of a limited partnership.

title: Dark Matter Search Hints At New Shape For Galaxy
description: THE trouble with living inside the Milky Way is that the nearby stellar trees obscure the galactic forest, and much of what astronomers think they know about this galaxy's appearance and structure is inferred rather than seen. Unfortunately, inferences drawn from sketchy data sometimes turn out to be wrong, and new measurements reported last week are forcing theorists to reconsider their ideas about the Milky Way -- and perhaps all galaxies.

title: Scripps (E.W.) Co.(SSP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included start-up costs for the Home & Garden Television network of $ 2 million, or 2 cents a share, in the latest first quarter and $ 200,000 in the year-ago period.

title: Bosnia Peacekeeper's Death Divides French Government
description: With France approaching the end of its presidential election campaign, the deaths of two French soldiers in Sarajevo over the weekend have exposed divisions within the governing conservative party on what to do about the war in Bosnia.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Fighting words from a former President: GEORGE BUSH gets very angry at the suggestion that there are ulterior motives to his love for country music. "A lot of the sophisticated Beltway pundits would have had the American people believe that this was an affectation on my part, that I was saying I liked country music to be a good ol' boy and thus get people along the South or in Tennessee or Texas to vote for me," Mr. Bush said in an interview for a cable television station in Nashville, The Associated Press reported. The conversation will be broadcast tomorrow on the Nashville Network.

title: Kysor Industrial Corp.(KZ,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
2 Chiron Executives Quit To Join Smaller Enterprises
description: The Chiron Corporation, a leading biotechnology company, lost two senior executives today to smaller privately held enterprises in which it owns minority stakes.

title: Rockwell Int'l.(ROK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Brothers Arrested in Smuggling
description: Two brothers from India were arrested yesterday in connection with a conspiracy to smuggle aliens from India into the United States through Belize and Mexico, prosecutors said. The brothers, Gurmit Singh, 27, and Harvinder Singh, 23, who live in Roselle Park, were also charged in a Federal indictment with laundering some $285,000 from drug trafficking.

title: Computer Cited In Amex Delay
description: The American Stock Exchange delayed the opening of equity trading yesterday because of a computer malfunction, an exchange spokeswoman said.

title: Marie Antoinette as a House Guest
description: The cast of "A Royal Affair," by Luis Santeiro, gets so caught up in the inspired silliness of the play that one hardly notices when the story simply disintegrates in the second act. The story is not crucial in a farce like this, and Max Ferra, the director, has evidently decided to play every gesture and line for laughs. The production, at the Intar Theater (420 West 42d Street, Clinton), gets plenty of them.

title: Sherwin-Williams Co.(SHW,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Now Hundley Catches Pitches Instead of Flak
description: This is the fourth year that Todd Hundley has come to the Mets' spring camp with the club-wide expectation that he would be the everyday catcher. In each of the three previous years, he found himself dogged by questions -- about his throwing ability, his confidence, his hitting. It was suggested that he wasn't ready. Or that he would lose his job to Charlie O'Brien. Or that Kelly Stinnett would be the Mets' opening-day starter in 1994.

title: VLSI Technology Inc.(VLSI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company said the latest first quarter contained 13 weeks, compared with 14 weeks in the year-ago period.

title: Hunt (J.B.) Transport Services Inc.(JBHT,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included gains of about $ 1 million, or 3 cents a share.c-Included gain of $ 2.7 million, or 7 cents a share, on the disposition of certain revenue equipment.Revenue is operating revenues.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What's it like for an actor and singer to be on the audience side of the footlights when his son performs? Just plain fun, says MANDY PATINKIN, who will be a spectator tonight at the Kaye Playhouse when his 12 1/2-year-old son, ISAAC GRODY-PATINKIN, plays Claudius in "The Death of Hamlet." The occasion is a benefit for Jacques d'Amboise's National Dance Institute.

title: Thirty-Two Cents Short
description: On a day when they did not need it, New Jerseyans got bad news about their taxes. Their state ranked last -- again -- for return on the tax dollar, according to a study released yesterday. New Jersey gets back only 68 cents of every dollar it sends to Washington.

title: Criminal Charges on Pap Test Make No Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Wabash National Corp.(WNC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
On My Mind; Dole In Bosnia
description: Senator Robert Dole is talking about how the United States got into and fought the war in Vietnam. He calls it incrementalism and is critical. He also talks about Bosnia and what he intends to do about that.

title: Q&A
description: Weather Patterns

title: A Church's Chief Executive Seeks the Target Audience
description: Like many other chief executives, H. Edwin Young has spent the 90's streamlining. Through a series of land deals, he sold off chunks of a 180-acre site on which he had hoped to build a new headquarters. That helped him slash long-term debt to $13 million from $26 million.

title: Megastores Mean Lost New York Jobs
description: The Giuliani administration wants to take rezoning steps that would bring big suburban discount retailers and warehouse stores into New York City areas zoned for industry. If the Mayor succeeds, he will put at risk thousands of jobs, especially in the boroughs outside Manhattan.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Child's Play No Longer A Simple Proposition
description: PARENTS know that computers will be a major part of their children's futures, but often they do not know what to do about it. Buy a computer? Sure, but what kind? Buy software? Sure, but which few titles out of thousands?

title: Nellcor Inc.(NELL,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1.23 million, or 7 cents a share, from a litigation settlement, in the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included a $ 500,000 restructuring charge.

title: Arts Library to Close a Floor
description: The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center has announced that it will close its third-floor research collections on June 26 for two and a half months to install a new heating and ventilation system. The divisions involved are the Billy Rose Collection, the Dance Collection, the Music Division, and the Rodgers and Hammerstein Archives of Recorded Sound.

title: Black Unity Finds Voice In Colombia
description: For Piedad Corboda de Castro, the first black woman to become a senator in Colombia, a recent visit here for a human rights conference also allowed her to solidify a growing relationship between black Latin Americans and black Americans.

title: Comsat Files a Patent Infringement Suit
description: The Comsat Corporation said today that it had filed a lawsuit against the Chronicle Publishing Company, the Baycable Group, and the General Instrument Corporation for reportedly infringing Comsat's patent for a security system for subscriber television systems.

title: MOTOROLA AND AMERICAN SENSORS TO MAKE GAS DETECTOR
description: American Sensors Inc. and a Motorola Inc. unit said yesterday that they had signed an agreement to develop smaller, more sensitive devices to detect hazardous gas. Motorola's Semiconductor Products Sector, based in Schaumberg, Ill., said it would develop a new thin-film semiconductor technology aimed at improving gas sensors by reducing false alarms and lowering power demands. American Sensors, based in Markham, Ontario, said it planned to use Motorola's new technology in its carbon monoxide detectors. Motorola closed down $1.75 in New York yesterday; in Toronto, American Sensors was up 62.5 cents at $13.125.

title: Abitibi-Price (ABY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net lossYear-ago results are restated.Results are in Canadian dollars.(Loss)

description: Healthtrust said that the primary reason for its increases in net income and revenues in the latest second quarter and six months was the addition of Epic Holdings Inc. As reported, the company completed its $ 1 billion acquisition of Epic Holdings in May 1994.

title: Flexsteel Industries Inc.(FLXS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Greener Pastures?
description: Residents in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut metropolitan area are less satisfied with their quality of life than people in some other urban regions, according to polls taken by a planning group. One poll found that 42 percent of the people living in the area would move out tomorrow if they could. Article, page B5.

title: Giuliani's 'Approval' Rating Below 50% in a Second Poll
description: A second poll in five weeks has put Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's popularity below 50 percent as the glow from his endorsement of former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo begins to fade next to the dour impact of his austerity program.

title: U.N. Chief Regrets Iraq's Attitude Toward Offer to Allow Oil Sales
description: Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali "regrets" Iraq's seeming rejection of a United Nations plan to allow Baghdad to sell up to $2 billion in oil over six months to pay for its food, medicine and other urgent needs, the Secretary General's spokesman said today.

title: Russell Corp.(RML,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
The Rich Get Richer Faster
description: The gap between rich and poor is vast in the United States -- and recent studies show it growing faster here than anywhere else in the West. The trend is largely the result of technological forces at work around the world. But the United States Government has done little to ameliorate the problem. Indeed, if the Republicans get their way on the budget, the Government will make a troubling trend measurably worse.

description: The nation's banks have discovered a revolutionary new way to approve small-business loans: Play down human judgment and let computers make most of the decisions.

description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Fashion; Transcending The Machine-Made
description: The vast building in lower Manhattan where Pucci International makes its mannequins is a hive of fashion manufacturing, the elevators rattling with the many languages of the workers who crowd the cars.

title: Pataki Finds Model Family for Tax Plan
description: John and Alyce Muller have two cute children, a house in the suburbs and a dog named Snuggles, and today they found the Governor of New York standing on their front lawn here, proclaiming them average New Yorkers who would benefit greatly from his plan to cut state income taxes.

title: Washington Federal Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The per share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: The Designers' Starting Point
description: Fashion designers are like jugglers, balancing seasons the way jugglers keep china plates spinning in the air. While working on one collection, they've got to think about next year's collections and order fabric for them.

title: Life in the Metropolis Found Lacking
description: People living in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut metropolitan region are less satisfied with the quality of life in their communities than are residents of four other parts of the country, according to polls released yesterday by a regional planning group.

title: Shopkeeper Claims Jackpot
description: Pravin T. Patel, 40, of Jersey City, and his wife, Sumitra, 37, came forward yesterday to claim their half of last week's $35.7 million lottery jackpot. The storekeeper said he would share his fortune -- a yearly check for more than $600,000 -- with his three children and 60 other relatives who live in New Jersey. The owner of the other winning ticket, bought in Essex County, has yet to come forward.

title: Stevens Playing Like $17 Million
description: Last month, when the Devils were struggling to earn a spot in the playoffs, Scott Stevens, their captain, was as guilty as anyone for New Jersey's ineffective performance. He made mistakes on defense and was almost invisible on offense.

DPL Inc.(DPL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

description: Whatever the problem, the solution is now obvious: jail.

Christine Todd Whitman, no matter what office she might seek in the future. Mrs. Whitman has apologized for an interview published in Britain last week, in which she said she had been told that young black men make a game of seeing how many children they can "sire" out of wedlock. Mr. Fields and others, many of whom question the existence of such a game, said that her apology cannot erase the damage her words caused.

title: INFINITY BROADCASTING GETS APPROVAL TO BUY KLUV-FM
description: The Infinity Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that the Federal Communications Commission had approved its purchase of KLUV-FM from TK Communications Inc. for about $51 million. The acquisition of the Dallas-Fort Worth radio station is part of Infinity Broadcasting's strategy of acquiring stations in the largest markets in the United States, the company said. The acquisition will lead to formation of the company's fifth top-10-market duopoly, since Infinity Broadcasting, based in New York, already owns KVIL-FM, the biggest revenue radio station in the market, Infinity said.

title: School Budget Vote Today

description: TRW Inc. reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings surged 79 percent, spurred by strong automotive-parts sales and improvements in productivity and operating margin.

title: A Writer Becomes His Hero In 1876
description: What kind of a weekly series gig could Richard Dean Anderson possibly find after ABC's "MacGyver" (1985-1992), in which his Special Forces hero got out of one scrape after another with such unlikely scientific tools as a paper clip or a candy bar? Try the United Paramount Network's "Legend," which, although set in 1876, teams up Mr. Anderson with an odd, ahead-of-his time scientist whose inventions are just dandy for last-minute rescues. Two of the executive producers for this new show, having its premiere tonight on Channel 9, are Mr. Anderson and Michael Greenburg, formerly the producer of "MacGyver."

title: CHAMPION HEALTHCARE GETS HEALTHTRUST HOSPITAL

Healthtrust, based in Nashville, received Federal Trade Commission approval to sell the Salt Lake City hospital to Champion, which is based in Houston, on April 10. The sale of the hospital was required by the F.T.C. to resolve antitrust concerns that Healthtrust's acquisition last year of Holy Cross Health Services of Utah would reduce competition for hospital services in Salt Lake City.

title: THERMOLASE SURGES ON APPROVAL OF HAIR-REMOVAL LASER
description: Thermolase Corporation shares surged 70 percent yesterday after the skin-care products maker said the Food and Drug Administration had approved a laser-based long-term hair-removal device. Shares of Thermolase, which is owned by Thermotrex and based in San Diego, closed at $23, up $9.75, in American Stock Exchange composite trading. The hair-removal treatment uses a laser to remove unwanted hair, similar to electrical devices that remove hair follicles. The Lorad division of Thermotrex will make the laser.

Pliant, respectful, uncomplaining, with nary a thought of stealing your job or toppling your privilege! Hard working, with solid family values, and just begging for the opportunity to attend to your personal grooming. It is so difficult to find good help these days, and harder still to find an employee who will happily fetch your coffee and dry cleaning.

description: Mexico's state-owned oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, said today that its domestic sales of refined products rose to 1.562 million barrels a day in the first two months of the year, a 3.2 percent increase from the corresponding period last year. Pemex, which has exclusive rights for manufacturing, warehousing, transporting and distributing oil byproducts in Mexico, sold 499,900 barrels a day of gasoline in the first two months of 1995, up 2.9 percent from the corresponding period last year.

title: Sports of The Times; Steinberg's Doing This Other Thing
description: HE is the Jets' general manager, but he didn't go to any of the college all-star games or bowl games. He wasn't at the scouting combine in Indianapolis to inspect the huge slabs of prime beef that will go to market in the National Football League draft this weekend. He didn't stop at any campus to time a whippet wide receiver in the 40-yard dash.

Those questions were before a jury in Federal Court yesterday in a lawsuit in which Ms. Brounstein, a prize-winning cat breeder, is seeking unspecified compensation for humiliation and damage to her reputation.

title: MERCK CLEARED BY F.D.A. TO SELL NEW HYPERTENSION DRUG
description: Merck & Company said yesterday that it had won approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing Cozaar, a new hypertension drug. Cozaar is part of a new class of hypertension medicines. Analysts have said that Cozaar's annual sales could reach $200 million. The approval was announced after the stock market closed. Earlier, Merck shares closed up 25 cents, to $43.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Falling Nets Lose To Rising Celtics
description: Just over five weeks ago, on this same parquet court, you wouldn't have known these teams. The Boston Celtics were run off their own floor, the Nets were talking about an April date with Orlando, and the bottom feeders of the Eastern Conference could do nothing about it.

title: In a Video Rush, Phone Groups Aren't Waiting For Fiber Optics
description: The Pacific Telesis Group is leaping into the nascent business of wireless cable television. The company is expected to announce today that it will acquire Cross Country Wireless Inc. in a deal worth $175 million.

title: Stryker Corp.(STRY,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Stryker said that the latest first quarter included the operations of Matsumoto Medical Instruments Inc., its Japanese distributor, which became a 51 percent owned subsidiary last August. As a result of the consolidation with Matsumoto, net sales and net earnings for the first quarter of 1995 increased by $ 43 million and $ 1.9 million, or 4 cents a share, respectively, from the year-ago period.

title: Patterns
description: 'Todd Oldham Forever'

title: Attari Road Journal; At the Border, Smiles and Tea (and Hidden Tanks)
description: This quiet way station on the frontier between India and Pakistan has been called Asia's Checkpoint Charlie. But to many travelers who have passed this way, the comparison seems to mistake something in the complex relations between India and Pakistan.

title: Officer Injured in Scuffle at Coney Island
description: A police officer was injured by a bottle thrown during a scuffle with a group of youths at Coney Island early yesterday morning, a police spokesman said.

title: Time Warner to Sell Control Of Six Flags for $1 Billion
description: Time Warner Inc. announced yesterday its expected $1 billion deal to sell control of its Six Flags theme park business, in a move that will help it reduce its huge debt load.

title: The Brain's Evolution In the Family of Man
description: Running somewhat athwart the current fashion for diversity, Roger Bingham, host of "The Human Quest," asks, "Why are we so alike?" In the enlightening four-hour series tonight and tomorrow night at 8 on PBS, the answer is traced to the brain, mankind's common heritage.

title: Ndeti and Pippig Transform the Big Run Into a Rerun
description: They stood side by side -- Cosmas Ndeti of Kenya holding three fingers aloft, Uta Pippig of Germany holding two -- signifying their consecutive victories in the Boston Marathon, one having silenced a legion of doubters, the other having charmingly satisfied all expectations, both having combined to establish a first in the event.

title: Alfa Corp.(ALFA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Goodfellow reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss(Loss)The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Lions Find Peace Without Rankings
description: FOR most group-living species, the definition of social means knowing your place and showing it at every opportunity. In rare cases, however, the assembled animals do not bother forming a dominance hierarchy, preferring instead a form of relaxed anarchy. The most outstanding example of a species that lives in a stable group without bothering to assign rank to its citizens is the lion.

title: Mighty Mary Sails Into A 3-Way Tie
description: It pays to carry along a boat's most critical spare parts when it comes to America's Cup racing. The crew on Mighty Mary found that out today when its 27-foot spinnaker pole broke in half like a bent matchstick.

title: 4 at Oxford Capital Are Guilty in Fraud
description: New York State prosecutors said that three founders and the president of Oxford Capital Securities Inc., which is now defunct, have been convicted in a $10 million illegal investment scheme.

title: China Industrial Group Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The shares outstanding assume full conversion of convertible preferred shares issued in January.

title: Intel and Sun Register Strong Profit Surges
description: Fueled by a strong computer market, the Intel Corporation and Sun Microsystems Inc. both reported financial results today that far exceeded the most optimistic of Wall Street analysts' expectations.

title: No Audience For a President?
description: What if the President gave a prime-time news conference and no one came?

title: Syquest Technology Inc.(SYQT,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included a gain of $ 346,000, or 3 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: TRAVELERS GROUP (TRV,N)
description: Travelers Group said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings from operations slipped 1.3 percent, as profits plunged in its Smith Barney Inc. securities unit.

title: People
description: * George J. Simko, who retired Jan. 1 as president of the European and Mideast operations of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, was named to the new position of chairman of the executive committee of the board. * Howard Meditz, senior vice president and director for client services at Marquardt & Roche, Stamford, Conn., was promoted to president, succeeding Jim Marquardt, who was named co-chairman along with Ed Roche, who was previously executive vice president and creative director. Also, Tom Hackett, senior vice president and creative director, was promoted to the new position of executive vice president and chief creative officer.

title: The Critics All Agree, Tyson Won't Like It
description: Mike Tyson will not like "Tyson."

title: F.D.I.C. Wins Suit in Texas S.& L. Case
description: A Federal judge ordered a house painter-turned-condominium developer today to pay the Government more than $340.5 million in damages stemming from the biggest savings and loan failure in Texas history.

title: F.A.A. to Install New Radar At Nation's Busiest Airports
description: The Federal Aviation Administration pledged today that by the fall of 1996, the nation's busiest airports would be equipped with advanced radar systems that reduce the risk of planes colliding on runways.

title: Mayor's Rationale for Selling Three Public Hospitals Facing Strong Criticism
description: Five members of the board of directors of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation have harshly criticized a report that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has used as a rationale for trying to sell three of the city's public hospitals.

title: The Browns Sign Goad
description: The Cleveland Browns signed the former New England Patriots nose tackle TIM GOAD and the former Washington Redskins special-team member JOHNNY THOMAS, the team said yesterday.

title: Shootout at the On-Line Corral
description: WHEN the smoke cleared, Prodigy stood over its two main rivals in a "shootout" among on-line information services held last week at the Internet World trade show in San Jose, Calif.

title: Coastal Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Year-ago share earnings included a one-time gain of $ 2,022,000, or 38 cents a share, for reversal of an accrual for income taxes.

title: Guidant Corp.(GDT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Figures are pro forma as if the company on Jan. 1, 1994 borrowed $ 513 million under its credit facilities, paid $ 494.1 million in cash dividends, and received proceeds of $ 192.5 million from its initial public offering. Excluding the pro-forma adjustments, the company reported net income of $ 22.9 million in this period.

title: New Travel Service for World Wide Web
description: The New York Times Company and Advance Publications Inc., owner of Conde Nast Publications and Random House, said yesterday that they would cooperate to create a travel information service on the World Wide Web of the Internet.

title: There's a Better Way to Crack a Coconut
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: JUDY EPSTEIN was talking with a man in the steam room of her 50th Street gym. The fellow was complaining that the equipment was always broken. That day it was the whirlpool and the shower.

title: Mellon Bank Corp.(MEL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The year-ago first quarter was restated to reflect merger with Dreyfus.

title: Widow of a Pan Am Crash Victim Is Awarded $19 Million
description: In one of the largest financial awards to an individual in the history of commercial airline disasters, a Federal jury on Long Island has awarded $19 million to the widow of one of 270 people killed in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland.

title: Equifax Inc.(EFX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
A Forecast From Thatcher
description: Take it from Margaret Thatcher, the former Prime Minister of Britain:

title: U.S.C.'s Boselli Is Hungry, but the Pro Scouts Are Hungrier
description: Nuns vouch for him, pro scouts drool over him and Tony Mandarich will not be held against him. National Football League teams are aching to take Southern California's Tony Boselli, a 6-foot-7-inch, 325-pound offensive tackle with stomach muscles. If he lasts more than a half-hour in Saturday's draft, it will be a shock; if he lasts fewer seasons than Mandarich, it will be heresy.

title: Business Travel; How to find an American-operated clinic in the heart of Moscow, day or night.
description: BUSINESS travelers and tourists alike can avail themselves of Western medicine while in Russia, at the Columbia-Presbyterian/Moscow Clinic in the heart of Moscow at 4 Dobryninsky Lane. The outpatient clinic's staff consists of seven United States board-certified doctors who are on contracts and available 24 hours a day.

title: Thurman, Rhodes and Carr to Enter Draft
description: Three more prominent underclassmen -- SCOTTY THURMAN of Arkansas, RODRICK RHODES of Kentucky and CHRIS CARR of Southern Illinois -- decided yesterday to declare for the National Basketball Association draft.

title: Banc One Corp.(ONE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Banc One Corp. said its net interest income for the latest first quarter was $ 1,003,599,000 compared with $ 1,102,709,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Baltimore Gas & Electric Co.  (BGE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Honeywell Inc.(HON,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
In Hebron, Many Israelis Pray for Change of Government
description: By the thousands, Israelis flooded into Hebron today to worship at the Cave of the Patriarchs shrine, prayers that for many were also a bitter anti-Government protest.

title: For Top 2, Unity and Smiles
description: The Governor and the Mayor smiled, praised each other effusively and even shook hands twice before the cameras yesterday at City Hall. They made every effort to make it seem as if they were friendly, though it still remained unclear if they actually like each other.

title: No Headline
description: "I loved, admired and respected my wife when I married her 28 years ago. I still do, and I always will." STEPHEN J. SOLARZ, former Brooklyn Congressman. [ B1:3. ]

title: Slain Woman's Sister Testifies
description: Nesime Dokur of Morristown took the witness stand at the murder trial of her former brother-in-law yesterday and testified that he had a fiery, domineering attitude toward her sister. And, she added, the 1986 marriage of Mohammed and Nihal Abequa soured after their first child was born because he "wanted a servant, not a wife."

title: Argentine President Vetoes Patent Measure
description: Bowing to pressure from the United States over the protection of intellectual property, President Carlos Saul Menem vetoed a key piece of drug-patent legislation today.

title: Idex Corp.(IEX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
District Attorney to Review Homeless Abuse by 'Squads'
description: The chairman of the Grand Central Partnership has asked the Manhattan District Attorney to investigate accusations from former employees that they beat homeless people to roust them from banks and other sites around Manhattan.

title: Dixons Dismissing Saatchi & Saatchi
description: In another account loss attributable to the ouster of Maurice Saatchi, Dixons Group P.L.C., the large British retailer, said yesterday that it was dismissing Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide in London after a review. Dixons said it would move its account, with billings estimated at $60 million to $80 million, to two other shops, including the breakaway agency formed by Mr. Saatchi.

title: Foreign Affairs; Free Advice
description: When Bob Dole announced his bid for President last week he got the loudest applause from his hometown crowd with a foreign policy line. It was when he vowed that when he is President "American policies will be determined by us, not by the United Nations."

title: Armstrong World Industries Inc.(ACK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included restructuring charge of $ 10.1 million, or 24 cents a share on a fully diluted basis, for closing of Braintree, Mass., plant.c-Included gains of $ 9.1 million, or 21 cents a share on a fully diluted basis, for resolution of tax audits and sale of majority interest in Bega/US Inc.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dollar Hits More New Lows, Pulling Down Stock Market

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP., Dallas, a unit of the General Motors Corp., has signed a 10-year agreement worth about $100 million to manage the computer operations of the Birmingham Steel Corp. MCKESSON CORP., San Francisco, a health care products concern, has announced the creation of Mckesson Health Systems, a new unit which will provide pharmaceutical products, information technology services and custom delivery services to health care providers.

title: CoreStates Financial Corp.(CFL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from changes in an investment in Electronic Payment Services Inc., an affiliate joint venture of $ 11,800,000, or 8 cents a share, and a redesign charge for companywide redesign, including organizational restructure and workforce reduction, under the BEST (Building Exceptional Service Together) plan of $ 70,000,000, or 49 cents a share.c-Net loss and an extraordinary charge related to Constellation acquisition of $ 3,430,000, or 89 cents a share, and a charge of $ 3,430,000, or 2 cents a share, for change in accounting principle. Before this charge, the operating loss was $ 29,995,000, or 21 cents a share.Year-ago results are restated to reflect the subsequent acquisition of Independence Bancorp, which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.(Loss)

title: Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection & Insurance Co.  (HSB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
In Test of School-Voucher Idea, the Sky's Not Falling but Neither Is Manna
description: Five years into the nation's only school-voucher program, most parents say they are satisfied with the plan, which sends their children to private school at state expense, and attendance is up slightly. But academic performance remains about the same for these students as for public school students.

title: SPRINT CORP. (FON,N)
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that its profit from operations surged in the first quarter as wider long-distance operating margins offset slower-than-expected growth in calling volume.

title: Motor Vehicles Workers Protest
description: Need a new driver's license?

title: School Board Fighting Takeover
description: The Newark Board of Education will try to overturn a judge's order demanding an immediate state takeover of the city's schools. Lawyers for the board said yesterday that they would focus their appeal on the legality of skipping full public hearings before a takeover, not the broader issue of who is responsible for problems in the state's largest school system.

title: Oakwood Homes Inc.(OH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included one-time gain of $ 214,000, or 1 cent a share, for change in accounting for income taxes.

title: U.S. Regulators Drop Bias Proposal for Lenders
description: Federal regulators, bowing to intense opposition from bankers and Republicans in control of Congress, have dropped a proposal to require lenders to collect and report information on the race and sex of their small-business borrowers.

title: Death Tied to Virulent Illness
description: The death earlier this month of an Irvington woman is being attributed to the virulent form of the streptococcus bacteria sometimes called the flesh-eating disease. The woman was not identified. Officials said yesterday that they did not know of any other cases of the ailment in the state. Beginning July 1, the infection is to be added to a list of diseases that must be reported to the Department of Health by doctors and hospitals.

title: VW to Modify TV Commercial
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. has agreed to modify a television commercial for the Audi Quattro after BMW of North America filed suit, according to the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus.

title: Jostens (JOS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 634,000.c-Included a net gain of $ 10,987,000 from disposal of discontinued operations in the quarter and $ 10,177,000 in the 9 months.

title: North American Culture Before the Europeans
description: Tomorrow night brings the first two hours of "500 Nations," an elaborately produced eight-hour tribute to the achievements of North America's Indians hundreds of years before the coming of Europeans. With artifacts, paintings and photographs, models and computer graphics, the programs evoke what Kevin Costner, an executive producer and the host of the series, calls "the human history of North America." The music and sounds seem to come from a windswept past, but the voices of actors like Edward James Olmos and Wes Studi are up to the minute, reminders that the series is under the auspices of CBS Entertainment.

title: Rubbermaid Inc.(RBD,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
A War of the Beaches; Greenwich Battling Suit on Restrictions
description: Compared with the Jersey Shore and Long Island, Connecticut's beaches are small and tame -- and there are far fewer of them.

title: For the First Time, Polonia Takes the Field Alone
description: Luis Polonia only faintly smelled the grass and barely heard the baseballs caroming around Municipal Stadium in West Palm Beach last Saturday during batting practice. Polonia was preparing for a game against the Expos, but his thoughts drifted into dreary, depressing territory because he could not obscure the recurring vision of his mother's death.

title: Morrison Aims to Add I.B.C. Jewel to Crown
description: Tommy Morrison is eating alone these days.

title: U.S. Disaster Relief Expert Missing on Chechnya Mission
description: An American disaster relief expert and five Russian aid workers have disappeared while on an emergency mission to Chechnya, the breakaway region under attack by Russian troops, the State Department and his friends said today.

title: AES Corp.(AESC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $ 3,900,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: Alou Beats Showalter in 'All-Star Game Preview'
description: Buck Showalter of the Yankees and Felipe Alou of the Expos managed against each other tonight as Montreal edged New York, 2-1, in an exhibition game. They used to manage against each other in the Class A Florida State League and they will be doing it again this summer in the All-Star Game.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Black Teen-Agers Are Turning Away From Smoking, but Whites Puff On
description: African-American teen-agers have largely eliminated smoking from their lives, while white teenagers are still taking up the habit at high rates, according to a study reported in The Journal of the National Cancer Institute.

title: LIN Broadcasting (LINB,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net lossLIN Broadcasting Corp. said the latest results excluded the operations of several business it divested in 1994, including the LIN Television Corp.(Loss)

title: Facing Up to Crack Injustice
description: Like just about anyone familiar with drug crimes, the U.S. Sentencing Commission believes Congress went far astray a decade ago when it made punishment for sale or possession of the crack form of cocaine far more severe than for cocaine's powder form. Last week a bare majority of the commission recommended equalizing the two forms of illegal drug trafficking by lowering the crack penalties to those now in place for powder.

title: Treasury Chief Goes to India And Is Upstaged by Iranian
description: Nobody told Robert E. Rubin that his first venture abroad as Treasury Secretary would be as much fun as one of Hillary Rodham Clinton's elephant rides.

title:
Real Estate;
Symbol Technologies plans to buy an L.I. property that housed Grumman Data Systems.
description: IN a deal that illustrates the growth of the computer industry on Long Island amid cutbacks by military contractors, Symbol Technologies plans to buy a property occupied by the Grumman Corporation before it became Northrop Grumman.

title: Coram to Merge With Lincare in A Billion-Dollar Health Venture
description: In the second billion-dollar consolidation of home health care companies in two months, the Coram Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Lincare Holdings Inc. in a stock deal that valued Lincare at about $35 a share, or $1.38 billion, based on yesterday's closing price of Coram.

title: A Hunger Strike Is Abandoned
description: At least one of the two Rutgers students who began a hunger strike last week has abandoned the effort, intended to force the resignation of the university's president, Francis L. Lawrence. The second student has not been seen at the protester's unofficial headquarters since Monday. Mr. Lawrence has been under fire for remarks about links between heredity and standardized test scores.

title: City Council Orders Review of 33 Business Improvement Districts
description: The City Council has ordered the 33 business improvement districts in New York City to open their books for an investigation that seeks to determine whether they have amassed too much power without adequate oversight.

title: CROWN RESOURCES STOCK RISES ON OFFER
description: Shares of the Crown Resources Corporation gained $1.25 yesterday, to $5, following Monday's offer by Battle Mountain Gold Company to buy Crown Resources in a stock swap valued at $69.3 million. The offer, which expires in 15 days, proposes to exchange one Crown Resources share for 0.4375 share in Battle Mountain Gold. Battle Mountain, which is based in Houston, said its offer valued Crown Resources at $5.25 a share. Battle Mountain -- whose shares gained 12.5 cents, to $12.125 -- said its board made the offer in response to a recent inquiry from Crown Resources. However, a statement from Crown Resources, based in Denver, called the offer "unexpected" and said its board was reviewing the proposal.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Whalers Move Into 7th Spot Darren Turcotte's soft wrist shot from the point with 3 minutes 14 seconds remaining was enough to give the visiting Hartford Whalers a 2-1 victory over the Buffalo Sabres last night.

title: Ancient Mosques Along Silk Road Are Falling Apart
description: The dazzling mosques, cupolas and minarets of this ancient caravan city, which have helped shape the sacred framework of Islamic life for more than a thousand years, are falling to pieces. So are many of the mosaics and mausoleums of Samarkand and Khiva, this struggling country's two other fabled staging posts for the Silk Road, the route of spiritual, economic and intellectual commerce between Asia and Europe for centuries.

title: Henry A. Dudley, Lawyer, 82
description: Henry A. Dudley, a Washington lawyer who aided many educational, civic and charitable organizations, died on Sunday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 82 and lived in Washington.

title: Enter, Women
description: Next Thursday, businesses across America will participate in "Take Your Child to Work Day" -- and this has many feminists up in arms. According to the Ms. Foundation, which promotes "Bring Your Daughter to Work Day," girls need a day of their own because they suffer from low self-esteem and are typically "shortchanged" in school.

title: ACTIVIST INVESTOR URGES CHANGES AT CHASE
description: Michael Price, the activist investor who has purchased a 6 percent stake in the Chase Manhattan Corporation, turned up the heat on the big bank's management yesterday, calling for "dramatic change" at its annual shareholders meeting. In a question to Thomas G. Labrecque, the chairman of the nation's sixth-largest bank, Mr. Price took credit for the rise in Chase's stock to $44.75 yesterday; it was $35 before the 11-million-share purchase by Mr. Price's Heine Securities was disclosed. He said that an acquisition of Chase would be "far superior to the company's current strategy." Officials of Nationsbank, the huge North Carolina banking company, have said they would like to acquire Chase, although they have not approached it.

title: Earnings for Times Company Climbed 54% in First Quarter
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its earnings rose 54 percent in the first quarter, reflecting higher profits in the company's operating groups as well as higher equity from forest products operations.

title: Clark Stillman, 87, Rare-Book Collector
description: E. Clark Stillman, a collector and dealer in rare books, died last Wednesday at Cabrini Medical Center. He was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Jacobs Engineering Group (JEC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Long March Of the Arms Contractors; They Migrate South For Cheaper Labor in The Lower-Cost States
description: For years, the Lockheed Corporation centered its aircraft manufacturing in Burbank, Calif., where thousands of workers built prosperous lives on wages that reached as high as $20 an hour. That factory is closed now and wildflowers grow through crevices in the concrete that surrounds the shuttered buildings. The new heart of Lockheed's operations beats most strongly today here in Georgia, where the company makes its military planes with lower-cost labor.

title: Grantham's Departure Is Prompting Questions
description: National Basketball Association players were portrayed yesterday as being outraged that they have not been informed of the reasons behind the abrupt resignation of their union leader. Some players, according to their agents, believe the union is engaged in a cover-up of the real reasons for the departure of Charles Grantham.

title: History Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: State Street Boston Corp.(STT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 2.6 million, or 3 cents a share, for transaction costs related to the acquisition of Investors Fiduciary Trust Co.Year-ago figures are restated to reflect the acquisition.

title: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.(FRE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss on retirement of debt of $ 44,000,000.Year-ago quarter included a $ 16 million of non-recurring gains.

title: Multimedia Inc.(MMEDC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included an after-tax loss of 7 cents a share related to the launch of NewsTalk Television.c-Included an after-tax gain of $ 2.1 million, or 5 cents a share, from the sale of two radio stations.

title: Moments Of Inspired Insanity
description: In his three sonatas, Opus 10, Beethoven performs radical renovations on houses built by his predecessors. The vestiges of sonata-form practice are visible, but the C-minor's first movement, for example -- with its sudden excursions to C major, then G-flat minor -- jolt the ear from any Classical-era expectations. Alfred Brendel's second Beethoven recital, on Monday at Carnegie Hall, began with these three pieces and ended with the "Hammerklavier" Sonata. In the last, Beethoven is his own architect; no one has built anything like it before or after. The tools are also different, namely a piano of newly developed construction: larger, wider and more powerful than the clear, discreet instrument of the early sonatas.

title: Still Too Many Secrets
description: When he campaigned for the Presidency in 1992, Bill Clinton made the noble promise that he would reduce government secrecy. Three years and many bureaucratic battles later, President Clinton has approved a compromise that moves in the right direction, but not far enough.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Other Worlds, Other Times
description: What, you might be wondering, is Rupert Murdoch up to these days, apart from wresting eye-popping tax breaks from Washington politicians? Well, Mr. Murdoch's Fox Broadcasting, still aggressively wooing the young audience dear to the scheming hearts of advertisers, is doing its best to make sure viewers focus on any world other than the world they live in. Forget about what is really happening; fantasize about what might happen. Diversions, diversions.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: SCREENING TRIMS WELFARE APPLICANTS

title: Citicorp (CCI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 56,000,000, or 13 cents a share.

title: Clinton's Prime-Time Presentation Is Shunned by 2 Networks
description: President Clinton was upstaged by two fictional television characters this evening when two major television networks declined to broadcast his prime-time news conference.

title: Steinway & Sons Is Sold for $100 Million
description: Steinway & Sons, the piano manufacturer that has been a New York institution since its founding by Heinrich E. Steinway in 1853, was sold yesterday for $100 million to the Selmer Company, a maker of musical instruments.

title: SBC Communications Inc.(SBC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Year-ago first quarter was restated to conform to current classifications.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON (JNJ,N)
description: Johnson & Johnson reported yesterday a 20 percent increase in first-quarter earnings on strong sales of new products in its professional and pharmaceutical segments.

title: Ex-Head of Salomon Brothers Files Libel Suit Against Time Inc.
description: John H. Gutfreund, the former chairman of Salomon Brothers Inc., filed suit yesterday against Time Inc. in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan, accusing its Fortune magazine of having libeled him in its May 1, 1995, issue by falsely writing that he was barred from the securities industry for life.

title: International Specialty Products Inc.(ISP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: International Specialty Products Inc. attributed its improved net income in the latest quarter to increased sales in all products lines, particularly in specialty derivatives.

title: Matching Whiskies With Food: Best in the Smallest of Doses
description: IN Scotland, those who overindulge in single-malt whiskies sometimes find their way home in wheelbarrows.

title: France Threatens to Withdraw Bosnia Force
description: France, in the last stages of a presidential election campaign, threatened today to withdraw its 4,530 peacekeeping troops from Bosnia unless its diplomatic partners and the United Nations could insure their safety. The Government also demanded that the belligerents return to the negotiating table and extend a cease-fire set to expire at the end of this month.

title: International Briefs; French Aircraft Chief Demands a High Dollar
description: The chairman of Aerospatiale, the French company that co-produces the Airbus, called yesterday on the United States to increase the value of the dollar.

title: ROCKWELL PICKED TO BUY AUSTRALIAN CONCERN
description: The Rockwell International Corporation has been chosen by the Australian Government to purchase Aerospace Technologies of Australia Ltd., the country's Finance Minister, Kim Beazley, said yesterday. Rockwell, the big aerospace and defense company based in Seal Beach, Calif., will soon enter negotiations with the Government to settle on a purchase price for the company, known as Asta. Mr. Beazley said a price will be announced when a final sale agreement is reached, which should occur by the end of June. According to an Australian newspaper report, Asta is not likely to cost Rockwell more than $45 million. The Australian Government announced plans in 1993 to sell Asta, which makes aircraft components such as rudders, flaps and doors, and provides engineering services for defense and other industries.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Saturday about "The Fall Guy" at Playhouse 91 misstated the credits of the actor Mako, who directed the production. He was nominated for a Tony Award for his work in "Pacific Overtures"; he did not win one.

title: Quno Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
description: b-Net loss(Loss)The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Calgon Carbon Corp.(CCC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Restaurant Group Finds It's Niche: Raw, Vegetarian and Fast
description: IMAGINE sitting down to a feast of moussaka marinara, squash, olives and eggplant; Kenyan quiche made with seaweed noodles, corn and carrots; a little coconut soup, enhanced by corn and radishes, and for dessert, Hawaiian sunrise pie, a tropical concoction of bananas, Turkish pears and plums, topped off by a fruit shake sweetened with raisins and dates.

title: Cooper Tire & Rubber Co.  (CTB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Cooper Tire & Rubber Co. said earnings in the latest first quarter were hurt by the continued escalation and accumulated impact of raw material costs.

title: Livery-Cab Driver Killed
description: A livery-cab driver was struck and killed on Monday night by a stolen car being chased at up to 90 miles an hour through Washington Heights in Manhattan, the police said yesterday.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS AND HALLMARK SETTLE DISPUTES
description: The American Greetings Corporation and Hallmark Cards Inc. said yesterday that they had settled disputes over patents used to allow customers to create greeting cards with in-store computers. The disputes began in 1992, when American Greetings and closely held Hallmark began to contest the ownership and validity of patent claims for on-site personalized greeting card machines. The agreement gives each company a worldwide nonexclusive license to use the patent claims.

title: Personal Health
description: SMOKERS are finding it harder and harder to pursue their habit in socially acceptable ways. Smoking has been banned in most public buildings, at work sites and on public transportation and is becoming increasingly unacceptable in restaurants, private homes and cars. Smokers, no longer welcome to light up with cocktails or coffee, while reading the paper or doing their work, are being forced to go outside when they can no longer resist the urge.

description: I LOVE these pictures! They're so cute!" bubbles Linda Ronstadt as she surveys the Howard Chandler Christy murals of frolicking nymphs that line the walls of Cafe des Artistes.

title: Lab Reports Major Gain in Superconductivity
description: The dream of manufacturing cables capable of conducting huge electrical currents without resistance and at relatively high temperatures has come closer to realization because of a new technology unveiled yesterday by the Los Alamos National Laboratory, scientists there said.

title: Fiscal Watchdog for D.C.
description: Two decades after winning limited home rule, the nation's capital has finally had to pay for years of mismanagement by yielding many of its budget powers to a new financial control board of outsiders. But in signing legislation to create the new board, President Clinton was right to say that the District of Columbia has an opportunity as well as a burden. An independent panel overseeing the city's books could give the District something it has not had for years -- credibility. That, in turn, could actually strengthen the case for increased Federal aid.

title: Longtime Informer Is Accused in Killing
description: Over 40 years, Michael Burnett was a confidence man, stock swindler, international thief and a suspected murderer. And when he wasn't trying to elude the authorities, Mr. Burnett was working for them: Across those four decades, Mr. Burnett, working as an informer, also helped the Government recover stolen art, retrieve millions of dollars in embezzled funds and prosecute corrupt elected officials.

title: Nobody Can Keep Pace With John Grisham
description: Highbrow critics may shudder, but John Grisham has once again set the publishing world afire, selling about 300,000 copies of "The Rainmaker" in its first week in bookstores (the initial printing was a record 2.8 million copies). And on May 3, the book will step neatly into the No. 1 spot on the New York Times best-seller list. No one need ask who the real rainmaker is.

title: China Breaks Ranks With Other Nuclear Nations on Treaty
description: China, publicly breaking ranks with the other acknowledged nuclear-weapons powers, said today that it could back an extension of the nuclear nonproliferation treaty for either an indefinite period or a series of fixed periods of no less than 25 years' duration.

title: Agents of Graft -- A special report.; A Cocaine Trail in Mexico Points to Official Corruption
description: On the night last summer that a jet loaded with cocaine touched down near this old mining town in the foothills of the western Sierra Madre, state police officers reported something odd at the local gas station.

title: SONAT'S MERGER TALKS WITH READING & BATES ENDED
description: Sonat Offshore Drilling Inc. announced yesterday that its merger discussions with the Reading & Bates Corporation had broken off following Reading & Bates's rejection of Sonat Offshore's most recent offer. The offer, initially proposed on Feb. 27, was restated in a letter by Sonat Offshore dated last Thursday to the chairman and vice chairman of Reading & Bates. Reading & Bates officially terminated negotiations in a letter dated Monday. According to Sonat Offshore, the restated proposal offered a merger under which Reading & Bates stockholders would get a base price of $8.40 a share in cash or stock or both, plus a warrant to buy Sonat Offshore common stock.

The market valuation does not include the favorable impact of related funding sources.

title: Mayor Takes Council to Court On Independent Police Panel
description: The impasse between Mayor Rudolph W. Guiliani and the City Council over how to monitor police corruption moved to the courts yesterday as aides to the Mayor filed suit against the Council, saying its plan for an independent watchdog panel infringed on the Mayor's powers.

title: Keeping Actors on Pins and Needles
description: Goose and Tomtom, the titular misfits of David Rabe's peculiar and slight play of that name, appear at first glance to be a couple of brain-damaged acid-heads who carry guns and whip them out at every shadow that flits across what is left of their minds. "Wanna shoot somebody?" one asks as the two discuss what to do with the day. "We could find somebody to shoot."

description: Nina K. Soarz, the wife of former Brooklyn Congressman Stephen J. Solarz, pleaded guilty today to two criminal charges, confessing to stealing money from a charitable group she ran and to intentionally writing a bad check on the House of Representatives bank.

description: Using a tough new screening process for welfare recipients, New York City has sharply reduced the number of childless, able-bodied adults accepted for benefits this year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday.

title: Montana, Cool to the End, Says Goodbye
description: Joe Montana today surpassed Chinatown as a tourist attraction. More than two years since he threw his last pass as a San Francisco 49er, he stood in front of 20,000 hero worshipers this afternoon and retired from professional football. The crowd, standing on its toes and attempting in vain to tap him on the shoulder, chanted, "One more year, one more year" -- even if it meant him quarterbacking the Kansas City Chiefs.

For Old Armenians, Sorrows Arrive With Spring
description: THE forsythia at the Armenian Home in Flushing are blooming cheerily and the dandelions wink from the lawn, but for the old people who live there, April remains a time of heavy sorrows. They sit silently in sunny rooms, keeping to themselves what they saw and heard and smelled 80 years ago when their people were scattered and killed in the first of the century's many genocides.

title: NINTENDO TO BUY STAKE IN BRITISH COMPANY
description: The Nintendo Company Ltd. said yesterday that it would purchase a 25 percent stake in Rare Toys and Games Ltd. of Britain, the developer of the best-selling video game "Donkey Kong Country." Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but executives close to the companies said the investment was over $25 million. The investment, Nintendo's first in a software company outside Japan, was motivated by "the opportunity to keep this developer developing games exclusively for the Nintendo platform," said Howard Lincoln, chairman of Nintendo of America. In addition to "Donkey Kong Country," which has sold over 7.4 million copies, Rare Toys is the developer of "Killer Instinct," the most successful arcade video game, which Nintendo plans to release in a home video format as well, Mr. Lincoln said.

title: Anderson & Lembke In Management Shift
description: Anderson & Lembke in New York said yesterday that as part of a reorganization of top management, Alan J. Zorfas, 35, would join the agency in the new position of client services director, leading all its account management teams. He was previously general manager and client services director at Berlin Cameron Doyle in New York, which closed on March 31. Also, Greg Jorgensen, 38, account services director, was promoted to the new position of operations director. Both executives report to Hans Sydow, managing director.

description: The Devils had it all planned. They would defeat Tampa Bay tonight and the Florida Panthers on Thursday to set up a Saturday showdown at Byrne Meadowlands Arena against Philadelphia for supremacy in the Atlantic Division.

title: St. John's McLeod Transfers
description: After two seasons marked by frustration over lack of playing time at St. John's, forward Roshown McLeod is planning to transfer to Duke University. He will have two years of basketball eligibility left after sitting out the 1995-96 season.

title: THREE PEPSICO OFFICIALS SELL SHARES
description: Pepsico's chairman, another director and its treasurer all sold shares in the company last month as the stock climbed. Wayne Calloway, chairman and chief executive, sold 20,000 shares at $39.75, collecting $795,000 in an option-related transaction, according to the Washington Service. Mr. Calloway still owns 189,936 shares in the company according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Another director, Andrall Pearson, sold 20,000 shares at between $40.75 and $41, collecting $817,500. He retained 134,577 shares. And the treasurer, Randall Barnes, sold 21,319 option-related shares at $39.25, for $836,771. He kept 438 shares. Many option holders exercise rights to buy shares at a pre-set price and then sell the shares at the same time, collecting a profit. Pepsico shares closed up 50 cents yesterday at $41.

title: Val Telberg, 85, An Experimenter In Photomontage
description: Val Telberg, a Surrealist-influenced photomontagist who collaborated with Anais Nin, died April 5 in Southampton Hospital. He was 85 and had lived in Sag Harbor, L.I., since 1968.

title: Disney and 3 Bells to Form Venture for Video Services
description: The Walt Disney Company and three regional Bell companies said yesterday that they would form a partnership to deliver video programming over phone lines, but the long-expected announcement said little new about the venture's financing or structure.

title: An Elder Statesman of the Saxophone, Age 34
description: A typical Kenny Garrett solo moves from modern, densely harmonic lines to church shouts, deep blues phrases, rhythm and blues ideas and the mathematical logic of post-Coltrane improvising. Mr. Garrett, an alto saxophonist who is performing at Sweet Basil's this week, changes the relationship of his phrases to the beat, speeding up lines or slowing them down, repeating phrases to build tension. He worries notes, bending them in every way possible, spilling classically balanced be-bop lines over the rhythm section. His is a music of extremes, shouts and repetitions, but it is also an art of increments, of shadings.
