description: Arturo Frondizi, a former President of Argentina who bolstered the country's economy through a series of unpopular austerity measures during four tumultuous years in office from 1958 to 1962, died in Buenos Aires yesterday. He was 86.

title: Office Depot Inc.(ODP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
The Pulitzer Prizes: Journalism and the Arts Bestow a Most Prestigious Honor
description: The Pulitzer Prizes were awarded yesterday by Columbia University in 21 categories for excellence in the arts and journalism. PUBLIC SERVICE The Virgin Islands Daily News

title: International Briefs; Analysts Applaud Profit For Quarter at Banesto
description: Banco Espanol de Credito, the recently troubled bank unit known as Banesto, posted first-quarter earnings of 4.64 billion pesetas, or $37.12 million, showing that the Spanish bank unit was headed toward its first profitable year since 1992, analysts said yesterday.

title: Kaman Corp.(KAMNA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Closing of a Gay Theater, the Site of High-Risk Sex, Is Upheld
description: New York City did not violate free-speech rights when it closed a gay movie theater at which health officials said they had found high-risk sexual activity, a judge has ruled.

title: Johnson Wants to Compete in Atlanta
description: MAGIC JOHNSON, whose brilliant National Basketball Association career was cut short in 1991 after he tested positive for the AIDS virus, wants to play again in the Olympics. "It's his desire to participate in the Olympics in 1996," Johnson's agent, LON ROSEN, said yesterday. "He's been playing for the last year and a half on his tour. The team is 45-0."

title: Barrick Gold (ABX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company said the increase in most financial and operating measures in the latest period reflects the acquisition last year of Lac Minerals Ltd.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When REID VOGELHUT was a 12and just beginning to learn the trumpet, he talked his father into buying him a Dizzy Gillespie album and taught himself to play all the numbers on it.

title: 62 Slain in Raid on Village Near Liberia Port
description: At least 62 people, most of them women and children, were killed last week in an attack on a village near the Liberian port city of Buchanan, officials of the United Nations Children's Fund said today.

title: International Briefs; Iberia Cuts Its Air Fleet
description: Iberia, the Spanish state airline, has reduced its fleet by 19 percent in an effort to secure European Union approval for $1.06 billion Government bailout, a company official said yesterday. As part of a reorganization plan aimed at justifying the bailout, Iberia has eliminated 23 planes, putting its fleet at 97 planes, the official said. It has agreed to freeze its fleet size at that level until the end of 1998.

title: In a Louisiana Bayou Town, 'Uncle Pat' Is the Law
description: This town, surrounded by swamps, has one road in, one road out. If Police Chief Clarence (Uncle Pat) Matherne parks his police cruiser sideways across it, it is a dragnet.

title: Alumni Say Thank You In Their Favorite Way
description: When Charles Kaufman announced that he would step down as dean of the Mannes College of Music this year, the mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade -- a 1969 graduate of the school -- offered to sing at his farewell concert. A few more recent graduates were enlisted to round out the bill, and a Charles Kaufman Scholarship Fund was set up so that proceeds from the concert could be put to good use. There was a full house on hand for the concert at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening, and by the time the lights went down, the school had taken in $210,000 from ticket sales and donations.

title: In America; Safety? Too Costly.
description: How much is a life worth? How much is lost, in dollars, when a little girl dies in agony because her pajamas were not flame-retardant? Or when a baby boy is strangled because the slats on his crib were far enough apart to let him squeeze his head through?

title: Bernice Levy Rudnick; Philanthropist, 77
description: Bernice Levy Rudnick, a philanthropist active with organizations in New York City and in Palm Beach, Fla., died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 77 and also lived in Palm Beach.

title: Seoul Journal; Defectors Find That the Welcome Mat Is Fraying
description: During an escape from North Korea last year, Lee Ok Keum fainted on the frozen Yalu River as soldiers patrolled just yards away. But her husband still managed to bring her and their three children into South Korea to receive a hero's welcome.

title: Alco Standard Corp.(ASN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Alco Standard Corp. said the major components of the three-year transformation program at its Unisource unit are on schedule, with the unit expecting to make $ 100 million in cost cuts by the end of the transformation, though the full effect of the cuts will not be felt until fiscal 1997.

title: Simpson Team Embraces A Witness It Skewered
description: The Police Department's principal evidence collector in the O. J. Simpson case finally completed his testimony today, and on his way out of the courtroom his main interrogator thanked him twice, another defense lawyer embraced him, and both Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. and Mr. Simpson himself shook his hand heartily.

title: Integra Financial Corp.(ITG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Houston Post Bought and Closed by Rival
description: The country's fourth-largest city abruptly became a one-newspaper town today, after the 111-year-old Houston Post was sold to the Hearst Corporation, owner of the larger Houston Chronicle, which immediately shut it down.

title: Inside Peek at a 3-Star Kitchen
description: AROUND 9:15 P.M., my out-of-shape knees began to buckle from nonstop standing in the kitchen, and the Saharan front blowing in from 500-degree ovens nearby hardly revived me.

title: Topics of The Times; Whitman's Brooklyn, Still
description: At the Brooklyn end of New York City's most familiar bridge lies a modest patch of green called Walt Whitman Park, named in remembrance of the most American of poets, who lived, schooled and worked nearby. In the 1840's, Whitman wrote ecstatically of the city's "numberless crowded streets" and the "immigrants arriving, fifteen or twenty thousand a week" and "the teeming nation of nations" taking shape before his eyes. Whitman's vision finds full flower in Brooklyn today with its vast tracts of Arabs, Asians and especially Caribbean immigrants whose accents, colors and flavorings permeate every cranny of the bard's old home.

title: Gasoline Prices at 2 1/2-Year High On Fears of Tightening Supplies
description: Gasoline prices surged to a two-and-a-half-year high yesterday as traders grew concerned about tight supplies in advance of increased demand during the summer driving season.

title: With Return Of Remains, A 'Closure'
description: When they were seniors in Calhoun High School here 28 years ago, Frederick Burns, Joseph Carbone and Stephen Grilli were the best of friends. They made a pact to join the Marines together and fight for their country in Vietnam.

title: Hon Industries Inc.(HONI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
description: b-After a charge of $ 237,000, or 1 cent a share, which reflects adoption of FAS 112, ''Employers' Accounting for Postemployment Benefits,'' effective Jan. 2.

title: Breed Technologies Inc.(BDT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Merrill Lynch Net Falls by 38.9% in Quarter
description: There are signs that the yearlong slump in the securities business is coming to an end, even though Wall Street's first-quarter results have not matched the banner first quarter of a year ago.

title: Topics of The Times; The Huddled Masses Had No Bridge
description: A pending House bill to cut billions in Federal spending seeks to eliminate $15 million for a history-defiling footbridge from New Jersey to Ellis Island. Too bad the Senate's version leaves the money in place.

title: Asian Rhinos and Elephants Go Quietly
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Says Bus Companies Scuttle Tentative Strike Pact
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday said the private companies that provide busing to New York City's schoolchildren had scuttled a tentative agreement between his office and the union representing school bus drivers to avert a looming strike.

title: From the I.R.S. to the P.T.A.
description: Taxpayers still grumpy about sending their checks to the Internal Revenue Service on Monday might be in a better mood next year if Congress would take up this simple idea: why not send $200 less to the I.R.S. and give it instead to the local organization of your choice? It would be a step toward democratizing philanthropy and rejuvenating community life in America.

title: Frontier Corp.(FRO,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a non-taxable gain of $ 4.8 million on sale of Ontonagon Telephone in Michigan, partially offset by a pretax $ 4.8 million charge on acquisition of Minneapolis-based long-distance concern ASI.c-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 7,197,000, or 9 cents a share.

title: Oak Industries(OAK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company said its pro-forma net income per share was 39 cents a share in the latest first quarter, compared with 26 cents in year-ago period. It said the pro-forma data eliminates the effect of the tax-loss carryforward benefit.

title: BOISE CASCADE EARNINGS GAIN SEEN
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings would increase by $60 million from the initial public offering of stock in its office products distribution business. Earlier this month, Boise Cascade, a forest products company, sold about 17 percent, or 4.6 million shares, of the Boise Cascade Office Products Corporation, to the public. Boise Cascade said the offering was made to facilitate the accelerated growth of the office products business, which is based in Itasca, Ill. In the second quarter a year earlier, Boise Cascade -- which is based in Boise, Idaho -- had a net loss of $19.2 million on sales of $1.08 billion.

title: Politician Under Fire; Rockland County Prosecutor Faces Criminal Inquiry -- and Sex Scandal
description: For his two decades as District Attorney, Kenneth Gribetz has been such a towering figure on Rockland County's political landscape that the Republican opposition meekly endorsed him twice for re-election.

title: GTE Corp.(GTE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: GTE Corp. said the year-earlier revenue includes operations through the date of sale for its GTE Spacenet and certain nonstrategic local-exchange properties that were sold in 1994.The company said it had pro forma revenue absent the sold off operations of $ 4,621,000,000 in the 1994 first quarter.

title: Clinton Seeks New Welfare Bill, Saying G.O.P. Plan Is Too Harsh
description: President Clinton tonight repeated his vow to oppose the welfare overhaul passed by the House of Representatives as too harsh on children, and called on Congress to pass by the Fourth of July a comprehensive bill that would put the poor to work and provide greater flexibility for states.

title: Chiefs Tell Lott Hello, Montana Goodbye
description: The Kansas City Chiefs yesterday signed the veteran safety RONNIE LOTT as an unrestricted free agent, according to The Kansas City Star. Lott, who will turn 36 on May 8, played the last two seasons with the Jets. The Chiefs' policy is to refrain from commenting on signings until making an announcement. The team didn't confirm Lott's signing.

title: Dellenbaugh Chases a Miracle
description: What yachtsman with a yen to win wouldn't want to compete on one of the quickest, slickest, most talked-about sailboats in the world? And what if his crew -- an eager but relatively inexperienced group of female athletes -- were in close pursuit of the most sought-after prize in yachting?

title: Cable Price Controls Benefited Everyone
description: To the Editor:

title: A. P. Manginelli, 73; Led Fraternal Order
description: Anthony P. Manginelli, a New York businessman who was the leader of the Loyal Order of Moose, died on April 13 at his home in Syracuse. He was 73.

title: For Fans, This Is Life, Not a Film
description: It was, by all accounts, a must-see movie.

title: What Must Knicks Do? Win, of Course
description: Three games remain. One victory clinches the second-best record in the Eastern Conference. The Knicks are well aware of what they need to do as their regular season nears its end.

title: Rough Seas Suit Young America Just Fine
description: Plowing through deep seas like two whales on the run, the America's Cup defenders went racing today despite conditions that were adverse enough to keep the challengers ashore. Young America won the match by 2 minutes 46 seconds, and that was perhaps more a tribute to its affinity for rough water than to any single error by its opponent, Mighty Mary.

title: International Briefs; Sabena Stake Sale Faces European Hurdle
description: The European Commission said yesterday that it would only approve Swissair's plan to buy a 49.5 percent stake in the Belgian national airline Sabena when it received guarantees that the agreement would not distort competition in the European Union. The Swiss airline and the Belgian Government have been in talks for a year in an attempt to agree to conditions for the sale. The Belgian Government said Sabena needed a cash injection to survive.

title: Monthly Deficit In U.S. Trade Falls Sharply, Lifting Dollar
description: A sharp drop in the United States monthly trade deficit helped lift the dollar today from record lows against the Japanese yen and the German mark. But the increase was not enough to calm foreign exchange markets or stem demands from abroad for action by the United States to bolster its battered currency.

title: Calendar: Auction, Exhibitions
description: Benefit Auction Fashion Institute of Technology, 227 West 27th Street; (212) 760-7158.

title: Delchamps Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to Apr 1
description: b-Net income and the 39 weeks included a gain from cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes of $ 900,000, or 12 cents a share, and a loss from cumulative effect of change in accounting for postemployment benefits of $ 1,600,000, or 22 cents a share.The company said the quarterly results included a pretax restructuring charge of $ 15,000,000 which relates primarily to closed stores that have not been subleased in whole or in part. For the thirty-nine week period ended April 1, 1995, the Company's net loss was $ 10,002,000. The net loss included the pretax $ 15,000,000 restructuring charge noted above. Net earnings for last year's thirty-nine week period include accounting adjustments for changes in the methods of accounting for income taxes and postemployment benefits.(Loss)

title: Timken Co.(TKR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Undertones Of Relevance
description: President Clinton's paramount challenge these days is to persuade the public and a Republican Congress that he has a place in a political debate that risks passing him by. But in his efforts to prove his relevance, he often seems reduced simply to proclaiming it.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in some editions yesterday with an article about Michael Burnett, a longtime Government informer who has been charged with having a Staten Island woman killed, was published in error. The picture, of a man with a mustache, showed an unidentified law-enforcement official who was escorting Mr. Burnett from a courthouse in 1986; Mr. Burnett, clean shaven, was shown correctly in other copies.

title: Showalter Not Getting Much Job Security
description: George Steinbrenner declined today to guarantee that Buck Showalter would manage the Yankees for the entire 1995 season, saying he would never make such a statement about a manager and that it was unnecessary because Showalter is aware of the owner's feelings toward him.

title: Carlisle Cos. (CSL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
International Briefs; In Brief
description: The Microsoft Corporation, Redmond, Wash., will set up two or three joint ventures in China in the next six months to develop and manufacture the software it sells there domestically, a company official said.

title: Allies Split on How to Deal With Serbia Curbs
description: Days before the Security Council must decide whether to extend a partial suspension of sanctions against Serbia, a dispute over how to deal with the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, is fracturing the five-nation group guiding peace efforts in the Balkans.

title: The Gospel of Church Architecture, Revised
description: THE Gothic cathedral was designed to inspire awe and thoughts of transcendence. Megachurches celebrate comfort, ease and the very idea of contemporary suburban life.

title: About the Building
description: COMPLETED -- March 1977 NAMED FOR -- Judge Alfred P. Murrah, of the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, who died in 1975 SIZE -- 9 floors: 178,208 square feet; 4-level parking garage: 219,138 square feet (600 cars) COST -- $13,278,000 STRUCTURE -- Poured in place steel-reinforced concrete CAPACITY -- 590 workers; 41 children in day care

title: People
description: Len Fogge was named president of Franklin Spier, New York, succeeding David M. Cathers, who resigned in January to write a book about Stickley furniture. Mr. Fogge was previously president of the Grey Entertainment unit of Grey Advertising, New York. Michael Baldwin was named to the new position of senior partner and worldwide account director on the I.B.M. Corp. account at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, New York, a unit of the WPP Group. He was previously a senior vice president heading the Compaq Computer account at Ammirati & Puris/Lintas, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos.

title: BANKAMERICA CORP. (BAC,N)
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose about 19 percent, as a stronger economy prompted consumers and companies to borrow more.

title: Electronic Data Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Thompson Out 3 Weeks Because of Elbow Injury
description: Before he left Thomas J. White Stadium on Tuesday night, his flight information to New York in hand, Ryan Thompson swore that his elbow injury would not keep him out of the Mets' opening day lineup next Wednesday.

title: Federal Signal Corp.(FSS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Lugar Says He Will Run for President
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana today announced his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination, trying to make a virtue of his earnest but colorless manner by quoting from the Boy Scout oath and depicting himself as a leader of unblemished character.

title: ABT Building Products Corp.(ARTC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Caterpillar Profit Jumps 56.3%, Beating the Analysts' Consensus
description: Extending its string of record earnings into the fifth consecutive quarter, Caterpillar Inc. reported today that net income rose 56.3 percent in the first quarter, lifted by strong demand for its products.

title: Lam Research (LRCX,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Journal; Dole's Moral Stand
description: "I had never seen a whole episode of 'Murphy Brown,' " wrote Dan Quayle in his memoirs. That minor drawback did not prevent him from turning a light-hearted TV sitcom into a cultural battleground of the '92 campaign. Now, as the '96 campaign revs up, we have had the Easter Sunday spectacle of Bob Dole trying to make political hay by singling out the movie "Priest" on "Meet the Press" as Exhibit A of how Hollywood lacks "family values." Not only has Senator Dole not seen the movie, but he seemed so unfamiliar with its content that he referred to it as "The Priest."

title: American Maize-Products Co. (AZEA,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 3,294,000, or 32 cents a share, related to a plant consolidation and restructuring of its tobacco businesses.

title: HITACHI AND FONAR SETTLE PATENT DISPUTE
description: Hitachi Ltd. and the Fonar Corporation settled a patent dispute involving magnetic-resonance imaging technology yesterday, after opening arguments in a Federal jury trial in Hauppauge, L.I. Fonar, a maker of M.R.I. machines, sued Hitachi and the General Electric Company in 1992 over four Fonar patents related to M.R.I. technology, which is used to produce detailed pictures of the human body. Fonar was seeking $62 million from Hitachi and a subsidiary, Hitachi Medical, and about $300 million from G.E. After the settlement was disclosed, Federal District Judge Leonard Wexler granted a motion by G.E. for a mistrial, a court official said. Lawyers for G.E. argued that reports of the Hitachi settlement would bias the jury against G.E. Fonar, based in Melville, L.I., did not release details of the agreement.

title: Wheelabrator Technologies Inc.(WTI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Westamerica Bancorp (WABC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Figures are stated on a pro-forma basis, to reflect the company's acquisition this year of PV Financial on a pooling-of-interests basis, for 1.18 million common shares, valued at $ 37 million.Year-ago first quarter included a gain of $ 520,000 from sale of available-for-sale security investments.

title: Diamond Multimedia reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Inco Ltd. (N,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss and included pretax charges of $ 104 million ($ 56 million after tax) for planned production shutdowns and employment reductions in the company's primary metals business.(Loss)

title: Alltel Corp.(AT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Statements by the President and Attorney General
description: Following is President Clinton's statement in Washington yesterday on the bombing in Oklahoma City, as recorded by The New York Times, and remarks by Attorney General Janet Reno and excerpts from her answers to questions from reporters, as recorded by the Federal News Service:

title: Norwest Corp.(NOB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Dun & Bradstreet (DNB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Giddings & Lewis (GIDL,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
Mayor Favors Phasing Out Home Relief
description: A day after touting the success of tough new eligibility rules for New York's welfare program providing benefits to childless, able-bodied adults, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he actually favors abolishing the program altogether.

title: Capital One Financial Corp.(COF,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Year-ago results are pro forma as if the company was independently funded and a ''stand-alone'' company prior to its November 1994 spinoff from Signet Banking Corp.

title: New Oil Futures Contracts
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange said yesterday that it would allow trading in crude oil futures contracts for delivery in December 1998 and December 1999. Currently, crude oil futures can only be traded as far forward as December 1997. The new contracts will be added on May 1, the exchange said in a news release. The exchange said it was adding the contracts in response to industry demand. "The significant levels of open interest we see as far as 30 and 36 months out are clear evidence of an increased focus being placed on long-term risk management in this industry," Patrick Thompson, the president of the exchange, said.

title: U.S. Wealth Gap Is Also a Vietnam War Legacy; Justified Cynicism
description: To the Editor:

title: The ads for Jeep Cherokee and Chevrolet Tahoe appear to have something in common: imitation.
description: IMITATION, so it often seems, is the sincerest form of advertising. When Orvis, the supplier of fly-fishing equipment, teamed last year with Chrysler's Jeep division to promote a plush Jeep, they hit on a natural theme.

title: Playtex Products Inc.(PYX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
description: b-After preferred dividends of $ 1,163,000, net income applicable to common stockholders was $ 4,360,000.

title: Coke's Income Rose by 22% In First Quarter
description: Capitalizing on its global muscle as a beverage producer, and buoyed by strong gallon sales of its products, the Coca-Cola Company yesterday reported a 22 percent increase in first-quarter earnings.

title: Accounts
description: Glaxo Inc., Research Triangle Park, N.C., a unit of Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., to Grey Advertising, New York, as the first agency to handle direct-to-consumer advertising for Flonase, a prescription nasal spray for allergies. The billings were estimated at more than $12 million. Lewis & Gace Bozell, Fort Lee, N.J., part of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, continues to handle advertising for Flonase aimed at doctors.

title: Those Hybrid Made-for-TV Movies
description: It all used to be simple. Movies were made in Hollywood studios and released nationally through theater chains. Then along came television, which in addition to gobbling up Hollywood movies to flesh out skimpy schedules began, around 1969, producing its own made-for-television movies. These were initially low-budget affairs that gave "real" movie critics irresistible opportunities for sneering. The dividing line was clear. For a while.

title: Point, Click, Shop Till You Drop
description: SHOPPING by computer is not new, but it has yet to catch on with most consumers, especially those who use catalogues. Part of the reason is that until recently, personal computer screens did not have the clarity and sharpness of the typical four-color catalogue.

title: They Fear Only the Answer Is Worse Than the Question
description: Her eyes raw from crying, her hands trembling, Sharon Coyne crouched over in a chair, waiting for word that, somehow, her 14-month-old daughter, Jaci, had been found alive.

title: Moody's Lowers Paine Webber Debt Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday that it had lowered its ratings on $3.7 billion of Paine Webber Group Inc.'s debt because the brokerage firm was taking more risks following last year's acquisition of Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Outboard Marine Corp.(OM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $ 10.5 million related to transfer of land rights that the company held in Hong Kong for the quarter and 6 months.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dollar's Recovery Gives Blue-Chip Stocks a Lift Blue-chip stocks surged to within a point of their highs, bolstered by a recovery in the dollar. A surprising 24.6 percent drop in the U.S. trade deficit in February helped the dollar gain strength against the Japanese yen and the German mark. The Dow Jones industrials rose 28.36 points, to 4.207.49.

title: From Cosmopolitan To Enquirer and Star
description: Tony Hoyt, vice president and publisher of Cosmopolitan magazine, has been named as senior vice president and publisher of The National Enquirer and The Star, two weekly tabloid newspapers owned by American Media in Lantana, Fla.

title: A Hollow Plan for the Homeless
description: Gov. George Pataki wants to deny shelter to New York State's homeless unless they obey certain rules of behavior and participate in social service programs designed to help them fight drug or alcohol addiction or find housing and jobs. The idea is not unreasonable, but Mr. Pataki assumes a level of support programs for the homeless that does not now exist. Until it does, his proposal will only send the homeless back onto the streets.

title: On Ivy League Schooling
description: To The Home Section:

title: On Ivy League Schooling
description: To The Home Section:

title: U S West Inc.(USW,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included gains of $ 39 million, or 8 cents a share, in the latest first quarter, and $ 15 million, or 3 cents a share, in year-ago period, from sale of selected rural telephone exchanges. Excluding gains, company reported earnings of $ 291 million, or 62 cents a share, in latest quarter, and $ 309 million, or 70 cents a share, in year-ago period.

title: Kodak Shares Up as Earnings Climb 80%
description: Shares of the Eastman Kodak Company jumped yesterday after the company reported that its first-quarter earnings shot up more than 80 percent.

title: Fourth Financial (FRTH,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After $ 13.4 million in previously announced after-tax securities losses from the company's first-quarter balance sheet repositioning.c-Included $ 3.6 million of securities gains and $ 2.7 million of merger and integration costs.Year-ago results are restated to reflect poolings of interests.

title: New Offers Made in Lockout
description: The locked-out umpires and their employers, the American and National leagues, exchanged new proposals yesterday as they tried to reach agreement before the start of the season next Tuesday night. Neither side would disclose details. The leagues made their proposals yesterday morning, and the umpires countered late in the afternoon.

title: Court Hears Challenges to Black Districts
description: The Supreme Court today took up perhaps the most basic affirmative-action issue in a democracy: whether election districts can be drawn according to the race of the people who live in them.

title: Re-thinking Day Care At the Job
description: The large number of children killed in the bombing yesterday of a Federal office building in Oklahoma City underscored how day-care centers are increasingly being placed near work sites, leaving them exposed to the same dangers faced by workers in office buildings.

title: Jets May Be Pursuing Sapp Through a Cincinnati Line
description: The story burning the midnight oil on the National Football League fax hot line is that the Jets are contemplating a trade with the Cincinnati Bengals in order to move up to fifth place from ninth in Saturday's draft and take the all-America defensive tackle Warren Sapp.

title: City, Bus Drivers And Firms to Talk
description: Representatives for the school bus drivers' union, private bus companies and city labor negotiators have agreed to meet today to try to avert a threatened bus drivers strike on Monday.

title: OTHER NEWS
description: Gas Fumes Create Panic in Yokohama

title: CHRONICLE
description: EDMUND G. (PAT) BROWN, the former Governor of California, turns 90 tomorrow, and The Associated Press says he will celebrate at his Beverly Hills home with three generations of one of the state's most influential political clans -- his own.

title: Autopsy Fails to Settle Manila-Singapore Dispute
description: A joint autopsy conducted by Philippine and Singapore pathologists on a Filipino maid who was killed in Singapore in 1991 and for whose murder another Filipino was executed last month ended today with both sides reporting "irreconcilable differences" over their findings.

title: T R Financial Corp.(ROSE,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.S. Wealth Gap Is Also a Vietnam War Legacy; McNamara's 'Sinecure'
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida's Carter Is Aware The Draft Is Anyone's Pick
description: Larry Jacobs, the agent for defensive end Kevin Carter, doesn't tell his client the latest scuttlebutt on the National Football League college draft that filters through his Jacksonville, Fla., office.

title: A Week When All Roads Lead to Milan
description: VISITORS attending the Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the international furniture fair, or the Eurocucina kitchen show, both of which ended last week in Milan, Italy, were caught up in a series of events. One evening, Enzo Mari, the radical Italian architect, drew a large crowd outside the Alessi shop as he cut up plastic water bottles, recycling them into vases. Across town, the Japanese architect Shigeru Uchida provided an oasis of serenity with new, yet traditional teahouses.

title: Relevance Is Not Enough, Mr. Clinton
description: No troops will be marching to battle under a banner that reads "The President is relevant." Yet that is about as inspirational as President Clinton got during his televised news conference Tuesday night. After weeks in which Congressional Republicans have dominated the political debate, and after an assertive televised address by House Speaker Newt Gingrich exulting in the accomplishments of his first 100 days, the Democrats are desperate for political leadership. But the best Mr. Clinton could offer was assurances that the Constitution, his record and his ideas make him relevant -- and thus someone the Republicans should work with.

title: 72.3% of School Budgets Win Approval
description: New Jersey voters approved on Tuesday a sharply higher number of school budgets than they did last year, brushing aside predictions that anger over property taxes and criticism of local districts' spending by the state would cause another wave of rejections.

title: Other Bombings in America
description: 1978-1994: A series of mail-bombings injures 10 and kills 2 in 15 separate incidents nationwide. The F.B.I. believes the cases are connected, and that a lone bomber is responsible. The investigation, code-named Unabom, continues.

title: Baylor's Pact Is Extended by the Rockies
description: The Colorado Rockies yesterday extended the contract of Manager DON BAYLOR through the 1996 season. Baylor, 45, signed a two-year deal with the expansion Rockies before their inaugural 1993 season. Colorado had an option for this year. (AP)

title: Plumber Is Charged With Fraud
description: The way the Division of Consumer Affairs figures it, the plumbing bill should have come to $7,950. Instead, an official said, a Byram Township woman was charged $23,082.56 by the plumber who answered her call for help when her frozen pipes burst. Yesterday that plumber, Jeffrey Biggiani of East Hanover, was named in a 53-count complaint accusing him of violating the Consumer Fraud Act. The lawsuit asks restitution for more than 50 customers and an injunction to keep Mr. Biggiani from operating in New Jersey.

title: Snap-On Inc.(SNA,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
Lydall Inc.(LDL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.S. Wealth Gap Is Also a Vietnam War Legacy; Grief and Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Space Photos Reveal New Planetary Mystery
description: Something about the dynamic forces driving the thick atmosphere of Neptune has astronomers mystified.

title: Newell Co.(NWL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company said its increase in net sales was primarily due to the 1994 acquisitions of Home Fashions Inc., Faber-Castell and Newell Europe. It said its increase in net income was primarily due to internal growth.

title:
YACHT RACING;
Youths Sail Through Educational Regatta
description: Extreme weather kept the America's Cup challenger and defender finals from racing Tuesday, but inside the Young America compound, in a 12-foot tank, 16-inch model boats competed in the UNUM/Young America Cup.

title: RAYCHEM SHARES FALL ON LOWER-THAN-EXPECTED EARNINGS
description: Shares of the Raychem Corporation fell 12.5 percent yesterday, after the company reported earnings far below Wall Street's expectations. Raychem, a maker of electronics and telecommunications equipment based in Menlo Park, Calif., said it earned $10.9 million, or 25 cents a share, in its third quarter, which ended March 31. Raychem earned $1.1 million, or 2 cents a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier, but the company earned barely half the 49 cents a share that Wall Street had expected for the latest quarter, according to First Call Inc., which tracks analysts' earnings projections. Shares of the company fell $5.125, to $35.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A Diplomatic Post for Hughes?
description: William J. Hughes left Congress last year after two decades, saying he wanted to spend more time with his family.

title: Essay; The 25% Solution
description: "Can we simplify the tax system," asked President Clinton at a news conference we can thank CBS for telecasting live, "without being unfair or increasing the deficit?" His rumination was in response to a question about a "flat tax," and he went on to pledge: "If we can do it, then I am open to it."

title: Libyan Girds For Defiance Of the West
description: Muammar el-Qaddafi, who governs Libya with a love of grandiose state projects and unflinching repression, has reorganized his security forces, purged rivals from his inner circle and set Libya on a course of defiance against the West that will probably endure as long as he remains in power.

title: More Roving Guards for Casinos
description: It may be easier for people under 21 to sneak into the Trump Taj Mahal Casino, but it will be harder for them to sneak drinks or bets. That was the experts' prediction after a decision by the State Casino Control Commission to allow the Taj to increase its use of roving security guards in place of the stationary monitors who stand on the perimeter of the gambling hall to bar minors. The decision allows a two-month test of the new procedure.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge an article or return it unless it is accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: 5 Are Found Dead in an Arson-Homicide Case
description: In one of the worst mass murders in modern Connecticut history, five people were found dead or fatally wounded after a suspicious fire Tuesday night destroyed a three-family home here, the state police said today.

title: REEBOK SHARES FALL ON FLAT FIRST-QUARTER EARNINGS
description: Shares of Reebok International Ltd. fell sharply yesterday, a day after the company reported flat first-quarter earnings and said it was concerned about the outlook for the next two quarters. Reebok, the footwear and clothing company based in Stoughton, Mass., said that its overseas sales were disappointing in the first quarter and that it planned to realign its operations to cut costs. Reebok earned $65.9 million, or 80 cents a share, compared with $65.8 million, or 77 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Shares of Reebok fell $2.625, to $31.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock has fallen 15 percent since last week.

title: Outside, Monitors Remain Neutral
description: BEIGE. Putty. Taupe. Dun. And, oh, yes, off-white.

title: Toll Booth Plan Is Opposed
description: Not in my backyard! Mayor William J. Boehm and members of the Chamber of Commerce do not want the New Jersey Highway Authority to erect the Garden State Parkway's fourth Ocean County toll plaza here. They are conducting a petition and telephone campaign against the authority's proposal to build the booth at Exit 74 and charge a 35-cent toll to pay for a $7 million expansion there.

title: York Intl. Corp.(YRK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Harris Corp.(HRS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 10,100,000, or 25 cents a share, from cumulative effect of change in accounting.Year-ago 9 months' results included Harris Computer Systems Division, which has since been spun-off to shareholders as an independent public company.

title: Max H. Karl, 85, Pioneer in Mortgage Insurance
description: Max H. Karl, a lawyer who invented the modern form of private mortgage insurance, helping to put home ownership within reach for millions of families, died in his sleep yesterday at the Baptist Hospital in Miami. He was 85 and had retired to Miami.

title: Sightings of Virgin Mary Reduced to Traffic Issue
description: The problem caused by huge crowds that descended upon Marlboro Township in the hope of seeing a vision of the Virgin Mary was officially downgraded to a traffic nuisance today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the opening of a Brancusi exhibition at the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris misstated the title of Margit Rowell, who prepared it. She is the chief curator of drawings at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, not its chief curator of design.

title: Petty Has Surgery for Prostate Cancer
description: RICHARD PETTY underwent surgery for prostate cancer Tuesday at a hospital in Greensboro, N.C.

title: Bridge
description: A team from the Manhattan Club, 27 West 72d Street, is now the last undefeated squad in the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship, which begins in the fall and continues for almost a year. Playing at their home club Tuesday night, Lapt Chan, Uday Ivatury, Phillip Alder, Jim Krekorian, Brad Moss and Elizabeth Reich won by 25 imps against a foursome led by Dorothy Truscott. The losers enter the once-defeated bracket, in which eight other teams survive.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Old Kent Bank, Grand Rapids, Mich., a unit of Old Kent Financial Corp., is selling $100 million of bank notes due in 1998 through CS First Boston. The notes are priced at 99.80 to yield 6.952 percent. The noncallable issue is rated A1 by Moody's and A by S.& P.

description: b-Net loss(Loss)

title: Justices Allow Unsigned Political Fliers
description: Casting doubt on the election laws of nearly every state, the Supreme Court ruled today that the right to distribute anonymous campaign literature is protected by the constitutional guarantee of free speech.

title: Cobra Golf Inc.(CBRA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Rockland Prosecutor's Friend Assists in Investigation of Him
description: In a major step forward for the two-year-old Federal investigation of Kenneth Gribetz, the longtime Rockland County District Attorney, a close friend of Mr. Gribetz's has pleaded guilty to mail fraud and has begun cooperating with prosecutors.

title: For Chrysler, a Question of How Much Cash Is Enough
description: The Chrysler Corporation stands accused by some of its largest investors of a most remarkable transgression: hoarding too much cash.

title: California's 'Three-Strikes' Law Has Made Big Cuts in Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Seagram, brimming with cash, is looking to build MCA swiftly.
description: WHAT is the Seagram Company's next target going to be? CBS? A record company? A cable company? Television stations?

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Bruins Topple Sabres Cam Neely and Adam Oates each had a goal and two assists as the Boston Bruins beat the Buffalo Sabres, 4-1, last night in Boston. Neely, returning after missing five games with an inflamed hip, scored his 22d goal of the season on a power play at 3 minutes 3 seconds of the second period. He also assisted Oates and Ray Bourque on their 10th goals of the season. Boston is 5-2-1 in its last eight home games. Buffalo, battling for one of the final playoff spots, has lost five of its last seven games. (AP)

title: Republic New York Corp.(RNB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
McDonnell Douglas Corp.(MD,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

PARENT & CHILD;
When Staying Is Worth the Pain
description: THE 1970's and 80's witnessed a therapeutic revolution: wives and husbands with a pent-up desire for divorce started to leave their marriages in droves -- nearly three times as many as in the 1960's. Only this time, in a sharp break with past practice, the therapists were encouraging the exodus.

title: Rangers Find Verbeek Won't Back Down
description: Pat Verbeek stood up to Kjell Samuelsson on Tuesday night, which isn't easy. Samuelsson, the Penguins' rugged defenseman, is one of hockey's biggest players at 6 feet 6 inches, 235 pounds. Verbeek of the Rangers is one of the shortest, generously listed at 5-9 and weighing 190.

title: Fleet Financial (FLT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: World News Briefs; Iranian Chief Adamant On Russian Atom Deal
description: President Hashemi Rafsenjani of Iran ended a three-day state visit to India today with a blistering attack on the United States, saying Teheran was determined to acquire nuclear power reactors from Russia despite strong objections from Washington.

title: Caterpillar Financial Services Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Caterpillar Financial Services Corp., a unit of Caterpillar Inc., attributed its increase in net income mainly to a $ 4.2 million unrealized gain for interest rate caps, compared with a corresponding $ 5.4 million unrealized loss in the year-ago quarter.

title: Earnings at MCI and ATT Rise As Long-Distance Calls Grow
description: MCI has won the latest skirmish in its running battle with AT&T and Sprint for long-distance telephone customers, based on the company's first-quarter results.

title: Michigan National Corp.(MNCO,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Norman Takes On Messiaen And Berg
description: In their current Carnegie Hall appearances, Jessye Norman and Pierre Boulez are launching an enlightened conspiracy in behalf of Berg and Messiaen. On Tuesday night, Miss Norman gave a solo recital that included some of Messiaen's "Poemes pour Mi" and Berg's Seven Early Songs. On April 24 Miss Norman is to sing the same songs of Berg in their orchestral version, with the London Symphony under Mr. Boulez. On Sunday, Mr. Boulez conducts the orchestral version of the Messiaen, this time with Maria Ewing as soloist.

title: Cold, Tired, Lost Hikers Found Safe In a Park
description: They spent the night huddled together in Bear Mountain State Park, yelling for help when they heard noises and setting off the flashes on their cameras so rescuers could find them.

title: TERROR IN OKLAHOMA CITY: AROUND THE NATION  Aftershocks of Terror Spread Out Quickly After the Explosion in Oklahoma City; Government Buildings Close in Eight Cities As Extra Caution Becomes Order of the Day
description: Almost immediately after the explosion rocked Oklahoma City's downtown yesterday, government workers across the nation began to feel shock waves of anxiety and feelings of vulnerability.

description: Haemonetics Corp. said it repurchased more than 800,000 shares in the latest fourth quarter, completeing its authorized 1,000,000-share repurchase plan.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday listing the 10 most popular network television shows in the week of April 10-16 omitted a program that was tied with "Cybill" for 10th place. It was "60 Minutes."

title: A Good Year for Jobs
description: With New Jersey leading the way, the Port Authority said, 1994 was a good year for employment. Jobs were up 67,000 in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan region, the best growth spurt since 1987, said George Marlin, executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. He attributed part of the growth to recent changes in tax and business regulations in New Jersey and predicted that with similar moves in the city, "New York will be rebounding just the way New Jersey is rebounding."

title: '55 Dodgers' Series Banner Returns to Its Rightful Home
description: Greece may still be trying to get back the priceless sculptures Lord Elgin took from the Parthenon, but Brooklynites no longer have to yearn for the only World Series championship pennant won by the Brooklyn Dodgers. After wanderings worthy of Odysseus and a saga of theft and exile, the banner that once fluttered above the right-centerfield wall in Ebbets Field is coming home tonight.

title: First Empire State Corp.(FES,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.N. and Bosnia: Why Do the Peacekeepers Stay?
description: After a week of repeated humiliations for the United Nations, a pointed question is being asked here: Are the 24,000 United Nations soldiers still in Bosnia simply because it it too difficult and dangerous to get them out?

title: Cultures Clash, Opportunity Knocks; In Scarsdale, Entrepreneurs Cater to Bewildered Japanese
description: Japanese business executives who are transferred to New York for a few years find little need to leave this affluent, heavily white New York City suburb of 17,000 to meet their daily needs.

title: On Transracial Adoptions
description: To The Home Section:

title: Advertisers' Access To Classroom Seen
description: Advertisers have gained unchecked access to the classroom, Consumers Union, the nonprofit publisher of Consumer Reports, contends in a study, "Captive Kids: A Report on Commercial Pressures on Kids at Schools."

description: b-Included $ 5 million after-tax gain from sale of Arizona Public Service unit.c-Included $ 25 million pretax rate settlement stemming from 1991 case.

title: New Proposal for Coliseum: Use It to Hold Conventions
description: More than a decade after the city put the New York Coliseum in mothballs, setting off an often bitter series of negotiations over selling it to Mortimer B. Zuckerman, city officials now say the best thing to do for the time being is to use it as it was originally intended: a convention center.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY HOSPITAL IS ACCUSED OF STEERING PATIENTS The University Hospital of Brooklyn, a state-run teaching hospital, discriminated against some Medicaid patients by sending them to a nearby city hospital for services the hospital routinely gave to non-Medicaid patients, state health officials said. B2. COLD, TIRED, LOST HIKERS FOUND SAFE Six children spent the night huddled together in Bear Mountain State Park, yelling for help when they heard noises and setting off the flashes on their cameras in hope that rescuers could find them. B3.

title: Visiting 'Arcadia's' Kindly Cousin in London
description: It's easy to get the impression that London is a far more generous theater town than New York. Plays that receive respectful but less than rave reviews here often go on to obtain respectable West End runs; in the brutal competition of New York they would be on twofers as soon as the theater parties had run out.

title: Bombardier Expanding Output of Jet Boats
description: Bombardier Inc. said today that it would expand production of its Sea-Doo and Ski-Doo jet boats with the acquisition of assets from two marine manufacturing companies.

title: International Briefs; Air France Loss Narrows
description: Air France narrowed its net loss by 72 percent in 1994 as it reaped the benefits of lower interest payments, lower fuel costs and lower subcontracting costs. France's state-owned airline said yesterday that the consolidated net loss for 1994 fell to 2.36 billion French francs, or about $481 million, from 8.48 billion francs in 1993, when it took a one-time charge of 1.8 billion francs for restructuring. The airline called the figures reported yesterday "intermediary," saying it would report results for the 15-month period ending March 31 in June.

title: Good and Bad News for H.M.O.
description: The State Supreme Court had good news and bad news for the Health Care Plan of New Jersey, a health maintenance organization. First the bad: In a unanimous groundbreaking ruling, the court decided that H.M.O.'s -- like doctors and other health care providers -- can be sued for malpractice. The good: the court said in a unanimous decision that Health Care Plan of North Brunswick was not liable for a share of a nearly $3 million jury award to a patient whose doctor failed to diagnose testicular cancer. The court said the doctor waited too long to countersue the H.M.O.

title: Amgen (AMGN,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a $ 20 million signing payment to Rockefeller University for the exclusive license to the ob gene, which reduced earnings by about 10 cents a share.

title: World News Briefs; Rwanda Evicts 100,000 From Refugee Camp
description: Rwandan soldiers evicted more than 100,000 people from the country's largest refugee camp today, ordering them to return to the homes they fled during the ethnic slaughter last year.

title: Diplomacy in Japan: 'Joan of Art' Again
description: AS she drove through the iron gates that guard the entrance of the American Ambassador's residence, Joan Adams Mondale gently juggled armloads of paper-clad bundles. In each was a piece of art destined for its private quarters, the new home of Mrs. Mondale and her husband, Walter -- the former Vice President and current Ambassador to Japan.

title: Body From Bay Is Identified
description: A body fished from Barnegat Bay was identified yesterday as Joseph Schiffino. Mr. Schiffino, 22, of the Bayville section of the township, disappeared on March 31 while he was checking duck blinds.

title: No Headline
description: "There are places we have to crawl over bodies to get to other people. People are crying out to us. There are areas where we can reach through and try to touch their hands. There are some areas we can't get to at all." -- JON HANSEN, of the Oklahoma Fire Department. [ B10:1. ]

title: AT HOME WITH: Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee; Art and Politics: Keeping It All Fresh
description: RUBY DEE had started to yawn when the telephone rang the other night in the Westchester County home she shares with her husband, Ossie Davis. It was one of their three children, instructing Ms. Dee to watch herself on television.

description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split May 6, 1994.

title: John E. Howard, 70, Prosecutor In Murder of Robert F. Kennedy
description: John E. Howard, the chief investigator and a principal prosecutor in the case against Sirhan Bishara Sirhan, the assassin of Senator Robert F. Kennedy in 1968, died on Monday at his home in Irvine, Calif. He was 70.

title: Preparing Students For the World Of Jobs
description: The pressures of global competition have spawned a variety of successful experiments in rethinking how to educate the neglected majority of our high school students -- the 70 percent who will not finish four years of college.

title: An All-Star Tribute to Both Jobim and a Style
description: The evolution of pop music in the last four decades has often seemed like an undeclared war between melody and hard rhythm -- between the yin and the yang of music -- with aggressive beats increasingly trampling over pliant melodies. But as Brazilian pop music has shown, these basic musical elements need not be antagonistic. An all-star tribute to Antonio Carlos Jobim on Tuesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall was more than a salute to the Brazilian composer, who died in December at the age of 67. Using Jobim's songs as a springboard, the concert showcased a national style whose seamless union of melody and pulse has long been the envy of the pop world.

description: THERE is a well-recognized phenomenon in the world of welfare called churning, and it happens whenever politicians decide to shake up the welfare system.

title: The Tools of a Terrorist: Everywhere for Anyone
description: The powerful bomb that ripped off the face of a Federal building in Oklahoma City yesterday was probably made of inexpensive fertilizers and chemicals that are widely available at gardening centers, chemical supply houses and gasoline stations, civilian and Federal explosives experts said.

It was shares of the Discovery Zone, not Viacom shares, that fell 46.875 cents, to $10.15625.

title: Economic Scene; Russian obstacles: disgruntled farmers and the new cartels.
description: IS Russia poised for economic takeoff? After three years of on-again, off-again reforms and with the Pyrrhic military victory in Chechnya still fresh in the news, skepticism comes easily. But little by little, wary analysts are abandoning their caution. "Russia is a real market economy now," says Andrei Shleifer, an economist at Harvard who has advised the Russian Government on privatization.

title: Fruit of The Loom Inc.(FTL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Fruit of the Loom Inc. said its profit margins remained under pressure in the latest first quarter as a result of offshore manufacturing start-up costs, an unfavorable product mix and the $ 8 million pretax loss in its Mexico operations.The company also said the losses in Mexico resulted from the devaluation of the peso and the curtailment of selling and marketing activities in Mexico.Latest first quarter included some severance costs related to laying off ''less than 100'' sales and marketing workers and exit costs associated with closing some offices.

Electrical Rates Rising, Again
description: Electrical rates are going up again, by about 45 cents a month for typical residential consumers, after a vote by the Board of Public Utilities on a request from the Public Service Electric and Gas Company. In November, the board granted the utility an increase that raised the monthly bill of the average residential consumer about $2.40. The latest increase, amounting to $130 million, is intended to offset fuel costs that were higher than anticipated. Rates for nonresidential consumers will rise by 5.8 percent. A consumer group, New Jersey Citizen Action, said it would appeal the board's decision in state court.

description: Two airlines, American and USAir, reported dramatic turnarounds in their first-quarter results yesterday, mainly reflecting growing travel and continuing cost-cutting.

title: U.S. Again Urges Turkey to Pull Out of Iraq
description: President Clinton urged Turkey today to withdraw its troops soon from northern Iraq, but Prime Minister Tansu Ciller said she could not yet say when that month-old operation would end.

title: Some Action, Little Talk
description: No one ever accused the white men who run the nation's large corporations of being social reformers. They generally prefer less government to more, and they like the social structure that put them in power. So as some politicians vow to abolish programs that grant preferences to women and minorities, chief executives might be expected to welcome the move.

title: Foreman Setting Sights Beyond Schulz
description: He is of the coffee generation. George Foreman skips rope, chops wood, slaps a 100-pound bag and drinks two cups a day, caffeinated. This heavyweight champion of the world is not only old enough to be his next opponent's father, but he also woke up two months ago a grandfather.

title: Motor Vehicle Workers Stay Home to Protest Plan to Privatize
description: Operations at 21 of New Jersey's 48 motor vehicle field offices were crippled today as workers staged a sick-out to protest Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's plan to transfer state-run offices to private agents.

title: Gossage, at 43, Ends His 22-Year Career
description: GOOSE GOSSAGE, whose 95-mile-per-hour fastball intimidated hitters, has called it a career at age 43 after 22 years in the majors. Last year, he was a setup relief pitcher with the Seattle Mariners but was not invited back. "I'm not voluntarily retiring," he told The Colorado Springs Gazette-Telegraph on Tuesday. "I'm just retired. It's a bittersweet feeling."

title: Objection to 'Priest' Isn't Creating a Hit
description: The conventional wisdom here is that controversy lures audiences. And no one in the movie business has been better at controversy than Miramax, the New York-based film company whose public disputes over often provocative films have generally been good for business.

title: IMC Global Inc.(IGL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

Year-ago 9 months' loss from continuing operations of $ 20,700,000 included charges of $ 20,300,000 from write-down of an investment.(Loss)

title: Ensign Resource reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Schneider, World Cup Star, Retires at 30
description: VRENI SCHNEIDER retired yesterday at the peak of her career as one of skiing's greats. The 30-year-old Swiss won three World Cup overall titles, three world championships and three Olympic gold medals. "I decided that now is the right moment, to stop while I'm on top," she said in Geneva.

title: Digital Posts a Profit for 2d Quarter in a Row
description: Struggling to turn itself around after losing more than $5.8 billion over the last four years, the Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday posted its second consecutive quarterly profit, surpassing most analysts expectations by a wide margin. The company is on course for its first profitable year since 1990.

title: New Aria Awards Presented to 3 Singers
description: The Aria Awards, a newly established group of prizes for singers, have been awarded to Michelle DeYoung, a mezzo-soprano, and Jorge Garza and Jon Villars, tenors. The three singers, each of whom received a cash stipend of $15,000, were chosen by a panel of professionals and did not know they were being considered. The awards are meant to encourage promising artists early in their careers.

title: International Briefs; OPEC Is Seen as Likely To Keep Output Ceiling
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is unlikely to change its current oil output ceiling when it meets in June, Rilwanu Lukman, the Secretary General of the group, said yesterday. Mr. Lukman, on a tour of the Persian Gulf, said no minister he had visited so far had suggested OPEC's current output ceiling be changed when the organization meets in Vienna.

title: From One Castle To Another: Yours
description: AMERICAN furnishings manufacturers have been laying siege to Britain's stateliest homes, plundering their furniture, fabrics and lamps with an abandon worthy of the Saxons.

title: U.S. Wealth Gap Is Also a Vietnam War Legacy; North-South Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: A Nonconformist in a League of His Own
description: The San Antonio Spurs can't live with Dennis Rodman, and they can't live without him. They have colluded against him, sent an assistant coach to one of his motorcycle rallies, debriefed his confidant, and they still hear only grunts out of him.

title: The Fish Spain Loves
description: To the Editor:

Testimony Ends in Trial Of Mother In 5 Deaths
description: Testimony ended today in the murder trial of Waneta E. Hoyt, with the prosecutor charging that Mrs. Hoyt had deprived her five young children of the chance to reach adulthood by suffocating them a quarter century ago, all because they would not stop crying.

Higher levels of earning assets provided a partial offset.At March 31, Ford Motor Credit's total gross finance receivables and net investment in operating leases were $ 87.3 billion compared with $ 74.4 billion a year earlier, a 17 percent increase.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DEAN FOODS CO., Franklin Park, Ill., reached an agreement in principle to acquire Rio Grande Foods Inc., McAllen, Tex., a subsidiary of Flowers Industries Inc., Thomasville, Ga., for an unspecified amount of cash.

title: Elisa Monte Troupe Presents Two Premieres
description: Elisa Monte Dance hurtled onto the stage on Tuesday night in the first of two programs to be presented in the troupe's two-week season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea). The choreography was gutsy and as bright as new coins. The nine performers are uniformly impressive in looks and dance skills. Best of all, this is a company of individuals. The ingredients were first-rate and made for an evening of luscious, feel-good dancing. And yet there was a slight hollowness to the program, as if an emotional thread or raison d'etre were missing in this abundance of pleasure.

title: Sonoco Products Co.(SON,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
Blue-Chip Stocks Surge; Broader Market Retreats
description: Blue-chip stocks surged yesterday to within a point of their all-time high, while the broader market ended lower.

description: On His Own

description: MTV Networks and Polygram N.V. are joining forces to start two MTV channels in Asia, the companies said yesterday. MTV is owned by Viacom Inc.

title: Lotus Loses $17.5 Million For Quarter
description: The Lotus Development Corporation reported an unexpectedly large $17.5 million loss for the first quarter yesterday, in contrast with earnings of $21.3 million a year earlier. Revenue fell 18 percent, to $202 million from $247 million.

title: Brazil's Chief, In U.S., Says He'll Insist on Key Reforms
description: In a speech that points to the growing importance of foreign investment for Brazil, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso pledged yesterday that his country would not abandon steps toward legal reform and open markets, and he predicted that initial changes in the Constitution would be approved by the Brazilian Congress in three to four months -- much sooner than expected.

title: Crash Cited at a Hearing on Runway Risk
description: In a last transmission to the control tower at the St. Louis airport, just before an 80-ton T.W.A. jet bore down on a twin-engine Cessna, the pilot of the small plane radioed that he was "ready to go on the right side."

title: 12 Victims Were Children in 2d-Floor Day-Care Center
description: A car bomb went off with a thunderous explosion here this morning, ripping through a Federal office building, collapsing walls and floors, and killing at least 31 people. Many others were buried in the wreckage, and the death toll seemed certain to rise.

title: Beware the First Sip Of Ol' Demon Coffee
description: MEMOIR FROM ANTPROOF CASE By Mark Helprin 514 pages. Harcourt Brace. $24.

title: Earl Blackwell Memorial
description: A memorial service for Earl Blackwell, a society impresario and promoter of celebrities and their events, is to be held on May 3 at 3 P.M. at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, 415 West 59th Street, Manhattan. Mr. Blackwell died last month at the age of 85. Among those to take part in the service, which is open to the public, are Arlene Dahl, Patrice Munsel, Douglas Fairbanks Jr. and Isabel Stevenson, president of the American Theater Wing.

title: Oh, What a Difference Whaler Trade Makes
description: When Hartford traded Pat Verbeek to the Rangers on March 23, it seemed as if the Whalers were conceding the season to build for the future. They were dealing away their captain for a part-time defenseman, a minor league defenseman and a couple of draft choices.

title: A Brooklyn Hospital Is Accused Of Rejecting Medicaid Patients
description: The University Hospital of Brooklyn, a state-run teaching hospital, discriminated against some Medicaid patients by sending them to a nearby city hospital for services the hospital routinely provided to non-Medicaid patients, State Health Department officials said yesterday.

title: A. E. Johansen, 89; Ex-Member of House
description: Former Representative August E. Johansen, a Michigan Republican who was among the most conservative voices in his 10 years in Congress, died on Sunday in a nursing home in Orlando, Fla. He was 89 and moved to Florida from Battle Creek, Mich., in the mid-1960's after leaving Congress.

title: Ann Taylor Stock Falls After Resignation
description: Shares of the Ann Taylor Stores Corporation fell sharply yesterday after the resignation of a top merchandising executive.

title: Gore, at U.N., Says Nuclear Powers Are Fair on Weapons Treaty
description: Vice President Al Gore, speaking at a conference on the future of a 25-year-old treaty barring the spread of nuclear weapons, tried to assure delegates today that the United States and other nuclear powers are not using the treaty in ways that are unfair to nations without nuclear weapons.

Majdal Shams Journal; When Nations Draw Lines, the Druse Find a Way
description: Standing on the slopes of the Golan Heights on a recent Friday, a Druse woman went through what has in the last decade become a ritual. "Here he is!" she boomed through a loudspeaker.

description: THE RESCUE: When rescuers found the hundreds of cut, burned and terrified victims, it became a matter of grasping for the living while trying to ignore the dead. Page B10

title: International Briefs; Daimler-Benz Unit Ties Its Fortunes to the Dollar
description: Daimler-Benz Aerospace A.G. warned yesterday that it would post another heavy loss this year if the dollar did not quickly rise from its current record lows. The aerospace subsidiary of Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany had made significant gains in cost reduction and would continue to do so this year, aided by personnel cuts, officials said.

title: U.S. SEEKS MORE INFORMATION ON INGERSOLL-RAND DEAL
description: The Department of Justice has requested additional information for its antitrust review of the Ingersoll-Rand Company's proposed $1.5 billion acquisition of the Clark Equipment Company, the companies said yesterday. Ingersoll-Rand, the industrial machinery maker based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., said it was prepared to sell some paving-equipment operations to avoid duplicating Clark's operations if necessary. Last week Ingersoll-Rand agreed to increase its bid to $86 a share for Clark, a maker of construction equipment based in South Bend, Ind.

title: Baltimore Grapples With Idea of Legalizing Drugs
description: It has been eight years since Kurt L. Schmoke was a newly elected mayor with a radical idea: take the profit out of selling cocaine, marijuana and other illegal drugs by legalizing them.

title: U.N. Eases Libya Flight Ban to Allow Pilgrims to Go to Mecca
description: The Security Council eased its three-year-old ban on flights from Libya today to permit Egyptian airliners to carry Muslim pilgrims to Mecca.

title: Remnants of Branch Davidians Gather to Grieve and Look to Future
description: The carnage in Oklahoma City came two years to the day after about 80 sect members perished in a fiery assault on the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex. That raid was staged by agents of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, a Federal agency that had offices in the building bombed yesterday.

title: Japan Arrests No. 2 Leader of Sect Linked to Tokyo Attack
description: The police on Wednesday arrested the chief of clandestine activities of the Aum Shinrikyo religious sect, which is under suspicion in the poison gas attack on the Tokyo subway system last month.

title: Signs of an Economic Slowdown Send Price of Copper Plunging
description: Copper prices fell sharply yesterday as continuing signs of an economic slowdown weighed down the market.

description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Tuesday about a campaign parodying a series of advertisements for the Milk Processors Education Program of the National Fluid Milk Processor Promotion Board referred incorrectly to comments by Charlie Decker, the program's executive director. He said that the milk industry would drop the "low fat" designation from milk with 2 percent fat -- not that the industry would relabel 2 percent milk as "reduced fat."

title: Basque Rebel Bomb Wounds Madrid Party Chief and 11 Others
description: Basque separatists detonated a bomb underneath the car driving a conservative opposition leader to his office today, wounding 12 people in an attack condemned by all political parties.

description: General Dynamics Corp. attributed its increased earnings to increased productivity and cost reductions offset by declining sales.

description: The Ford Motor Company said today that its earnings jumped in the first quarter, as strengthening sales in Europe and South America compensated for what the company called a surprisingly weak auto market in the United States.

description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday as the dollar steadied.

title: In Shock, Loathing, Denial: 'This Doesn't Happen Here'
description: Before the dust and the rage had a chance to settle, a chilly rain started to fall on the blasted-out wreck of what had once been an office building, and on the shoulders of the small army of police, firefighters and medical technicians that surrounded it.

title: Ruland Named Assistant Coach at Iona
description: JEFF RULAND, who led Iona to two National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament appearances, has returned to his alma mater as an assistant coach. TIM WELSH, who was promoted to head coach last month after his father, JERRY, retired for medical reasons, announced Ruland's hiring yesterday.

title: No Scholarships for Indonesia's Soldiers
description: The Clinton Administration wants to resume taxpayer-financed courses for Indonesian military officers in the United States. It is a terrible idea.

description: b-Included a charge of 2 cents a share related to the closing of most of the company's Senior Spectrum tabloid newspapers.

title: Nets Stumble Toward the End With Fifth Straight Loss
description: The Nets have been eliminated from the playoffs, but they played with enough intensity tonight to please Coach Butch Beard. Still, the result was a familiar one in this season of discontent.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a Pulitzer Prize-winning photograph described it and credited it incorrectly in some copies. The picture was by Jacqueline Arzt, not Jean-Marc Bouju; it showed a Rwandan child too weak to stand in line for vaccinations (not children pleading to be allowed to cross a bridge between Rwanda and Zaire). Ms. Arzt, along with Mr. Bouju, Javier Bauluz and Karsten Thielker, won the feature photography prize for The Associated Press.

Coliseum About-Face
description: More than a decade after New York City put the Coliseum in mothballs, setting off an often-bitter series of negotiations over selling it to Mortimer B. Zuckerman, city officials now say the best thing for the time being is to use it as a convention center.

title: D.R. Horton Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
TALKS EXTENDED IN PLANNED SALE OF SPRINT STAKE
description: Talks on the proposed $4.2 billion sale of a 20 percent stake in the Sprint Corporation to Deutsche Telekom A.G. and France Telecom have been extended to May 17. Germany's Post and Telecommunications Minister, Wolfgang Botsch, said yesterday that a preliminary agreement for the sale had been set to expire last Saturday. Mr. Botsch said some progress had been made, but added that various issues remained unresolved. One unresolved issue is believed to be the reluctance of the United States to allow the state-owned telecommunications companies of Germany and France to buy a stake in an American company while their markets remain restricted.

title: GS Technologies Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: GS Technologies Corp. attributed the increased in revenues in the latest first quarter to the acquisition of the remaining 50 percent interest in ME International.

title: Seagull Says It Saw No Wrongdoing
description: Seagull Entertainment, a television syndication and programming production company, says it knew of no wrongdoing in business transactions involving two top officials of Wells Rich Greene BDDP Communications. The officials left the agency company last week after Wells Rich accused them of unauthorized use of $500,000 in corporate funds for personal gain in dealing with an outside company, which was later identified as Seagull.

title: Rebel Attack Ends a Cease-Fire in Sri Lanka
description: Efforts to end Sri Lanka's long ethnic war appeared to collapse today after rebel commandos infiltrated a key Government naval base and blew up two gunboats, killing 11 sailors and wounding 21 others. The bodies of four rebels were also found.

title: Judge Refuses to Sequester Jury In Terrorism Case in New York
description: The judge in the New York terrorism trial of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman and 10 co-defendants rejected a request by some of the defense lawyers that the jurors be sequestered for at least the next several days to shield them from news of the bombing of a Federal office building in Oklahoma City.

title: JVC Jazz Festival Announces Lineup
description: The schedule for the 1995 JVC Jazz Festival, announced yesterday, rounds up such stellar performers as the pianist Oscar Peterson and the singers Mel Torme and Peggy Lee, along with lesser-known musicians from around the world, including Russia. It also draws on some of the biggest stars in Afro-Cuban music, among them Celia Cruz, La India and Oscar D'Leon. Brazil is represented by Gal Costa and Joao Bosco, and the Euro-African singing group Zap Mama is also scheduled to appear. Echoing last year, the festival is again taking over Bryant Park for a series of six free concerts.

description: Hey, parents can be useful in their children's growing up! At an hour in length, it's like making a meal of some good-for-you side dish, maybe kale.

description: The authorities opened an intensive hunt today for whoever bombed a Federal office building in Oklahoma City, and proceeded on the theory that the bombing was a terrorist attack against the Government, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Savagery in Oklahoma City
description: The powerful explosion that crumpled a large part of the Federal building in Oklahoma City yesterday was a savage attack against the security and civil order that Americans often take for granted. Like the World Trade Center bombing two years ago, it shakes the faith -- maybe now just the fading hope -- that Americans can be spared this kind of deranged act on their home soil.

description: In a chilling reminder of last month's poison-gas attack in the Tokyo subway, about 300 people were taken to hospitals here on Wednesday after strange-smelling fumes spread through Yokohama's main railroad station and through a train.

description: Basketball National Basketball Association

title: Mary Bingham, Matriarch of a Newspaper Empire, Dies at 90
description: Mary Bingham, the matriarch of the Bingham newspaper empire, died suddenly in Louisville, Ky., on Tuesday evening. She was 90 and lived in Glenview, 15 minutes outside Louisville, on the family estate.

title: Mending Ties, U.S. Praises Brazil Leader
description: President Clinton gave a warm embrace to President Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil today, signaling that after years of tensions fed by military rule, corruption and hyperinflation, the United States wants to make Brazil an important partner on trade and security.

title: Young People Who Try Suicide May Be Succeeding More Often
description: Suicide is an increasingly serious problem among the nation's youth, with especially big increases among all children ages 10 to 14 and among young black men, according to Federal statistics released today.

title: For Children
description: Earth Day Events Various locations (212) 922-0048 (general information) Recommended for all ages Today and tomorrow
