title: Sports of The Times; Can Rangers Overcome Dave Curse?
description: HOW did it come to this? The last time we looked, the Rangers were parading the Stanley Cup all over Manhattan, letting assorted and perhaps even sordid strangers drink from its sacred rim. Now look.

title: NYNEX IN SERVICE ACCORD WITH MFS COMMUNICATIONS
description: The Nynex Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the MFS Communications Company that eases the way for MFS to compete in the Nynex Massachusetts calling region. The agreement will give customers a choice of providers for local phone service in the areas that MFS chooses to serve. The move is the second such agreement between Nynex and MFS. In January Nynex gave MFS increased access to the Nynex market in New York. Nynex, based in New York, is moving to open its local market in hopes that state and Federal legislators will let it into the long-distance industry.

title: A Violinist Who Adds Breadth to the Details
description: Dmitry Sitkovetsky's violin playing has deepened considerably over the last decade. Always an imaginative colorist with a secure technique rooted in the Russian Romantic school, Mr. Sitkovetsky used to express his individuality more fully in the details of his phrasing than in a work's full canvas. But in his recital on Wednesday evening at the 92d Street Y, he found a way to present a broader view without sacrificing the fine points that have long been central to his interpretive style.

title: Sale of Bridgeport's Zoo On a Merry-Go-Round
description: For this hard-pressed city, running Connecticut's only public zoo has become a $400,000-a-year luxury that officials say they can no longer afford.

title: Fear About Retaliation Among Muslim Groups
description: For many Arabs in the United States, and particularly in and around this city, the bombing on Wednesday and the speculation that it might have been the work of Muslim fundamentalists is a reminder that the lives they have so carefully built have not isolated them from the mistrust and fear that can surface in a crisis.

title: Tennessee Williams's Next-to-Final Finale
description: At the top of the second act of "Clothes for a Summer Hotel," Tennessee Williams's rueful rumination on the disillusions of life as mirrored through Zelda and F. Scott Fitzgerald, Zelda has a brief, torrid affair with a young French aviator named Edouard. As the lovers part, Zelda postulates that the pilot will leave her arms and die in a fiery plane crash. It doesn't happen, of course. As the flier points out, he doesn't crash his plane. He just grows old. Williams suffered the same disappointment.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Arturo Frondizi, a former Argentine President, misstated his age and his birthdate in some copies. He was 86 and was born in 1908.

title: Experts Search for Debris To Link Bomb to a Suspect
description: Forensic specialists using chemistry to track down terrorists like those responsible for the bombing here face daunting technical challenges, and experts at a meeting on the topic on Wednesday expressed fear that the United States would now see more bombings.

title: Legendary Detective Wages War on Word 'Unsolved'
description: Detective Jerry Giorgio says he must crack two particularly troublesome murder cases before he'll let himself retire from the Police Department. And if experience is any guide, the killers will come to justice, although it might take some time.

title: Hurley's Season Over?
description: Sacramento Kings guard BOBBY HURLEY was placed on the injured list yesterday and is expected to be replaced by DERRICK PHELPS for the last three games of the regular season. Hurley strained his lower back during pregame warm-ups Tuesday night. He could return if Sacramento makes the playoffs. (AP)

title: Bank Buys Inn at an Auction
description: For $150,000, a bank may soon own two Galloway Township retail developments, the Smithville Inn and the Historic Towne of Smithville.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 7 about the anniversary of the start of ethnic massacres in Rwanda misidentified the leader who was honored that day by the Government in a mass reburial. It was the former interim Prime Minister, Agathe Uwilingiyimana, not former President Juvenal Habyarimana.

title: Israeli Study Sees Higher Death Rate From '91 Scud Attacks
description: Accepted wisdom here is that for all their understandable anxiety at the time, Israelis emerged little scathed from the Scud missiles fired at them by Iraq during the 1991 war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Dallas Trip Turned Into 16-Hour Legal Ordeal, Student Says
description: Onis Siddiqi says he is a 24-year-old business student from Queens who came to Dallas with his older brother on Tuesday seeking to deal with "an immigration problem."

title: Into the Crossfire Of the Bad Guys
description: HOW could David Caruso's television fans have been surprised at his decision to leave a hit series, "N.Y.P.D. Blue," in a less than decorous way? That face speaks volumes, and it's the face of a grapefruit-smashing tough guy, not a gentleman. Mr. Caruso has a fine natural abrasiveness, his mouth twitching as if at the taste of something rotten, his voice taunting, his body coiled in a menacing stance. In "Kiss of Death" he becomes a movie star with a vengeance, the kind of movie star he was meant to be.

title: F.B.I. SEEKS 2 SUSPECTS IN OKLAHOMA BLAST; SEARCH FOR SURVIVORS, AND BODIES, IS SLOW
description: With the death toll at 53 and sure to rise, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had identified two suspects, described as white males, in the bombing of the Federal office building here, and had issued warrants for their arrest.

title: Kimberly-Clark (KMB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 26.8 million, or 17 cents a share, for translation losses related to the Mexican peso devaluation.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of religious holidays, alternate-side street parking regulations are suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Subpar Race by Eltish Adds to Derby Puzzle
description: Eltish, the prime European candidate for the Kentucky Derby, ran third in the Feildon Stakes at Newmarket, England, yesterday, adding to the growing confusion enveloping the Run for the Roses. But his trainer still planned to run him in the hard-to-figure Derby.

title: Art in Review
description: Aaron Siskind Robert Mann Gallery 42 East 76th Street Manhattan Through April 29

title: CSX Corp.(CSX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
School Bus Walkout Is Averted After Both Sides Soften Positions
description: School bus drivers agreed yesterday to call off a strike planned for Monday in exchange for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's decision to delay seeking cheaper bus service by ending lifetime job security for union drivers, the Mayor said.

title: Army Approves Arsenal Project
description: The Army is giving the green light to $10.5 million in construction projects at Picatinny Arsenal in Morris County. Informed of the plan, Representative Rodney Frelinghuysen, whose district includes the arsenal, said, "This decision further confirms the department's commitment to the future of Picatinny." A Congressional report last week said the arsenal ranked low in military value but would be costly to close.

title: More on the Blast
description: THE CHILDREN -- The day-care center was alive with children about to start a day of songs and toys and projects. Then the room exploded in their faces. Page A23. THE TRAIL -- Federal agents raced to a truck-rental agency in Kansas in pursuit of suspected bombers, but the trail quickly grew faint. Page A24. THE MOOD -- Until yesterday, Amber Fleming had always felt a bit superior about Oklahoma City, where locking up is strictly optional. Page A26.

title: Identifying Injured Loved Ones By Clues of Hair and Birthmarks
description: It was the birthmark on the child's tiny thigh that told Jim Denny he had finally found his son.

title: Looking for Poetry In All the Wrong Places
description: The decline began with glue-sniffing and led to a labyrinth of abasement, malicious mischief and teen-age ecstasy. It was described in neon-bright detail by an amazingly precocious Jim Carroll, who at the age of 12 began writing the journal entries that would establish him as a baby Burroughs. Those journals are now the basis for a self-consciously bleak film tracing Mr. Carroll's evolution from ball-playing parochial schoolboy to neo-Beat poet. The latter pose seems particularly out of place, since the film has no poetry of its own.

title: Bank of Boston Corp.(BKB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from early retirement of debt of $ 6,600,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: At the Bar; Putting law in its place: second fiddle to Sam Cooke.
description: G. David Tenenbaum doesn't know a lot about history. Doesn't know much geography. Doesn't know much about science books, or about the French he took. But he does know about Sam Cooke, and he has collected it in a biography of the legendary pop singer.

title: Olin Corp.(OLN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
In City After City, a Bad Case of Nerves
description: Workers in Government buildings were jittery, subway service in Boston was halted and even the hospital treating young victims of the Oklahoma City bombing was evacuated yesterday as officials across the country dealt with hoax after hoax, scare after scare, in the wake of the explosion. Threats led the authorities to evacuate Government buildings in at least 15 cities, The Associated Press reported.

title: Albany Aides Assail Delays In Budget
description: As a lawn mower tended the greening grass of the Executive Mansion, 200 or so legislative workers, mostly Democrats, rallied today outside Gov. George E. Pataki's residence, complaining that their paychecks had been held hostage to the late budget.

title: Times Mirror Co.(TMC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included $ 3.2 million pretax restructuring charge and $ 7.2 million pretax gain on sale of securities, income from discontinued cable operations of $ 4,611,000, or 4 cents a share, an extraordinary gain of $ 1,634,294,000, or $ 13.24 a share, on merger of cable operations, and after a charge of $ 4,511,000, or 4 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Included income of $ 15,225,000, or 12 cents a share, from discontinued cable operations.The latest first quarter per-share earnings are after preferred dividends of $ 4.73 million.

title: Marching In the Parade Of Animals
description: MAN is the crown of creation, or so the common wisdom runs. Not everyone in history has agreed. The ancient Egyptians didn't always think so. Nor did the people of Africa or India. For those cultures, animals -- from lions to falcons to tsetse flies -- not only had the power to shape human lives but also provided a mirror in which, for better or worse, humans could see themselves reflected.

title: Two Groups Name Finalists for Awards
description: Two organizations have named finalists for their annual awards.

title: Textron Inc.(TXT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
Tyco Int'l.(TYC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included net charge of $ 31.2 million related to merger and transaction costs, and extraordinary loss of $ 2.6 million, or 3 cents a share, from early extinguishment of $ 100 million of Kendall International debt.Year-ago periods were restated to account for pooling of Kendall, a recent acquisition.

title: BellSouth Corp.(BLS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included one-time gain of $ 67.5 million, or 14 cents a share, on sale of minority interest in international investment.

title: Union Pacific Corp.(UNP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $ 116 million, or 56 cents a share, on the sale of the Wilmington, Calif., oil field and related facilities. The period also included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 2 million, or 1 cent a share, reflecting the operations of the company's hazardous waste management unit, USPCI, sold at the end of 1994.

title: Weak Dollar And Its Costs
description: "A country which is responsible for the key currency of the world has the responsibility of maintaining reasonable stability of it," Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, complained earlier this week. Translation: Do something -- anything -- to halt the decline of the dollar.

title: In Love, On to AIDS, Out of Love
description: Ming (B. D. Wong) is a young, assimilated Chinese-American. He's hip, outgoing, in tune with the popular culture that bred him. Oscar (Francis Jue), his somewhat older Chinese-born lover, also sounds completely American, but his roots are in the old traditions, not in Boston, where the two have lived together for four years.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; An unusual hybrid agency seeks to cross-pollinate campaigns on each side of the Atlantic.
description: A LEADING British creative team and a small American agency are joining forces for an unusual, potentially innovative venture: forming allied agencies based in London and New York to work both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Reynolds & Reynolds Co.(REY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
That Certainly Was a Performance!; In the Greenroom, Where Artists Meet Audience, Diplomatic Neutrality Is Crucial
description: A friend or colleague has just performed. It wasn't great. What do you say?

title: Corrections
description: An April 18 letter from Charlayne Hunter-Gault mischaracterized The Times's April 8 review of "Rights and Wrongs: Human Rights Television" by stating, "your reviewer dismissed it as 'yet another leftish addition to already suspect public broadcasting.' " The review actually stated, "Critics see it as yet another leftish addition to already suspect public broadcasting."

title: No Headline
description: "Hard to believe a dad can't identify his own boy." JIM DENNY, at Presbyterian Hospital in Oklahoma City. [ A1:1. ]

title: Chiefs Sign Lott and He Joins 2 Other Ex-Jets
description: The Kansas City Chiefs, who lost one future Pro Football Hall of Fame player when quarterback Joe Montana retired this week, have signed another. Eight weeks after the Jets dropped Ronnie Lott, the Chiefs announced yesterday that they had signed the celebrated safety to a three-year contract.

title: Court Awards $83 Million to 600 Investors
description: A California state court has awarded more than $83 million in damages to 600 investors in a series of collapsed real estate investments.

title: Pacific Gas & Electric (PCG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included charge of 7 cents a share related to litigation reserves.c-Included charge of 12 cents a share related to gas reasonableness matters.The results are after preferred dividend requirements of $ 14.5 million in both the latest and year-ago first quarters.

title: A New Talent
description: When Arthur Ashe helped inaugurate the Arthur Ashe Youth Tennis Center, he was probably hoping a TRACI GREEN would come along. Two years after Ashe died of an AIDS-related illness, Green was named to the 1995 United States national team. The 16-year-old Philadelphian is only the third black woman in the team's eight-year history.

title: On My Mind; Ending Forgiveness
description: From the moment the bomb went off in Oklahoma City, the message of helplessness went out across the country: We can't stop terrorism. Maybe the Government can catch some of the killers but other terrorists will always be able to strike America when and where they wish.

title: Belanger's 3d-Period Goal Ends 2 Streaks
description: This was a sad night of firsts for the Devils, who saw the end of two streaks against the Florida Panthers and wound up with their lowest shot production of the season, 17.

title: Retrospective of Films From South Africa
description: "Apartheid Framed: South African Film, 1948-1994," a retrospective featuring more than 18 films and videos, opens today and is to run weekends through June 4 at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. Several premieres are included in the series, which will also feature guest speakers, among them Rob Nixon, a professor of English and literature at Columbia University, who is an organizer of the retrospective.

title: I.B.M. Profit Up Smartly; Stock Climbs
description: Driven by surprisingly high revenue from product sales and its service businesses, I.B.M. posted record first-quarter earnings yesterday, surpassing analysts' expectations by a wide margin.

title: Tandy Corp.(TAN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The results for the latest first quarter included $ 1.67 million in dividends for the employee stock ownership plan, compared with $ 1.81 million in the year-ago period.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Varian Associates Inc.(VAR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Mazda to Halve Output of Autos For North America Through May
description: Hurt by weak sales in the United States and the strong yen, the Mazda Motor Corporation said today that it would cut in half its Japanese production of cars bound for North America during April and May.

title: Shelter Fee Is Proposed For Homeless
description: The Pataki administration is proposing to charge homeless people rent, in effect, for staying in public shelters if the state determines that they have personal assets, jobs or other sources of income beyond basic welfare grants.

title: Kiwi Will Start Bermuda Flights
description: The name says 'International' and now the airline is adding flights to match. Kiwi International Airlines will inaugurate international service on May 25 with daily flights between Newark and Bermuda. The company, which began service in 1992, was named for a flightless bird because so many of its original employees lost their wings when other airlines failed. It now serves Atlanta, Chicago, Newark, and Orlando, Tampa and West Palm Beach in Florida.

title: Mexican Talks With Rebels Are Delayed
description: More than a year after a first round of peace talks failed to end an armed uprising in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas, Government representatives delayed resuming the talks today until their safety was guaranteed by the rebels.

title: Giants Aim to Pick a Very Quick Study
description: While free agency can be a bonanza to teams by helping them to improve rather quickly, it can also be a drain because it turns the draft into something that can no longer be used to slowly rebuild teams.

title: Service Corp. Int'l.(SRV,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
American Express's Net Flat, but Continuing Operations Gain
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its net income was flat in the first quarter but that earnings from continuing operations rose 11 percent, propelled by increased profits in the company's travel and mutual fund businesses.

title: Russia Balks at a U.N. Move To Tighten Serbia Border Ban
description: Russia refused today to support a Security Council resolution intended to close loopholes in Serbia's borders through which Bosnian and Croatian Serbs have been obtaining weapons and other strategic supplies.

title: INSIDE
description: School Bus Strike Averted

title: Lewis Group Meets
description: A commission that will study the circumstances surrounding a drug test administered to Reggie Lewis and others on the Northeastern basketball team met yesterday in Boston, and plans to issue a report by September. Northeastern's president, JOHN CURRY, had announced he would form the commission last month, after reports arose that Lewis had tested positive for cocaine before the 1987 N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. Lewis, the Celtics' captain, died in July 1993, three months after he collapsed during a Boston playoff game. (AP)

title: Corporate Lawyers, Too, Turn to the Hard Sell
description: They are not about to send out slippers with their pictures on them or pens saying "sue someone you love," like the marital lawyer Raul Felder did last year. Nor are they jostling for first crack at analyzing high-profile cases, as criminal lawyers are doing with the O. J. Simpson trial. And they are certainly not turning into power television advertisers like Jacoby & Myers and other personal injury lawyers.

title: Sit-In at Princeton In President's Office
description: Demanding more representation for Asian-Americans and Hispanic people in the curriculum and on the faculty, a group of Princeton University students occupied the president's office here today.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Blinky Palermo' 'Editioned Works' Brooke Alexander Editions 476 Broome Street SoHo Through May 6

title: Partners & Simons Gets Puma Account
description: Puma USA, the marketer of athletic footwear based in Brockton, Mass., said yesterday that it had awarded its account to Partners & Simons in Boston. The billings were estimated at $4 million to $8 million. The account, which includes advertising and direct marketing responsibilities, was previously handled by Berlin Cameron Doyle in New York, which closed on March 31. Partners & Simons was awarded the account without a review; Puma, a unit of Aritmos A.B., had considered the agency during a previous review.

title: Warner-Lambert (WLA,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Case Corp.(CSE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 9,000,000, or 13 cents a share.c-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 29,000,000, or 41 cents a share.Year-ago income from continuing operations of $ 33,000,000, or 44 cents a share, included $ 2 million in preferred stock dividends.

title:
About Real Estate;
Projects Ease Shortage Of Rentals in Stamford
description: Two projects are helping fill a severe shortage of rentals here. The projects are the first to take advantage of changes in the zoning laws allowing office space in downtown Stamford to be converted to housing.

title: 'Reaffirming Spirituality,' at El Museo del Barrio
description: Spiritual art and political art are at heart the same thing. In both cases, liberation is the goal, passion of thought and feeling the means. This is one of the clear messages delivered by "Reaffirming Spirituality" at El Museo del Barrio, the last -- and best -- of three exhibitions organized by Susana Torruella Leval to celebrate the museum's 25th anniversary.

title: Police Officer Convicted of Extorting Payoffs
description: As brutality and corruption investigations into six Bronx police precincts widen, a Bronx police officer was convicted yesterday for extorting cash payoffs from neighborhood drug dealers by threatening them with arrest if they did not pay.

title: Expectations of Lower Output Push Crude Oil Prices Higher
description: Crude oil prices surged yesterday as expectations for lower production next month prompted refiners to buy contracts for May delivery. The contracts expired yesterday.

title: American Home Products Corp.(AHP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 624 million, or $ 2.03 a share, on the sale of the oral health business.

description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 2,900,000, or 42 cents a share.Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect common-stock dividends declared in March 1994 and March 1995.

title: Cutting Welfare Won't Reduce Teen-Age Births
description: To the Editor:

title: Burlington Northern Inc.(BNI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included expenses of $ 31 million, or 20 cents a share, from the company's pending merger with Santa Fe Pacific Corp. Excluding merger-related expenses, the company reported net income of $ 127 million, or $ 1.34 a primary share and $ 1.30 a diluted share.c-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 10,000,000, or 11 cents a share.

description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $ 24.2 million, or 12 cents a share, from the recent settlement of a glass technology dispute with Pilkington PLC.

Diner's Journal
description: The Theme Is Fashion

title: New York City Lacks Vision in Disowning Small Arts Groups
description: To the Editor:

title: Egypt Opposes Extending Pact On Spread of Nuclear Arms
description: Egypt announced formally today that it could not support the indefinite extension of a treaty barring the spread of nuclear weapons because of Israel's refusal to sign the pact, to support the creation of a nuclear-free Middle East or to make any other concessions to its Arab neighbors on the issue.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in New York City that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend "THE FALL GUY," Playhouse 91, 316 East 91st Street, Yorkville. Mako directs Gary Perlman's translation and adaptation of Tsuka Kohei's comedy about a Samurai film star, his ex-girlfriend and his loyal stuntman. Closes Sunday. Performances: today at 8 P.M.; tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets: $30. Reservations: (212) 307-4100.

title: Kandol Journal; Cambodia's Agony Lingers, in Death and Blindness
description: In the shade of a sugar palm tree beside a one-room schoolhouse of palm and bamboo, Dr. Do Seiha examined a farmer's 3-year-old son as dozens of other children watched with laughter and apprehension.

title: Whereabouts Of Teen-Ager Baffles Police
description: Less than two weeks ago, Robin F. Murphy, a tall, slender 17-year-old from this Putnam County town, bought candy and Easter presents for her younger brothers and sisters and hid them in her bedroom. She never got the chance to deliver them.

title: Improving the Improvement Districts
description: New York's City Council, alarmed at allegations that the Grand Central Partnership has engaged in financial wrongdoing and assaults on the homeless, has launched a broad inquiry into the operations of all 33 "business improvement districts" serving commercial and industrial areas throughout the city. The Grand Central Partnership is perhaps the best known of these districts, which are authorized to tax property owners and use the funds to provide security guards, trash cleaners and other services beyond those furnished by the city.

title: Warhol Judge Awards $7.2 Million to Lawyers
description: In a long-awaited decision, a Manhattan judge yesterday ruled that Edward W. Hayes and Francis Harvey must be paid $7.2 million for their work as lawyers for the estate of Andy Warhol. She also awarded the two lawyers, who have carried on a bitter and extended legal dispute with the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts, the estate's main beneficiary, an additional $250,000 to cover their legal expenses.

title: Program Manager Cites F.A.A. Disorganization for Delays in Runway Radar Project
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has the computer and radar technology needed to warn controllers of impending runway collisions like the one that killed two people in St. Louis last November, but, a program manager said today, the agency is too badly organized to put it in place.

title: Occidental Petroleum Corp.(OXY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss(Loss)Results for the latest first quarter included $ 23 million in preferred stock dividends and the year-ago period included $ 17 million in preferred stock dividends.

title: Ryder System Inc.(R,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 7,759,000, or 10 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Schlumberger Ltd.(SLB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Revenue is operating revenues.

title: International Briefs; Italy Plans to Sell 53% Stake in Stet
description: IRI, the Italian Government holding company, said yesterday that it would sell its 53 percent stake in the telecommunications giant Stet S.p.A. through a public share issue, rejecting an offer from a group of banks to buy Stet and then sell some of its shares. IRI said it had sent a Government committee a short list of Italian and foreign investment banks to act as coordinators for the sale.

title: McKesson Corp.(MCK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $ 309.3 million, or $ 7.10 a share, which included $ 152.3 million of compensation costs and income tax expense related to PCS transaction; $ 157.1 million of restructuring charges, and benefit from a foundation contribution.The latest year also included income from discontinued operations of $ 21 million, or 48 cents a share, and an extraordinary gain of $ 576.7 million, or $ 13.23 a share, on sale of PCS.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 9.2 million, or 22 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 30.6 million, or 75 cents a share, in the year. The year also included extraordinary income of $ 24.5 million, or 60 cents a share, the net effect of gain on sale and donation of Armor All stock and a loss on the termination of interest rate swap arrangements, extraordinary charge of $ 4.2 million, or 10 cents a share, related to debt extinguishment, and after a charge of $ 16.7 million, or 38 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Inside Art
description: Mass Moca Lives!

title: Contractor Admits Kickback
description: An Essex County contractor admitted in Federal court yesterday that he accepted $250,000 from an Irvington Housing Authority official for doing no work, then kicked back $100,000.

title: Nedved's Questionable Goal Is the Right Answer
description: Imagine the uproar if the shoe -- or disputed skate -- had been on the other foot. What if the Hartford Whalers had defeated the Rangers last night at Madison Square Garden on a controversial goal like the one scored by Petr Nedved?

title: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.  (BMY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Shelter Fee Planned for Some Homeless
description: The Pataki administration is proposing to charge homeless people rent, in effect, for staying in shelters if the state determines that they have personal assets, jobs or other sources of income beyond basic welfare grants.

title: Texas Utilities Co.(TXU,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
The Blossoming of a Wallflower
description: Feel-good romantic comedies don't feel good when they deliver an empty, saccharine view of the world. On the other hand, when they're as breezy and adorable as "While You Were Sleeping," it's time to fall in love. This is a formula film, but it has the kind of good cheer and fine tuning that occasionally give slickness a good name. The year may be young, but the first hit of the summer is here.

title: F.C.C. Planning Mobile Radio License Auction
description: The Federal Communications Commission announced a plan today for auctioning off a new batch of specialized mobile radio licenses.

title: PAINE WEBBER GROUP INC. (PWJ,N)
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings fell 38 percent from the period a year earlier. Still, its profit exceeded Wall Street's expectations, mainly because of improved trading revenue.

title: Friends Say Senator Pryor of Arkansas Will Quit
description: Senator David Pryor of Arkansas is expected to announce on Friday that he will not seek a fourth term, thus becoming the fifth Democratic Senator to decide not to run for re-election next year.

title: Vaughn to Enter Draft
description: DAVID VAUGHN has decided to pass up his senior year at Memphis playing for his uncle, Coach LARRY FINCH, to enter the National Basketball Association draft. "I've had fun playing for my uncle, and it's difficult for me to leave," Vaughn, a 6-foot-10-inch power forward, said yesterday.

title: Hasbro Inc.(HAS,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 4,282,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12 U.S. DEAF ON DOLLAR European and Japanese pleas that Washington stem the dollar's slide are falling on deaf ears: American policy makers lack the will and doubt they have the way to buck up the buck. A weak dollar makes foreign goods more expensive, threatening recoveries abroad. A1 U.S.-NORTH KOREA TALKS BREAK UP The U.S. and North Korea broke off talks in Berlin without reaching agreement on how to put a crucial nuclear accord into effect, the negotiators said. A10

title: Charm on the Surface, And Stalinist Realities
description: Nikita Mikhalkov walked off the stage at the Academy Awards ceremony last month carrying his Oscar for best foreign-language film in one hand and the movie's star, his 8-year-old daughter, Nadia, in the other. He knows the value of being a sentimentalist and a showman. He is also a director of the first rank, whose films go far deeper than their seductive visual beauty. So it makes sense that his exquisite, lyrical and tough-minded "Burnt by the Sun" combines surface charm with trenchant realism. Mr. Mikhalkov himself plays a retired army officer and hero of the Russian Revolution, who on one gloriously sunny summer day in 1936 discovers the reach and horror of Stalin's rule.

title: Now Batting: TV Marketing
description: Major league baseball will try to persuade strike-wearied fans to return to the fold with a seasonlong marketing campaign that will make its debut on ESPN's opening day game Tuesday night between the Marlins and the Dodgers.

title: A Writer Discovers Challenge In Illness
description: Seated in his wheelchair at his computer at home this morning, Brian Dickinson began writing his weekly column for The Providence Journal-Bulletin with one of the few parts of his body he can still move -- the middle finger of his left hand.

title: Cutting Welfare Won't Reduce Teen-Age Births; Babies So Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: ARCO Chemical (RCM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company said its improved results in the latest quarter are due to its core propylene oxide and derivatives business and the effect of economic growth on its styrene monomer product.

title: Ideas and Confessions Of a Quirky Cartoonist
description: "Crumb" was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 27. The film opens today at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.

title: Gillette Co. (G,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: Donations to Help Bomb Victims
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has set up a nationwide telephone line for people with information about the bombing in Oklahoma City. The number is (800) 905-1514.

title: North Korea Leaves Talks on Nuclear Pact
description: The United States and North Korea broke off talks in Berlin today without reaching agreement on how to put a crucial nuclear accord into effect, the negotiators said.

title: Sun Co.(SUN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net income, which was after a charge of $ 7 million, or 7 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting principle.(Loss)

title: Article 055395 -- No Title
description: A citadel, the dictionary says, is a fortified place or stronghold. Could the name be wishful thinking on the part of the restaurant Citadel, which opened four months ago at a site where three other restaurants -- Dom, Three Roses and Cafe Scorpio -- have failed in the last three years?

title: The Top Draft Pick in Economics; A Professor-to-Be Coveted by Two Dozen Universities
description: She's only 24, but everybody in the world of economics already knows her. About two dozen universities -- Berkeley, Harvard, M.I.T., Princeton, Stanford and Yale among them -- sought her as a junior member of their faculties. They called her one of the most promising candidates in several years. "We fought really hard to get her," said Bengt Holmstrom at M.I.T., where she ultimately accepted a job. "I've rarely seen somebody about whom there was as much unanimity."

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HAMPSHIRE GROUP LTD., Anderson, S.C., a maker of sweaters and hosiery for department stores and other retailers, agreed to acquire Winona Knitting Mills Inc., Winona, Minn., for undisclosed terms. SOUTHWESTERN LIFE CORP., Louisville, Ky., an insurance holding company, said it would sell its unit, Bankers Life Insurance, New York, to the Indianapolis Life Insurance Company for about $35 million.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Favored Early, Ignored at the Finish

title: Riverwood Intl.  Corp.(RVW,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
description: b-Included equity in earnings of affiliate, net of tax, of $ 7,740,000, and a charge of almost $ 3 million, or 2 cents a share, to cover the expenses of stock-based management incentive plans, primarily because the company's common stock price increased by 20 percent from the year-end 1994 level.Year-ago first quarter ended March 26.Sales are net sales.

title: A Piece of a Rented Truck Offers a Clue to 2 Suspects
description: As rain fell on the wreckage of Oklahoma City's Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building late Wednesday night, Federal agents unearthed a piece of a leased truck that sent investigators racing to a truck-rental agency in Kansas and onto the trail of two suspected bombers.

title: Two Boys in Quest of a Cure
description: Anyone who played in the woods as a child should relate to the scenes in "The Cure" when two 11-year-old boys, one of whom has AIDS, brew mysterious herb teas from leaves and roots they have collected outdoors. After seeing a headline in a supermarket tabloid proclaiming that a doctor in New Orleans has found an herbal cure, Erik (Brad Renfro) tries to heal his ailing next-door neighbor, Dexter (Joseph Mazzello), with teas made from the local foliage.

title: Hong Kong Worries Over Fate of Legal System Under Chinese Rule
description: As Hong Kong hurtles toward reunification with China two years from now, a central pillar of this territory's vibrancy -- its vigorous legal system and independent judiciary -- is under threat, leading business figures, lawyers and legislators here say.

title: 'Where's My Baby?' A Cry That Echoes Still
description: The walls of the day-care center were adorned with the creations of toddlers: works in crayon, finger paint, paste and paper. A bulletin board listed the day's activities: songs and toys and special projects. And there were large windows, perfect for little daydreamers to gaze out and wonder.

title: Nucor Corp.(NUE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
Stocks Advance on Oil Issues and I.B.M. Earnings Surge
description: Stocks rose yesterday, pushed up by six rounds of computer-guided "buy" orders, particularly for shares of oil companies and I.B.M.

title: Illinois Tool Works Inc.(ITW,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
WEYERHAEUSER RAISES DIVIDEND AND PLANS BUYBACK
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company said yesterday that it had raised its second-quarter dividend by 33 percent and planned to buy back up to 5 percent of its outstanding stock. Shares of Weyerhaeuser rose 12.5 cents, to $39, on the New York Stock Exchange. The buyback plan calls for 10 million shares to be repurchased within a year. Based on the closing price yesterday, the repurchase would be valued at about $390 million. The dividend will rise to 40 cents a share from 30 cents, a payout that had been in effect since 1988. Weyerhaeuser is a supplier of paper, pulp and other forest products based in Tacoma, Wash.

title: Hawkins, Ferry, the Pearl: An Over-50 Dream Team
description: You could start Connie Hawkins, Bob Love and Bob Ferry up front and Earl Monroe and Guy Rodgers in the backcourt. When they tired, you could replace them with Paul Silas, Bailey Howell, Cazzie Russell, Cliff Hagan and Barry Clemens.

title: Sears Posts Strong Earnings, With Allstate in Starring Role
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company reported first-quarter earnings today that were better than analysts had expected. They showed a strong improvement at the Allstate insurance division.

title: New Zealand Buries Haunting Past Failure And One Australia
description: New Zealand's Black Magic hasn't advanced far enough yet to lay its hands on the America's Cup. But today it came closer than any other yachting team in Kiwi history. And for that, even the reserved New Zealanders found cause for jubilation.

title: Southern New England Telecommunications Corp.(SNG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Revenue is consolidated sales and revenues.

title: Earnings Jump 36% at Capital Cities/ABC
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings, buoyed by Super Bowl advertising gains at the ABC television network, jumped 36 percent.

title: Home Video
description: Every so often -- and invariably after the release of a popular title like "Belle Epoque" or "Like Water for Chocolate" -- video analysts report a surge of interest in foreign films in the United States. Specialists in foreign videos, though, say that while sales are up somewhat, the category is holding about steady.

title: Bausch & Lomb Inc.(BOL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
Did a Man Expelled By Yale 'Belong'?
description: To Yale University officials, Lon Grammer is a C student from a California community college who lied his way into the Ivy League. They say he won admission to Yale by forging his community college transcripts to give himself an A-plus average and by manufacturing letters of recommendation in his transfer application.

title: Fingerhut Companies (FHT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Philip M. Foisie, 73, an Editor At Washington Post and in Paris
description: Philip M. Foisie, who initiated overseas news coverage at The Washington Post as its foreign editor and later served as the executive editor of the Paris-based International Herald Tribune, died on Tuesday at a hospital. He was 73 and lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Birabeau Allan Stone Gallery 113 East 90th Street Manhattan Through tomorrow

title: SCEcorp (SCE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The latest first quarter's share earnings were after a one cent charge for employee severance.

title: Schering-Plough Corp.(SGP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
The Bengals Are Willing to Trade Places
description: Last year, the Cincinnati Bengals were sitting in the driver's seat of the National Football League college draft with the No. 1 pick over all. They kept the pick and selected defensive tackle Dan Wilkinson of Ohio State.

title: Workers Get Walking Papers
description: Today is the final day of work for 317 Essex County employees whose jobs were eliminated by the county executive, James Treffinger, in his efforts to close a budget gap of $162 million. "Every department is affected," said Brenda Veltri-Possumato, personnel director.

title: Trinova Corp.(TNV,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Corrections
description: A chart on the Health page in some editions yesterday, about mortality rates and exercise intensity, referred incompletely to the energy expenditure levels shown. The levels were expressed in kilojoules, or thousands of joules, per week. (A joule is the work done in moving a one-kilogram mass by one meter.)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dollar Up for Second Day On Strong Buying Overseas

title: Latest Signs of a Slowdown Help to Raise Bond Prices
description: For the first time this week, prices of long- and short-term government securities moved in the same direction yesterday, as fresh evidence of a slowing economy combined with a rebounding dollar to help lift prices.

title: Summing Up a Life, With Outside Help
description: THE DISTINGUISHED GUEST By Sue Miller 282 pages. HarperCollins. $24.

title: For Survivor, the Recovery Starts
description: David Grossman, the sole survivor of the shootings at a Montclair post office last month, is home from the hospital.

title: G.M. Profit of $2.2 Billion Tops Wall St. Expectations
description: The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that a long-awaited turnaround of its North American automotive operations was responsible for strong first-quarter earnings of $2.2 billion, or $2.51 a share.

title: Season Ended For Isles' Pilon
description: Rich Pilon will miss the Islanders' seven remaining games after X-rays taken Wednesday disclosed that the defenseman has a broken left wrist.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: WELFARE SCREENING PROGRAM CRITICIZED

title: Hoffenberg Confesses to Ponzi Scheme
description: Steven Hoffenberg, one of the brashest figures on the New York business scene, pleaded guilty yesterday to criminal conspiracy and fraud charges in connection with a $460 million scheme that was described by prosecutors as one of the largest financial swindles in history.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Slip a Bit on Big Board
description: On the American Stock Exchange during the same period, short interest rose to 99.1 million shares from 97.4 million, an increase of 1.7 percent.

title: Don't Look to Hydrogen for Future Fuel
description: To the Editor:

title: Capital Cities/ABC Inc.(CCB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
description: The ABC Television Network and the television stations reported a significant increase in revenues for the first quarter of 1995. These gains were due to increased advertiser demand and the broadcast of Super Bowl XXIX in 1195, and in part to the absence of the Winter Olympics, which were broadcast on another network in 1994.Revenue represented net revenues.

title: Dream Comes True
description: ARTHUR AGEE, whose life was chronicled in the acclaimed documentary "Hoop Dreams," yesterday became the first player to sign with the Florida Sharks of the United States Basketball League. Agee, who played at Arkansas State last season, was the first choice by the Sharks in last week's U.S.B.L. draft. " 'Hoop Dreams' is now officially a reality," the Sharks' president, ANDY BADOLATO, said at the Sarasota, Fla. signing in front of a shark tank. (AP)

title: Kohlberg, Kravis to Acquire Bruno's Supermarket Chain
description: Bruno's Inc., a large supermarket chain in the South, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company for nearly $1 billion in cash and stock.

title: Anti-Terrorism Bill: Blast Turns a Snail Into a Race Horse
description: On Tuesday, the Omnibus Counter terrorism Act of 1995 was a proposal on a slow track in Congress and the subject of a lively debate as to whether it would violate fundamental civil liberties, including the right to confront one's accuser.

title: Landstar Systems Inc.(LSTR,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
description: Landstar Systems Inc.'s revenues in the latest quarter included $ 39.2 million in revenues from recently completed acquisitions.

title: What Would the Old Boys Say?
description: The old-boy network of the 1950's and 1960's, when a professor at Harvard called his counterpart at M.I.T. to discuss whether there was a faculty job for his best student, has long since been replaced by an organized, centralized market for new Ph.D.'s, complete with rankings, flyouts, tryouts, signing bonuses and special deals.

title: Vietnam's Aftereffects In 'Redwood Curtain'
description: With Robert S. McNamara's public apologia currently rubbing salt in various Vietnam War wounds, the timing could hardly be better for the "Hallmark Hall of Fame" presentation of "Redwood Curtain," Sunday night on ABC. Hiding behind this curtain, in the forests of Northern California, are hundreds, perhaps thousands, of shattered Vietnam veterans unable to re-adjust to the "normal" world they left behind. In fairy-tale tradition, this forest is truly haunted.

title: F.T.C. CHARGES THREE COMPANIES WITH FRAUD
description: The Federal Trade Commission charged three companies with fraud yesterday in schemes to sell investments in new communications technologies. The agency said Chase McNulty Group Inc. of St. Petersburg, Fla., and Digital Interactive Associates Inc. of Denver used deceptive tactics to sell shares in partnerships to acquire licenses for wireless interactive television networks nationwide. Consumers invested nearly $25 million in the two plans, the chairman of the agency, Robert Pitofsky, said. The third company, the Satellite Broadcasting Corporation, based in Irvine, Calif., was accused of misleading investors in a plan to market and distribute direct broadcast satellite television programming in Georgia. Chase McNulty and Digital Interactive did not respond to requests for comment. Satellite Broadcasting could not be reached for comment.

title: Ewing Limps, Harper Limps and Knicks Skip to a Victory
description: An injury to Patrick Ewing could not stop the Knicks. An injury to Derek Harper could not stop them. A 12-point fourth-quarter deficit could not stop them. And the Charlotte Hornets, whom the Knicks had not beaten all season, could not stop New York either.

title: Crown Cork & Seal Co.  (CCK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Results for 1995 include the operations of Tri-Valley Growers, acquired in the third quarter of 1994.Sales represented net sales.

title: LIBBEY-OWENS-FORD WINS LONG-TERM G.M. CONTRACT
description: The Libbey-Owens-Ford Company, based in Toledo, Ohio, said yesterday that it had received a long-term contract from the General Motors Corporation, valued at more than $700 million, to provide specialized glass for G.M. vehicles. Libbey-Owens-Ford is a unit of Pilkington P.L.C., a supplier of auto glass based in London. The company would not specify the length of the contract, but said long-term meant at least five years.

title: Argentina Site For G.M. Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it was planning to build a $500 million automobile plant in Argentina.

title: Fuji to Be Sponsor For Sony Imax Films
description: Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. said yesterday that it had agreed to become the first worldwide corporate sponsor of the 3-D Imax films presented by the Sony Corporation. Though the terms of the sponsorship package were not disclosed, it was estimated to be valued in seven figures.

title: In Presidential Bout, Gaullist Rivals Take Off the Gloves
description: Charles de Gaulle might have been horrified by the spectacle: two members of a party founded to preserve his legacy scratching each other's eyes out over the presidency.

title: Yanks Return to Denver Facing Flurries and Flu
description: The New York Yankees came back to Denver today for the second time in less than a month, facing fatigue, the flu, the flurries, an unbelievably taxing schedule and the throng that helped re-introduce Coors Field to baseball.

title: Tania K. Stern; Therapist and Translator, 91
description: Tania Kurella Stern, a physical therapist and a co-translator, with her husband, of the work of many noted German writers, died on Monday at her home in Wiltshire, England. She was 91.

title: Poor See New Indignity in Welfare Fraud War
description: Mildred Williams sat nervously in a room with blue walls early Wednesday, waiting for her name to be called. She had come to the welfare office at 330 Jay Street in Brooklyn seeking public assistance. It was the second time in two months.

title: Landlord Held In the Deaths Of Five Men In Connecticut
description: The landlord of a fire-ravaged three-family home in which five men died Tuesday night was arrested today in North Carolina as evidence mounted that the slayings resulted from a vicious landlord-tenant dispute.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * CIT Group Holdings Inc., New York, is selling $200 milion of notes due in 1998 through CS First Boston Corp. The notes are priced at 99.78 to yield 6.832 percent. The noncallable issue is rated Aa3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc., A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corp. and AA- by Duff & Phelps.

title: J. Peter Grace, Ex-Company Chief, Dies at 81
description: J. Peter Grace, the outspoken and at times controversial industrialist who headed a major American company longer than any other chief executive, died of cancer on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 81 and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Ruddick Corp.(RDK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
Salo Can't Do It Alone
description: One goal has not been enough to beat the powerful Philadelphia Flyers since early February, but one goal was all the support the Islanders could manage tonight for the promising rookie goalie Tommy Salo at the Spectrum.

title: INTUIT'S STOCK FALLS ON CONCERN ABOUT MICROSOFT DEAL
description: Shares of Intuit Inc. fell yesterday, as a report of possible moves by the Justice Department increased speculation that the proposed $1.4 billion acquisition of Intuit by the Microsoft Corporation might fall through. While some analysts said they did not expect the Justice Department to oppose the acquisition, private antitrust lawyers said department officials were inclined to impose restrictions on what Microsoft could do with the Quicken personal finance software program of Intuit, which is based in Menlo Park, Calif. Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash., has its own personal finance software. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Intuit fell $1.25, to $76.25, and shares of Microsoft fell 87.5 cents, to $75.25. A report in an on-line newsletter, Interactive Week, said Justice Department officials were collecting evidence for a possible challenge to the acquisition.

title: McDonald's Corp.(MCD,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Results for the latest first quarter included $ 11.9 million in preferred stock dividends and the year-ago period included $ 11.8 million in preferred stock dividends.Systemwide sales in the latest first quarter totaled $ 6,671,600,000, compared with $ 5,709,200,000 in year-ago period.

title: Ciba-Geigy Expands Oncogene Alliance
description: Ciba-Geigy A.G., the Swiss drug and chemical giant, yesterday strengthened its alliance with Oncogene Science Inc., a biotechnology company in Uniondale, L.I.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Modern Hierogylphs' 'Gestural Drawing and the European Vanguard 1900-1918' Equitable Gallery 787 Seventh Avenue (at 52d Street) Manhattan Through May 6

title: Precisely Cultivating A Lively Garden
description: At 73, the painter Nell Blaine is not gone and not forgotten, but she's not exactly in the limelight, either. Her simultaneous exhibitions on West 57th Street -- a show of recent watercolors and paintings at the Fischbach Gallery, and a small 45-year survey at the Tibor de Nagy Gallery -- give her quietly luminous achievement a moment of deserved prominence.

title: 3 Health Systems Study Venture
description: Three of the nation's largest Catholic health care systems agreed yesterday to evaluate a merger that would create a $4 billion hospital and long-term care organization.

title: In Twisted Remains of Building, Hope and Expectation vs. Death
description: One way or another, Dr. Rick Nelson was determined to carry someone out from the tangled, unsteady remains of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building. But by late Wednesday night, as signs of survivors faded, he stood yards away from the shattered facade, willing even to help haul out corpses who were beyond the help of his surgeon's training.

title: The Good Earth Looks Better
description: Tomorrow, on the 25th anniversary of Earth Day, I'll be smiling, and so should you. Nearly every ecological trend in the United States is positive. The air and water are getting cleaner and the forests are rebounding: a natural recovery of historic proportions may be at hand. The first Earth Day, in 1970, was a time for demonstrations and expressions of rage. Earth Day 1995 is a moment for celebration.

title: Apple Earnings Rise Fourfold, But Still Below Expectations
description: Stung by a surprising loss in foreign-currency dealings, Apple Computer Inc. reported earnings today that fell far short of Wall Street's expectations, even though they surged nearly fourfold.

title: Black (Box) Art of Steal-Per-View
description: Hey you! You with the illegal black boxes stealing pay-per-view fights, absconding with money rightfully belonging to cable companies, boxers and promoters like Bob Arum and Don King. You say you have no sympathy for them?

title: CHRONICLE
description: When members of the Rockefeller family take on a cause, they certainly give it their all. Consider International House, the residence hall and program center where 700 graduate students and trainees from some 100 countries live every year.

title: SmithKine Beecham (SBH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The net income and share earnings excluded exceptional items.Sales are from continuing operations.Share earnings are per equity unit American depository receipts.Results in United States dollars have been translated at the exchange rate used for pounds sterling for the three months ended March 31, 1995, and March 31, 1994, at the average rate for the latest period, 1 pound sterling equaled $ 1.59.

title: Strain of Simpson Trial Takes Toll on One Juror
description: For the first time in the O. J. Simpson case, a sitting juror today asked Judge Lance A. Ito to release her from the panel, saying she "can't take it anymore."

title: Images, but No Camera
description: Photograms, the ghostly images made by placing objects directly on a sheet of photographic paper or film and exposing it to light, have lately been enjoying something of a revival. In recent years, several contemporary photographers, including Joan Fontcuberta and Kunie Sugiura, have used the process to achieve surprisingly diverse effects.

title: Bell Atlantic Corp.(BEL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a charge of 4 cents a share for the impact of the devaluation of the Mexican peso on Bell Atlantic's estimated share of the dollar-denominated debt of Grupo Iusacell.c-After an extraordinary charge from early extinguishment of debt of $ 6,700,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: 49ers' DeBartolo Hurt In Two-Car Collision
description: The 49ers' owner, EDWARD DeBARTOLO JR., remained hospitalized in San Francisco yesterday after breaking his collarbone in a collision on his way to the airport Wednesday. DeBartolo, who came to San Francisco for JOE MONTANA's farewell rally Tuesday, should be able to return to his Youngstown, Ohio, home today, CARMEN POLICY, the team president, said.

title: Move It!
description: For more than 20 years the Harvard School of Public Health has followed the fates of 17,300 middle-aged men. This week the Journal of the American Medical Association reported Harvard's findings: To live a long and healthy life it is necessary to break a sweat. Often.

title: Beverly Enterprises Inc.(BEV,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company said year-ago first-quarter results are restated.

title: Precautions After Oklahoma City
description: It is impossible to look at the grotesquely shattered remains of the Oklahoma City Federal building without wondering whether such bombings will become a brutal commonplace of American life. Once the plague of foreign lands and the stuff of Hollywood special effects, destructive car bombs have now twice torn apart lives and workplaces in the United States. While there is no sure way to prevent a determined bomber from attacking, the country and Government can take steps to make it harder and to limit potential damage.

title: Getting Even In Hollywood Can Be Fun
description: Several of George Huang's former bosses helped him get "Swimming With Sharks" made, even though they should have been hiding under their desks instead. In his six years working for various movie executives, Mr. Huang filed away trenchant observations about great big egos and helpless little assistants. Now he gleefully brings those observations to the screen.

title: Central & South West Corp.(CSR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Arrow Electronics Inc.(ARW,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect August 1994 acquisition of Gates F/A Distributing Inc. and November 1994 acquisition of Anthem Electronics Inc.

title: An Officer Dies and 2 Are Wounded in an Armed Siege
description: A gunman shot three police officers yesterday in a wild gun battle in this quiet Camden County suburb, killing at least one and creating a siege around his home that lasted into the night.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the listing of new equity issues in Business Day on Monday misstated the terms and the lead underwriter for an initial public offering by Shared Technologies Cellular Inc. The offering is for 950,000 shares, not 550,000 units. H. J. Meyers & Company is the lead underwriter.

title: Milovan Djilas, Yugoslav Critic of Communism, Dies at 83
description: Milovan Djilas, the Yugoslav Communist revolutionary whose denunciation of his former comrades in 1957 as a privileged and self-serving "new class" became an early banner of dissidents and anti-Communists, died in Belgrade yesterday. He was 83.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID GEFFEN, the billionaire entertainment company executive, has donated $5 million to the Westwood Playhouse, part of the University of California at Los Angeles, which acquired the building in 1993 to help strengthen its performing arts program.

title: FPL Group (FPL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Brogna, Easy as 1-2-3, Regains Homer Touch
description: Earlier this week, Dallas Green told Rico Brogna to get into the batting cage and hit until his hands started bleeding. Brogna's swing had been off, his batting average abysmal, and Green wanted his young first baseman to put in some extra work.

title: Hospital Group Sues State
description: The New Jersey Hospital Association has gone to court trying to stop the Whitman administration from slashing Medicaid reimbursements by $135 million to help balance the budget. The association, representing 100 hospitals, argues that health care for the poor will suffer if the cuts stand. The state maintains that hospitals can absorb the cuts by operating more efficiently. On Tuesday, arguments on the association's request for an injunction to block the cuts will be heard in Federal Court.

title: For These Women, a Heavy Right Is More Powerful Than Sisterhood
description: "Some people will find it evil and weird," said Leslie Howe, who fights at 135 pounds, "and some will find it a turn-on. It's a subjective reaction. There are ramifications."

title: KeyCorp (KEY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $ 35,800,000, or 15 cents a share.Latest quarter's income from continuing operations of 4173,900,000, or 71 cents a share, included a gain of $ 41.6 million, or 17 cents a share, on sale of mortgage loan servicing business, and charges of $ 5.8 million, or 2 cents a share, on sale of asset management unit, and $ 30.9 million, or 13 cents a share, on securities losses related to balance sheet reconfiguration.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: An Escaped Killer Is Caught
description: The killer who walked away last week from Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital was in custody in Florida yesterday, while a State Senator called for tighter security at institutions for the criminally insane. William Jennings, 39, hospitalized after killing his parents in 1980, had been transferred earlier this year from the state's most secure hospital, Forensic Psychiatric in Trenton, to Marlboro, where he had unsupervised grounds privileges.

title: Restaurants
description: The first time I had dinner at I Trulli, we were the only people in the place. The owner kept nervously throwing logs into the big glass-enclosed fireplace, and the spare, beautiful room grew warmer and warmer. Shadows played against the white walls as the bare trees in the garden stretched to touch the windows. We ate olives and spread tangy homemade ricotta cheese onto thick, rough slices of bread. We drank bottles of spicy, generous wines from southern Italy, and when the waiter asked how everything was, we said it was fine.

title: Defense Denied Mistrial Request Over Oklahoma Blast Publicity
description: The judge in the New York terrorism trial of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman and 10 other men yesterday rejected requests for a mistrial made by defense lawyers who held that their clients' right to a fair trial had been imperiled by graphic news reports about the bombing of a Federal building in Oklahoma City.

title: Abroad at Home; Faith In Reason
description: Thirty years ago, as a reporter in Washington, I could enter almost any Government building without a security check and walk down the halls from office to office. That now seems an almost unimaginable past.

title: Sarajevo Haggadah Barely Escaped Nazis
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEDYNE SHAREHOLDERS ADVISED TO REJECT WHX MOVE
description: Teledyne Inc., an aerospace, industrial and consumer products company based in Los Angeles, said yesterday that a shareholder advisory group had recommended that shareholders reject two nominees of the WHX Corporation to the Teledyne board. WHX, a steelmaker based in Wheeling, W. Va., is seeking to acquire Teledyne for $1.2 billion in cash and stock. In its bid, WHX is trying to win two seats on the Teledyne board. The adviser, Institutional Shareholder Services Inc., of Bethesda, Md., said Teledyne's shareholders should re-elect the company's seven incumbent directors at the annual meeting on April 26, Teledyne said.

title: Clinton Vows a Relentless Pursuit of Bombers and Hopes to Go to Oklahoma
description: President Clinton promised today to follow the trail of the bombers of Oklahoma City to the ends of the earth, and the White House said he wanted to attend a memorial service for the victims on Sunday there unless the authorities decided that his presence would impede the investigation or rescue efforts.

title: Cooper Industries (CBE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 3,800,000, or 34 cents a share.

title: Sun Posts Loss; Occidental Rebounds for a Gain
description: The Sun Company posted a loss for the first quarter yesterday, while the Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it had swung to profitability.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Critics as Artists' Andre Zarre Gallery 48 Greene Street SoHo Through May 6

title: High Over the Andes, In Enormous Goggles
description: "Wings of Courage" is a swooping, old-fashioned adventure tale that uses flashy newfangled technology. The first fiction movie made for IMAX 3-D (the format that makes everyone wear oversized, goofy-looking goggles), this 40-minute film plays to the strengths of its 3-D technique. It's a winning ploy. Based on real events, it tells of daredevil aviators flying mail over the Andes in 1930, but the tale takes second place to the way it is told. In the very first scene, a biplane seems to sail off the screen and hover over the heads of the audience. When aviators go to a nightclub, viewers might step into the space between the table in the foreground and the couple doing a tango in the rear. And when a plane lands, the camera seems to be attached to the rear wheels.

title: Where Nothing Ever Happens, Terrorism Did
description: Two days ago 21-year-old Amber Fleming wrote in her diary: "Worked from 10-6. Got my nails done. Went over to Michael's after book study and watched 'Blazing Saddles' and took my kitten home."

title: Affirmative Action Mocks True Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks! Peanuts! Crackerjack!
description: The Yankees yesterday joined baseball's effort to win back fans with free tickets by making available 4,500 bleacher seats for each game during the first week in May. The seats will be available only on the day of the game for four contests with the Boston Red Sox and three with the Milwaukee Brewers from May 1-7.

title: The Spoken Word
description: SIDNEY LUMET, Teacher's Auditorium, Tisch Film School, New York University, 721 Broadway, at Waverly Place, Greenwich Village. The film director will read from his new book, "Making Movies." Sponsored by Posman Books. Tonight at 6:30. Free. Information: (212) 533-2665. "COUPLETS: A CELEBRATION OF LOVE IN VERSE, SCENE AND SONG," Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street. Romantic works by Shakespeare, Shaw, E. E. Cummings, Edna St. Vincent Millay and others will be read by Victoria Wyndham and Charles Keating, actors. Tomorrow at 8 P.M. Tickets: $20 (performance only) and $40 (includes reception); $9 for students. Proceeds benefit Symphony Space. Information: (212) 864-5400.

title: New York State Electric & Gas Corp.(NGE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Cutting Welfare Won't Reduce Teen-Age Births; Food Stamp Lobby
description: To the Editor:

FMC Corp.(FMC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Art in Review
description: Marcus Harvey Tanya Banakdar Gallery 130 Prince Street SoHo Through April 29

title: Suggestions for Some Theater a la Carte
description: THERE was a time, the old ones say, when New Yorkers actually talked about the theater, when Manhattan dinner and cocktail conversations simmered with heated considerations of O'Neill's anger, Albee's ontology and Carol Channing's eyelashes.

title: Market Place; Just What Card Will Kerkorian Play Next?
description: Does the man who would be emperor of the Chrysler Corporation have no clothes? Or, does Kirk Kerkorian's sleeve conceal some yet-unseen trump card in his $22.8 billion bid for the company?

title: Oates Given 2-Week Leave
description: Texas Rangers Manager Johnny Oates, his wife hospitalized with exhaustion, was granted a two-week leave of absence today and will miss the start of the season.

title: A Better Welfare Reform Plan
description: It is too early to make sense of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's report that tougher screening reduced the number of new enrollees in the New York State welfare system by 60 percent for the first three months of the year. Perhaps fraud is that rampant. Perhaps, contrary to the city's assertions, applicants were rejected for petty reasons or discouraged by byzantine procedures. Whatever the explanation, Albany should not use the figure, as Gov. George Pataki has suggested, as reason to back his harsh welfare reform plan over the Democratic alternative.

title: William Scott, 46; Led AIDS Groups
description: William Arnold Scott, who founded organizations aimed at increasing awareness of gay and lesbian concerns in Houston and became a national figure on AIDS issues, died on April 4 at Park Plaza Hospital in Houston. He was 46 and lived in Houston.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER ACQUIRES CARTER HOLT
description: After a weeklong effort, the International Paper Company acquired control yesterday of Carter Holt Harvey Ltd., the paper company based in New Zealand. International Paper, based in Purchase, N.Y., paid 1.7 billion New Zealand dollars, or about $1.15 billion, to lift its stake to 50.1 percent for the company, which it has managed for the last four years. Before the takeover, International Paper held 23.7 percent of the company. With Carter Holt, International Paper, the world's largest producer of forest products, hopes to increase its manufacturing capacity without building new plants.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Wednesday about a farewell concert at Alice Tully Hall on Monday in honor of Charles Kaufman, the retiring dean of the Mannes College of Music, referred incompletely to a speaker, Jonathan F. Fanton. Besides being a trustee of the New School for Social Research, he is its president.

title: Thomas to Conduct Lincoln Center Concerts
description: Michael Tilson Thomas is to conduct the New World Symphony Orchestra in his composition "From the Diary of Anne Frank," on April 28 at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. The work, composed for Audrey Hepburn and dedicated to her while she was a roving ambassador for Unicef, is to be narrated by Debra Winger. Mahler's Symphony No. 1 will complete the program. Tickets, at $18 to $35, are available at the Fisher Hall box office or through Center Charge (212) 721-6500.

title: A Day in the Very Public Life of Jersey City's Chief Executive
description: MAYOR Bret Schundler was running late. First, his father had stopped by City Hall to say hello. Second, his right foot was dragging a bit in the lace-up sandal the doctor made him wear after removing a plantar wart.

title: Wrong Harvard Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: Chubb Corp.(CHB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a net one-time charge of $ 6.5 million, or 7 cents a share, resulting from the adoption of a new accounting standard relating to the measurement of loan impairment.

title: White Supremacist Executed For Murdering 2 in Arkansas
description: Richard Wayne Snell, a white supremacist who expressed no remorse for killing a Jewish businessman and a black police officer, was put to death by lethal injection on Wednesday night, but not before delivering a threat to Gov. Jim Guy Tucker, who declined to block his execution.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HUGH DOWNS, the co-anchor of ABC's "20/20," also sticks to what he does. In 1985, he made it into "The Guinness Book of World Records" for having logged more hours on camera than anyone else on commercial network television.

title: ZAPATA CANCELS SALE OF UNIT TO MANAGEMENT GROUP
description: The Zapata Corporation said yesterday that it had canceled plans to sell its fishing business to a management-led group. The company, based in Houston, said on April 6 that it would sell the marine protein division as part of a larger plan to withdraw from the natural gas business, its chief operations. The expected purchase price for the marine protein unit had been $56 million in cash and the assumption of $11 million of debt. Zapata said the deal fell through because the acquisition group could not secure financing.

title: Mets May Have Bonilla Linger in Outfield Role
description: Although Dallas Green seems far from enamored of the idea, he did not rule out the possibility of moving Bobby Bonilla back to the outfield when he was asked today about his plans for filling his right field vacancy.

title: Youths and Woman Assault Police Officer
description: Three male teen-agers and a 21-year-old woman beat an off-duty policeman in Queens with a bicycle wheel and a chain yesterday after the officer approached them complaining that something had been thrown at his car, the police said. The attack left the officer in serious condition at a hospital.

title: Searching for the Psyche's Secrets Among Grids and Random Images
description: Beginning in the 1940's, the New York School painter Adolph Gottlieb earned a place among America's leading artists with his pictographs. They consisted of loose grids. Gottlieb spoke of the grids as houses, and compared their compartments to rooms, which he filled with abstract shapes, some of them derived from African masks, Pre-Columbian sculptures and American Indian objects.

title: Art in Review
description: Thomas Woodruff 'The Secret Charts' P.P.O.W. 532 Broadway (at Prince Street) SoHo Through tomorrow

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Spurs Clinch Home Advantage Sean Elliott was fouled on a layup with 0.5 seconds left, then made both free throws to lead San Antonio to a 112-111 victory over the Mavericks in Dallas last night as the Spurs clinched homecourt advantage throughout the playoffs. The Spurs improved to a franchise-best 60-20 and locked up the National Basketball Association's best record for the season. Dallas led by as much as 103-97 with 4 minutes 47 seconds left. "It was a special way to win our 60th," said Spurs Coach Bob Hill. "It guarantees us the best record in the league. Now the real season begins." (AP) SUPERSONICS 111, ROCKETS 101: Gary Payton, playing in his fourth straight game with a bothersome broken ring finger on his left hand, scored 25 points to lead Seattle over visiting Houston and a sweep of the teams' four-game season series. (AP)

title: Consolidated Freightways Inc.(CNF,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect the conversion of Series C Preferred stock to Common stock in the three months ended March 31, 1995.Revenue represented total revenues.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows: ALIGHIERO E BOETTI and RICHARD LONG, Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, SoHo (through tomorrow). Perhaps the most beautiful two-artist, two-work exhibition in SoHo, this show brings together two geography-driven sensibilities: on the wall is Mr. Boetti's emerald-green tapestry listing the 1,000 longest rivers in the world; spread before it on the floor is Mr. Long's "Somerset Willow Line," an arrangement of sticks evoking a river bed of spare and brittle elegance (Roberta Smith).

title: Knight-Ridder Inc.(KRI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 7,320,000, or 14 cents a share.

description: b-Included $ 144,533,000 after-tax write-off recognized in the third quarter as a result of a disallowance by the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio of a portion of its investment in the Wm. H. Zimmer Generating Station.

description: Stan Douglas David Zwirner Gallery 43 Greene Street SoHo Through April 29

title: A Cornell Applicant Is Rejected Again
description: This time, Elizabeth L. Mikus got the thin envelope.

Harold Fong, 56, Judge in Center Of Dispute on Write-In Ballots
description: Judge Harold M. Fong of Federal District Court in Hawaii, who prompted an important constitutional ruling and became involved in the tangled legal affairs of Ferdinand E. Marcos, the longtime President of the Philippines, died on Thursday at Queen's Medical Center in Honolulu. A lifelong resident of Honolulu, he was a few days short of his 57th birthday.
