description: b-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 680 million, or $ 1.71 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: Apogee Enterprises Inc.(APOG,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-Net lossc-Included a restructuring charge of $ 4.5 million or 34 cents a share in both the quarter and year. The year also included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 525,000, or 4 cents a share.(Loss)

title: Ref Gets the Rangers' Seventh-Man Award
description: From a Ranger fan's perspective, Referee Bill McCreary could have been named one of the three stars of last night's game. And if the New Yorkers indeed make the playoffs, McCreary might just deserve an assist, as well.

title: Split Scheduled At General Mills
description: The board of General Mills Inc. has set May 28 as the day the company will split into separate consumer foods and restaurant businesses.

title: Prevention of Mexican-Style Crisis Sought
description: Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, proposed today the strengthening of international financial institutions to help prevent another Mexican-style financial crisis.

title: Knicks are at Camp for Playoff Cram Course
description: This is playoff week, which means it is time for Camp Riley.

title: A Clash Over a Trove of Original Scores
description: Hundreds of original manuscripts that include symphonies by Beethoven in his helter-skelter scrawl and operas by Mozart in his neat penmanship are the subject of one of the most politically charged cultural-heritage cases in Europe.

title: Shifting Debate to the Political Climate, Clinton Condemns 'Promoters of Paranoia'
description: President Clinton today denounced "promoters of paranoia" for spreading hate on the public airwaves and promptly found himself in a confrontation with conservative radio talk show hosts, whom he had not named but who interpreted his remarks as attacks on themselves.

title: South Jersey Industries(SJI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Less Crime on the Boardwalk
description: The safest street in the nation? Police Chief Nicholas Rifice says it is the Boardwalk here. His evidence: State Police figures released yesterday by city officials that say crime in the gambling resort dropped 18.7 percent last year and 42.6 since 1991.

title: Islanders Thrive On Youth
description: Already eliminated from playoff contention in what has been a dismal season, the Islanders took a happy glimpse into their future tonight as they defeated the Boston Bruins, 5-3, before 10,657 spectators at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Foreman Might Face Mandatory Rematch
description: George Foreman, 46 years old, $10 million richer and planning to continue fighting, could be forced by the International Boxing Federation to defend his title again against Axel Schulz, the man who nearly took it from him Saturday night.

title: Welch Cut by A's After He Plays Along
description: Even after agreeing to a huge pay cut and signing a minor league contract, BOB WELCH was unable to stay with the Oakland Athletics. Welch, who won the 1990 American League Cy Young award with a 27-6 record, was released late Sunday night by the A's as part of a series of moves that trimmed the roster to the opening-day limit of 28.

title: Corrections
description: The Parent and Child column in The Home Section on Thursday, about therapists who advise couples in troubled marriages to stay together, misstated the name of a therapist who is about to publish a book on the subject, "Soul Searching: Why Psychotherapy Must Promote Moral Responsibility" (Basic Books). He is Dr. William Doherty, not Dr. Walter Dorherty.

title: USX-Marathon Group (MRO,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a $ 55 million favorable after-tax effect of an inventory market valuation adjustment.c-Included net of $ 89 million mainly from a favorable inventory market valuation adjustment and a gain on the sale of certain production assets.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: John McGovern, 87, Developer Of Processes in Paper Making
description: John N. McGovern, an innovator in the pulp and paper field and professor emeritus of forestry at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, died on March 21 in a nursing home in Madison. He was 87 and was a longtime resident of the city.

title: Beckman Instruments Inc.(BEC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 3.1 million, or 7 cents a share, as an ongoing part of the restructuring program.c-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 5,100,000, or 18 cents a share. Also included is a pretax charge of $ 1.2 million, or after-tax of 3 cents a share, for restructuring.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARY GORDON, the novelist, teaches writing to elderly people at the Morningside Gardens Senior Center on the Upper West Side and to undergraduates at Barnard College, where she is the Millicent McIntosh Professor of English. This evening, she will bring both groups together at the college to read from their works.

title: Asarco Inc.(AR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included $ 31.9 million after-tax gain on the sale of Asarco's remaining interest in Asarco Australia Ltd. and a $ 2.6 million after-tax gain related to recovery of a bad debt previously written off.Asarco said in a press release that on April 5 it acquired an additional 10.7 percent interest in Southern Peru Copper Corp. for $ 116.4 million, increasing its holding to 63 percent.Asarco is consolidating the results of Southern Peru Copper in its results effective with the first quarter of 1995. Had Southern Peru Copper been consolidated in the first quarter of 1994, sales for that quarter would have been $ 579.7 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The world-class sign-scape of Times Square attracts its first Chinese marketer.
description: TIMES SQUARE will soon add another language to the many tongues used to pitch products from the colorful cacophony of its oversized outdoor posters: Chinese.

title: U.S. Bond Prices Mixed As Group of Seven Gathers
description: Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday with many investors on the sidelines, apprehensive over today's meeting of leading industrialized nations about the plight of the dollar.

title: Rangers Hang Onto Lead and a Piece of 8th Place
description: The Rangers just don't make it easy on themselves or their fans. Not when they take a four-goal lead, as they did last night. Not when they drive the other team's starting goalie from the net. Not when a top opposing player leaves with an injury. Not even when the officiating prompts the opposing coach to stand up on the boards and get penalized for protesting.

title: Jefferson's Love Life Doesn't Equal History; A Colonial Cinderella?
description: To the Editor:

title: Detroit Edison Co. (DTE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.N. in Bosnia: Black Robes Clash With Blue Hats
description: How many hats can the United Nations wear in its dealings with Bosnia?

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Styles pages on Sunday about the wedding of Deirdre Gibson Michalopoulos and Christopher James Vlasto referred incorrectly to the bridegroom's grandfather Solon G. Vlasto. He is not "the late."

title: Bank of England Deputy Is Named
description: Prime Minister John Major of Britain appointed Howard Davies, director general of the Confederation of British Industry, to become deputy governor of the Bank of England today.

title: Shopping Purgatory, or Paradise; Northeast's Supermarkets Outclassed by Sun Belt's
description: So what was it like, one recent evening in supermarket purgatory?

title: Rochester Gas & Electric Corp.(RGS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Fund-Raiser For the G.O.P. Is Indicted
description: A real estate executive who has been a major Republican fund-raiser was charged in an indictment unsealed yesterday with illegally demanding political contributions from tenants and brokers for several Republican causes, including Rudolph W. Giuliani's two mayoral campaigns.

title: The Explosion Echoes in Cyberspace
description: Almost before the boom of the explosion that devastated the Federal building had stopped reverberating across downtown Oklahoma City, cyberspace was alive with commentary.

title: Amerada Hess (AHC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 43.9 million, or 47 cents a share, on refund of windfall profits taxes applicable to years 1981 through 1986, and related interest.

title: Newspapers Are Advised to Build Their Brand Identities
description: Newspaper publishers should build their publications' brand identities with the public to compete in a new media marketplace, a national gathering of publishers was told here today.

title: Citgo Petroleum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Citgo is a unit of Petroleos de Venezuela S.A.

title: Security Company in Queens Is Robbed of About $1 Million
description: At least two masked gunmen entered the office of a security company in Queens Village, Queens, early yesterday, tied up five workers and got away with about $1 million, a police spokesman said.

title: Carl Whitaker, 83, Therapist Who Focused on Family Life
description: Dr. Carl A. Whitaker, a psychotherapist who overturned prevailing orthodoxy by focusing on the family rather than the individual in therapy, died on Friday at his home in Nashotah, Wis. He was 83.

title: St. Jude Medical Inc.(STJM,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: St. Jude Medical attributed its improved performance in the latest first quarter to its newly acquired Pacesetter division.

title: 7 Rich Nations Meet for Talks In Bitter Mood
description: For years, the world's three most powerful economies -- the United States, Germany and Japan -- have maintained at least the pretense of cooperation and civility when it comes to managing the world's most vital currencies. Even when vitriolic in private, they always issued soothing statements in public, vaguely promising "coordination" in hopes that a magic word would soothe the markets.

title: Great Lakes ChemicalCorp.(GLK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Let the Public, Not the Planners, Decide Future of Superstores
description: To the Editor:

title: Disney Reports 27% Increase In Net Income for 2d Quarter
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that net income rose 27 percent in the fiscal second quarter, a larger-than-expected gain, lifted by record sales of "The Lion King" video and increased attendance at its theme parks.

title: Not Giving in to Terrorism
description: A young New Jersey woman is going back to Israel, where her sister died in a terrorist bombing April 9. The woman's father, Stephen Flatow, said he was not worried about his 18-year-old daughter, Gail, resuming her studies in the land where 20-year-old Alisa was killed. "The message is, you don't give in to terrorism," he said.

title: Assault on Waco Sect Fuels Extremists' Rage
description: Until their seven-week standoff with Federal agents near Waco, Tex., in 1993, the Branch Davidians were an obscure and tiny religious sect, one of many in the United States.

title: Out West, Superstars Are Set for A Show
description: The shift of power began last June with the conference claiming its first title since 1988. It continued with four teams winning at least 57 games this season. Today, Hakeem Olajuwon worries not how he will stop Patrick Ewing but, rather, how will he propel the Rockets past the first round.

title: C.I.A. Pick Is Facing Senate Test
description: Over the past decade, Deputy Defense Secretary John M. Deutch has survived the tricky business of managing the post-cold-war Pentagon, the trench warfare of high-level academic politics and the unpleasant experience of being hit by a truck.

title: Caremark International (CK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 7,700,000, or 11 cents a share.c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 7,300,000, or 10 cents a share.Share earnings are rounded off.

title: Divorced Fathers Make Gains In Battles to Increase Rights
description: During the five years that William B. Hess arm-wrestled with his wife in court over the dissolution of their marriage, he compiled a list of complaints about how New Jersey's legal system treated divorced fathers. Why, for example, could he be forced to pay his sons' college tuition? If he had stayed married, no one could have compelled him to do so.

title: Newsprint Producers Hear Publishers' Price Troubles
description: More newspapers are likely to close or consolidate editions because of sharply rising newsprint prices, newspaper publishers meeting here said today.

title: ZENITH STOCKHOLDERS VOTE TO INCREASE SHARE LIMITS
description: The shareholders of the Zenith Electronics Corporation voted yesterday to increase the maximum number of shares that the company can issue to 150 million from 100 million. The company, a maker of consumer electronics, is considering one or more stock offerings this year. It may also offer debt or preferred stock that is convertible into common stock. The company, which is the last maker of color television picture tubes based in the United States, has said it needs $150 million to expand its main plant in Melrose Park, Ill.

title: Rush-Hour Protest Causes Gridlock
description: Hundreds of demonstrators blocked two bridges and two tunnels in Manhattan during the height of the rush hour yesterday, causing serious gridlock for over an hour in a coordinated protest of proposed state and city budget cuts and of police brutality.

title: True North Expects Loss for the Quarter
description: True North Communications in Chicago, formerly Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, expects a loss in the first quarter ending March 31 because of a substantial one-time charge against earnings resulting from the restructuring of the Italian operations of Publicis FCB Europe, its joint venture with Publicis S.A. in Paris.

title: Armco Inc.(AS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss and included a $ 20 million special charge related to the restructuring and idling of the company's Mansfield operations in March of 1994.Latest share earnings are after deduction of preferred dividends.(Loss)

title: Times Mirror and Cox Amend Cable Deal
description: The Times Mirror Company and Cox Communications Inc. have renegotiated the terms of the merger agreement under which they agreed to join their cable operations and create the fourth-largest cable operator in the nation.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TED KENNEDY JR. rarely talks about losing his right leg to cancer when he was 12, but tonight he will speak at a benefit for a new organization called Cancer Cured Kids.

title: Soviet Archives: Half-Open, Dirty Window on Past
description: In early August 1930, Stalin wrote a routine note to his most loyal comrade in the Soviet leadership, Vyacheslav M. Molotov, with 10 directives. The second one dealt with the hoarding of coins, a problem the Kremlin was trying to deal with.

title: Helping Toddlers After a Shock
description: WHILE the deaths of babies and young children in the day care center in the Federal Building in Oklahoma City is for many the most disturbing aspect of the bombing, there is another group of toddlers who are also victims.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 'How to Succeed in Business': The producers are trying.
description: HOW do you succeed in marketing "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying"?

title: USLife Corp.(USH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Share earnings excluded capital gains and losses. Net income per share including the gains was $ 1.05 a share for the latest first quarter, compared with $ 1.03 a share for the year-ago period.

title: Erickson Cited for D.W.I.
description: The Seattle Seahawks first-year coach DENNIS ERICKSON was cited April 15 for drunken driving. Erickson, whose University of Miami teams won two national titles, was stopped on Interstate 5 near Marysville. His blood-alcohol reading was .23. A level of .10 is the legal limit in the state. His arraignment is scheduled for May 3. (AP)

title: S.E.C. Backs Big Board on Eased Standards
description: The New York Stock Exchange has received Government approval to revise its listing standards in an effort to recruit more companies from its rival Nasdaq.

title: Accounts
description: * Titan Industries Ltd., Bangalore, India, part of the Tata Group, to the Lowe Group, London, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle the introduction in Europe of the company's quartz analog watches. The billings were estimated at $10 million. * Anheuser-Busch Inc., St. Louis, to Heater/Easdon Advertising, Boston, to handle Busch NA, a new non-alcoholic brew. The billings were not disclosed.

title: Ewing May Be Taking Final Shot At Elusive N.B.A. Championship
description: Last Friday in Boston, Patrick Ewing left his seat on the bench during a timeout to shake hands with Bill Russell.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dizzy Gillespie's famous bent bell trumpet (bent when a party guest tripped over it) fetched $63,000 at auction at Christie's East yesterday.

title: Turgenev's Inquiry Into Calamitous Love
description: Isaiah Berlin once described Ivan Turgenev as "the least vain of famous authors." When, in 1872, a Moscow company decided to give his "Month in the Country" its first stage production, 22 years after it had been written, Turgenev was pessimistic. Audiences, the great novelist said, will find it tedious, and they did. Seven years later no one could have been more surprised than Turgenev when the comedy was well received in its St. Petersburg premiere. Turgenev was grateful but, with some reason, still skeptical.

title: Chemical Mishap Cited in Blast
description: The explosion that toppled a factory here, killing four workers, occurred after a mishap in the blending of toxic chemicals was virtually ignored by the company for nearly 12 hours, the authorities said. Page A1.

title: 2 Seized in Thefts From School Warehouse
description: Two independent truck drivers were arrested yesterday morning and accused of conspiring with school warehouse employees to sell $32,000 worth of school supplies to private retail stores, officials said.

title: Tenneco Inc. (TGT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 1 million, or 1 cent a share, and after a charge of $ 39 million, or 22 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting principle reflecting postemployment benefits.Sales in the year-ago first quarter included $ 1 billion in revenues from the Case Corporation, Tenneco's former farm and construction equipment division. Excluding the Case revenues, Tenneco had $ 2.049 billion in revenues in 1994. Following an initial public offering in June 1994 and a secondary offering in November 1994, Tenneco's ownership in Case Corp. was reduced to about 44 percent.Subsequent to November 1994, Case is reflected in Tenneco's financial statements using the equity method of accounting. Therefore, for the 1995 first quarter, Case's revenues are not included with Tenneco's, and 44 percent of Case's net income is included in Tenneco's operating income.The 1994 results from continuing operations have been restated to reflect the chemicals and brake businesses as discontinued operations.Sales are net sales and operating revenue.

title: Freeport-McMoRan Inc.(FTX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 5.7 million, or four cents a share, because the company didn't receive its proportionate share of Freeport-McMoRan Resource Partners L.P.'s (FRP) fourth quarter distribution.c-After an extraordinary charge of $ 5,459,000, or 4 cents a share, from early retirement of debt.Year-ago income from continuing operations of $ 23,419,000, or 13 cents a share, included a $ 28.6 million gain, or 20 cents a share, on the conversion of Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc. securities.Share earnings results are after preferred dividends in both periods.

title: Yeltsin Orders 3-Week Halt To War on Chechen Rebels
description: Clearly nervous that Russia's World War II victory celebration could turn into a public relations fiasco, President Boris N. Yeltsin has decreed a halt to all combat in the breakaway region of Chechnya, beginning Friday, while dozens of Western leaders are in Moscow for V-E Day.

title: The Very Soul of Tango, From an Unlikely Source
description: Who would have thought a Swedish choreographer with an intellectual bent could get to the heart of the tango -- and the personalities of four distinctive dancers -- and come up with a piece as juicy and full of wit as Irene Hultman's "Tango-Babe"? The new work, performed on Sunday night at St. Mark's Danspace, is a joy.

title: Breast-Implant Judge Permits Lawsuits Against Dow Chemical
description: Reversing his earlier decision, a Federal district judge here ruled today that the Dow Chemical Company could be sued in Federal court for damages that might have resulted from silicone breast implants made by an affiliate.

title: Term Papers on CD-ROM Turn Words Into Virtual Reality
description: Goodbye, term paper.

title: MAGTEN SELLS ITS STAKE IN WESTPOINT STEVENS
description: Westpoint Stevens Inc. said yesterday that the Magten Asset Management Corporation had sold its entire stake of 2.9 million shares of the company, a maker of bed and bath products. Shares of Westpoint Stevens rose 87.5 cents, to $18.375, in Nasdaq trading yesterday. Westpoint Stevens, based in West Point, Ga., had revenue of $1.60 billion last year.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Verismo 'Giselle' With a Leavening of Passion
description: If it's "Giselle," it must be spring, or at least time for American Ballet Theater's annual season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Opting for what seemed a sure bet, the company led off on Monday night with a star-studded partnership in 19th-century ballet's most celebrated tale of remorse and regeneration.

title: Dollar Drops as Outlook Dims For Action by the Group of 7
description: The dollar ended lower against most leading currencies yesterday as expectations faded that the United States and its economic allies would take steps to bolster the value of the dollar.

title: Amdahl (AMH,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Judge Prohibits City From Evicting East Village Squatters
description: A state judge yesterday prohibited New York City from evicting squatters from three dilapidated city-owned buildings that city officials said were dangerous. Instead, the judge ordered the city to come up with a plan for repairs to insure that the buildings were safe to occupy.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 17 about the backlog of civil cases in Federal courts in New York referred incorrectly at one point to the court of Judge I. Leo Glasser. His court, the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, is part of the Second Circuit; it is not part of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: People
description: Adrienne Cleere was named publisher of House Beautiful magazine, New York, owned by the Hearst Corp., succeeding Carole Ference, who left in February to join Ticketmaster Corp., Los Angeles, as publisher of a magazine scheduled for later this year or early next year. Ms. Cleere was previously vice president for international marketing at the Bloomingdale's unit of Federated Department Stores, New York. She is also a former vice president and publisher of W magazine, owned by Capital Cities/ABC.

title: Delighting in China's Past, Surviving in Its Present
description: LIANG AND LIN Partners in Exploring China's Architectural Past By Wilma Fairbank Illustrated. 207 pages. University of Pennsylvania Press. $29.95.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Oops: Gov. WILLIAM F. WELD of Massachusetts, a rising star in the Republican Party, was given a ticket for speeding on Sunday afternoon on Interstate 84 in New York, The Boston Globe reported yesterday. The Governor was returning from a vacation in Virginia when he was stopped for going 74 miles per hour in a 55-mile-per-hour zone.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Gay Group and Parade Backers Battle
description: A Supreme Court argument today about the right of the organizers of Boston's St. Patrick's Day parade to exclude homosexual marchers was not the clash of principle that had been expected. Instead, the case came down to an argument over what message, if any, the marchers would have conveyed had they been permitted to march under their banner identifying them as the Irish-American Gay, Lesbian and Bisexual Group of Boston.

title: Surveying the 20th Century
description: Joel Krosnick, the cellist of the Juilliard String Quartet, has pursued a sideline collaboration with Gilbert Kalish, the pianist, for the last few seasons. They have presented several surveys of the cello and piano repertory together, and on Sunday at Miller Theater they offered an overview of the 20th century in two concerts separated by a dinner break. A scheduling conflict kept me from attending the afternoon session, in which they played sonatas by Ginastera, Overton, Poulenc and Hindemith.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of the sportscaster Howard Cosell on Monday misidentified the cabinet post held in the 1960's by Dean Rusk, to whom Mr. Cosell once referred, saying it was appropriate to ask sports figures "the same sort of questions asked of Dean Rusk." Mr. Rusk was Secretary of State, not Defense.

title: 6-State Force to Open Inquiry Into Insurance Sales Practices
description: Consumer complaints about life insurance sales practices led the New Jersey Commissioner of Insurance to announce yesterday a multi-state task force to examine the problem, starting with the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

title: Muted Joy in Mudville, but Big League Ball Is Back
description: At least on this day, the dark clouds hovering overhead were only in the sky.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: IRA RICHER would drop by the Flavor-Cup in Greenwich Village after taking his kids to school. The coffee store, established in 1903, had, he said, a filtered, special Hopperlike light, unique in New York. Sylvia Carter, a food writer, had her U.P.S. packages delivered there and, with a few other coffee aficionados, would often sit on the bags of unroasted coffee beans and talk with Ron Bowen, who had worked in the store since his early teens.

title: Harsco Corp.(HSC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included nonrecurring income of 22 cents a share from the sale of an equity security and the partial settlement of a U.S. government contract.Year-ago revenue included a gain of $ 5,867,000 on the sale of investments.

title: Bell Atlantic Halts Plan for Video Services
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation called an abrupt halt to its scramble into television yesterday. Saying it wanted to rethink its strategy for upgrading its telephone network, the company asked the Federal Communications Commission to suspend its application to offer video services to as many as three million telephone customers in Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Baltimore, the District of Columbia, northern New Jersey and parts of Virginia.

title: Kerkorian Seeks Chrysler Vote On Buyout Offer
description: Despite the Chrysler Corporation's rejection of his $22.8 billion takeover bid, Kirk Kerkorian appears to be far from ending his battle for control of the company.

title: Newman in Series on Actors Studio
description: "Inside the Actors Studio," a new weekly series of interviews, opens on Bravo tonight with Paul Newman, probably the least Actors Studio-ish actor in America. But Mr. Newman was president of the Studio from 1982 to 1994, and he obviously has the kind of marquee value needed to begin this project, a collaboration between the Studio and the New School for Social Research. James Lipton, the moderator, is chairman of the school's new three-year fine arts course.

title: Don't Make Bill of Rights a Victim of Bombing; For Lower Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Inmate Denies Participating In '79 Slaying
description: Over the last few years, Long Island has been rocked by one lurid crime after another, almost to the point of caricature. But long before the arrests of Amy Fisher, Joel Rifkin and Colin Ferguson, Long Islanders were horrified by the slaying of a 13-year-old boy, John Pius, in 1979.

title: France Votes for Action
description: The old European Socialism of nationalized industries and a cradle-to-grave welfare state is a dying creed. But French voters, buffeted by persistent double-digit unemployment rates, seem reluctant to give up entirely on activist government.

title: Giants Eye First 1995 Opponent: Their Schedule
description: The Giants will open the 1995 season the way they closed 1994 -- playing the Dallas Cowboys at Giants Stadium. After that Monday night game on Sept. 4, the Giants will run through a four-week gantlet of games at Kansas City, at Green Bay, at home against New Orleans and at San Francisco, the Super Bowl champions, on Oct. 1.

title: Big Wheels of DuPont Tour Are Russian and American
description: On Wednesday night, 84 professional and 28 amateur riders will begin the $200,000 Tour DuPont, the most important bicycle race outside Europe. Two will be strong favorites.

title: Need to Mention the Landfill
description: Developers and real estate agents selling new homes must disclose nearby "physical conditions," such as hazardous waste sites, that might affect property values, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday. In the 6-0 decision, the court sided with 150 families who bought new homes in Voorhees Township without knowing they were near the abandoned Buzby Landfill.

title: Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc.(FCX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Share earnings are after preferred dividends of $ 13,403,000 in the latest first quarter and $ 12,305,000 in the year-ago quarter.

title: Book Notes
description: Edgars and Beyond

title: Monsanto Co. (MTC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a one-time net gain of $ 25 million, or 22 cents a share, reflecting payments to Monsanto by Talegen Holdings Inc. (previously Crum & Forster Inc.) and related entities, arising from several insurance-related settlements. The gain was offset by a charge for the formation of the rubber chemicals and instruments joint venture between Monsanto and Akzo Nobel N.V. There was no net effect of the offsetting items on net income or earnings per share.Sales are consolidated net sales.

title: Rwandan Killings Set Back Effort to Provide Foreign Aid
description: The killing of an estimated 2,000 ethnic Hutu by Rwandan Government troops last week is a major setback to efforts to bring international aid to this cash-strapped, desperately poor nation, United Nations and Western diplomats here say.

title: Borg Warner Security Corp.(BOR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
In America; The Longest Wait
description: Everyone's eyes, except those of the very small children, are melancholy. The very small children think it is all a game, like cowboys and Indians, and soon the dead will get up, brush themselves off and have a good hearty laugh at all the excitement they caused.

title: Food Notes
description: Fresh Spring Mushrooms

title: A Little Lamb Chop Goes a Long Way
description: LOVERS of meat and potatoes can have low-fat meals if the meat is used in moderation. This menu of loin lamb chops is filled out by a dish of potatoes, asparagus and peas.

title: Many Theories About Choice Of the Target
description: The date, investigators say, was painstakingly selected. So what about the place?

title: Personal Health
description: THE wounds from the Oklahoma City bombing last week are far more than physical ones, for the minds of many of the people directly and indirectly involved have suffered damage that can linger long after injuries to the body heal. Those who escaped harm and those who took part in rescue and recovery efforts may be as severely affected emotionally as the surviving victims and the families of the dead and injured.

title: Officials Cite Long Delay In Lodi Blast
description: The explosion that toppled a factory in downtown Lodi last week, killing four workers, occurred because of a mishap in the blending of toxic chemicals that was virtually ignored by the company for nearly 12 hours, allowing a volatile reaction to hurtle out of control, the authorities said today. And the effort to put out the resulting blaze, they said, may have been hindered by misleading information from the plant supervisors.

title: For Howard, New Chief With a Sense of Balance
description: H. Patrick Swygert and his close associates at the State University of New York at Albany, where he has been president since 1990, have a standing joke about who gets blamed when something goes wrong at a college.

title: JP Foodservice Inc.(JPFS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 4,590,000, or 48 cents a share, for early extinguishment of debt related to recapitalization.c-Net lossLatest 9 months' income from continuing operations of $ 2,197,000, or 23 cents a share, are historical. Pro forma figures, giving effect to recapitalization as if it had occurred on the first day of the fiscal year, are as follows: net income before extraordinary charge, $ 6,314,000, or 40 cents a share; net income after charge, $ 1,724,000, or 11 cents a share. The recapitalization was completed on Nov. 22, 1994.(Loss)

title: Hospitality Franchise Systems Inc.(HFS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Even the Mets' Most Grizzled Hearts Are Aflutter
description: Todd Hundley admits that he feels a little more anticipation than he has before recent opening days. John Franco is excited that his fellow bullpen mates are, in his eyes, better than any crew he's had in his seven seasons with the Mets. And though he rarely shows any emotion, Bobby Jones is visibly thrilled over his first opening day start.

title: McNamara Took a Long Step to Heal Our Vietnam Wound; A Day Late
description: To the Editor:

title: MICHIGAN FARMER AND BROTHER TIED TO BOMB SUSPECT
description: Two brothers jailed as witnesses in the Oklahoma City bombing were charged today with engaging in a bomb-building conspiracy in Michigan with the former Army sergeant who is accused of setting the blast.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press in Science Times yesterday about a new way to process hazardous waste misstated the given name of a researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He is Daniel R. Cohn, not David.

title: Aviation Agency Issues Rule to Insure Experience in the Cockpit
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday issued a rule requiring airlines to stop matching inexperienced pilots with inexperienced co-pilots.

title: Why Driving Prostitutes Out Doesn't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Leftover Players Make Final Pitches at Free-Agent Camp
description: When the Major League Baseball Players Association training camp for free agents grinds to an unceremonious close Wednesday, the former Met outfielder Vince Coleman knows just one thing: He won't be headed to his home in Arizona.

title: Kansas City Southern Industries Inc.(KSU,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 4.7 million, or 10 cents a share, related to DST Systems Inc.'s 50 percent investment in Investors Fudiciary Trust Co. in exchange for about a 4 percent stake in State Street Boston Corp.; and non-cash acquisition expenses of eight cents a share.

title: Judge Ito Appears Intent: Let's Get the Trial Moving
description: Judge Lance A. Ito brought down a metaphorical gavel in his courtroom today, unveiling a tougher and testier style that, should it last, might prod lawyers in the O. J. Simpson case into moving more quickly and assure restless jurors that their service is not permanent.

title: Met Life in Merger Talks With New England Mutual
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the New England Mutual Insurance Company said yesterday that they are discussing a possible merger.

title: Help Sought For World Loan Unit
description: Representatives of the world's poorest countries stepped into the growing congressional debate about foreign aid today by issuing a strong appeal to the United States and other donor countries to continue supporting the International Development Agency.

title: Kmart Plans to Cut Dividend; Loss From Operations Expected
description: The Kmart Corporation said today that it was cutting its dividend in half and expected to report a loss from operations for its fiscal first quarter.

title: Young Mother Gets Her Request
description: For a 17-year-old mother here who decided that three children were enough, the situation seemed a cruel Catch-22: New Jersey's welfare law denies benefits to children born to mothers on public assistance, yet the state's Medicaid program will not pay for voluntary sterilization for women under 21.

title: Bond Prices Off on Fear Of Inflation
description: Prices of Treasury securities dropped yesterday after a higher-than-expected consumer confidence report, which suggested that inflation could accelerate.

title: New Jersey Resources Corp.(NJR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 721,000, or 4 cents a share, reflecting a change in accounting for deferred income taxes.

title: Titan Wheel Int'l.(TWI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
500 Downtown Dwellers Have Lost Their Homes
description: Moderate rents and a downtown location made the Regency Towers an easy-living community for students, professionals and retirees -- regular folks who enjoyed coming home to a cold beer or a hot meal after a long day. Convenience turned to catastrophe last week when a body-rattling shock wave hit their building, busting doors, smashing windows and routing tenants onto the street and into an unfamiliar terrain, homelessness.

title: Carl A. Gerstacker, 78, Dow Chemical Chairman
description: Carl A. Gerstacker, chairman of the Dow Chemical Company from 1960 to 1976, died on Sunday night in Midland, Mich. He was 78.

title: Light Winds Drive Nothing but Questions
description: It was another day of waiting out the weather in the America's Cup trials today, and a further delay in Dennis Conner's final attempt to win the right to defend yachting's premier trophy against New Zealand's Black Magic.

title: G.M. to Sponsor AIDS Supplement
description: The General Motors Corporation has agreed for the first time to be the sole sponsor of a special magazine advertising supplement promoting the annual "Seventh on Sale" AIDS benefit.

title: Westinghouse Electric Corp.  (WX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included one-time pretax gain of about $ 35 million from asset sales, principally the company's two Sacramento radio stations. Excluding this one-time gain, earnings for the first quarter were about flat.

title: Maxicare Health Plans (MAXI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Preferred-share dividends in the latest first quarter were nil, compared with $ 1,350,000 in year-ago period.

title: Rio Verde Journal; Americans Home on the Booming Range, in Brazil
description: Out here in Brazil's big sky country, where the cows outnumber people and the billboards tout weed killers, Douglas Ferrell looks through the window of his air-conditioned tractor cab and sees dollar signs stretching to the horizon.

title: Better-Than-Expected Profits At Salomon and Dean Witter
description: Two leading securities firms reported first-quarter profits yesterday that were better than Wall Street's expectations, after rallies in the financial markets pushed up trading revenues in the first three months of the year.

title: United Asset Management Corp.(UAM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
HEWLETT-PACKARD CUTS PRICES ON HP OMNIBOOK LINE
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company cut the prices of its HP Omnibook line of notebook computers by 3 percent, to 15 percent, and cut some accessory prices even more. The company, a computer maker based in Palo Alto, Calif., made the cuts to "be a major player in the notebook market," said Christopher Morgan, worldwide marketing manager of Hewlett-Packard's Mobile Computing division. The price on the high-end HP Omnibook 4000 series of color portables was cut by 3 percent, to 15 percent, with an entry-level model now priced at $2,469. Hewlett-Packard reduced the prices of its small notebooks by 5 percent, to 10 percent.

title: Elting E. Morison, 85, Educator Who Wrote Military Biographies
description: Elting E. Morison, an educator, historian and author of two biographies of military leaders, died last Thursday at the Pheasant Wood Nursing Home in Peterborough, N.H. He was 85.

title: Homeless Advocates Fault Hartford's Ban on Begging
description: At the urging of merchants who say panhandlers are hurting their business, the Hartford City Council has passed an ordinance that bans aggressive panhandling.

title: No Headline
description: "The law is keeping up with social change: the stereotype of the divorced father as just a deadbeat dad is breaking down. It is true that some fathers just want to pay less child support, but others are splendid and nurturing." ELLEN J. EFFRON, former head of the custody committee of the A.B.A. [ A1:2. ]

title: Income Gap For Sexes Is Seen Wider In Retirement
description: While women usually earn less than men and are more likely to live in poverty, the economic gap between women and men widens in retirement, according to a new study by the Older Women's League.

title: Clinton Pledges to Defend Farm Subsidies
description: President Clinton came to corn country today to do a little spring planting: he promised to defend Federal farm subsidies from Republican budget cuts as a way of sowing good will in an important political state where he hopes to stave off any challenge to his renomination.

title: Pass the Puck, Get the Buck
description: WAYNE GRETZKY, who took a $2.3 million pay cut this season, still drew the top salary in the National Hockey League this season.

title: Bomb Echoes Extremists' Tactics
description: Whoever blew up the Federal building in Oklahoma City used tactics that are strikingly similar to those urged by far-right advocates of "leaderless resistance" against the Government, according to civil liberties experts who keep track of militant groups.

title: Engelhard Corp.(EC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Prosecutors Join a Union
description: All 55 assistant prosecutors in Middlesex County have joined a union. The reason is money.

title: INSIDE
description: Lobbying on the Inside Track

title: Three Women vs. a Broker; Olde Is Accused of Blatant Job Discrimination
description: Less than a year ago, Mary Graff was at the top of her professional game. Of the more than 1,000 brokers at the Olde Discount Corporation, Ms. Graff, who had been with the company for 11 years, led the list of big bond sellers in the latest company newsletter. She also managed the office in Glenview, Ill., which was among the top 5 producers of the 200 Olde offices around the nation.

title: International Briefs; Brazilian Government
description: Seeks Eletrobras Sale

title: Marion Foster, 97, Red Cross Official
description: Marion Lounsbury Foster, who was for many years a social services administrator with the Disaster Staff of the American Red Cross, specializing in public and private emergencies, died on Thursday at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 VOW, BUT NO PLAN ON DOLLAR The United States and its main economic allies ended a meeting with a vague vow to "strengthen their efforts" in both short-term tactics and long-term strategy to support the beleaguered dollar. A1 RWANDA AID IN QUESTION The killing of 2,000 Hutu by Rwandan troops is a major setback to efforts to bring international aid to that African nation. A3 SOVIET HISTORY REVISITED The reams of documents that have emerged from once-inaccessible Soviet archives have produced dramatic revelations, but also much frustration. A10 THE OTHER SERBS To Bosnian Serb nationalists, Serbs who have chosen to remain in Bosnia's capital, Sarajevo, are deeply disturbing. A8 MORATORIUM IN CHECHNYA Concerned that Russia's V-E Day celebration could turn into a public relations fiasco, President Boris N. Yeltsin suspended combat in Chechnya starting Friday. A8 TURKISH PULLBACK IN IRAQ Turkey has withdrawn 20,000 of its troops from northern Iraq, leaving 12,000 to continue operations against rebel Kurds. A12 PALESTINIAN'S DEATH A Palestinian prisoner's death, days after his arrest, prompted an investigation into possible abuses by his Israeli interrogators. A12 ARGENTINE ARMY ADMITS KILLINGS Argentina's Army Chief has admitted that the military persecuted and killed political opponents during the "dirty war" against leftists and dissidents from 1976 to 1983. A13 NUCLEAR STANDOFF IN JAPAN A Japanese Governor temporarily barred a ship carrying highly radioactive nuclear waste from unloading its cargo. A13 Rio Verde Journal: American finds riches in Brazil's farmland. A4 National A14-23 BROTHERS CHARGED IN BOMBING Two brothers held as witnesses in the bombing of the Oklahoma City Federal building were charged with joining an ex-Army sergeant in a bomb-building conspiracy. A1 WHY BOMB OKLAHOMA CITY? Investigators are trying to determine why the bombers chose Oklahoma City as their target, but so far no clear answer has emerged. A1 THE TACTICS OF HATE GROUPS Whoever blew up the Federal building used tactics similar to those urged by anti-Government advocates of "leaderless resistance," civil liberties experts say. A22 CONFLICT OVER NEW POWERS Differences between two Federal agencies are hampering the Administration's effort to obtain new powers to combat terrorism. A23 What part do politics play in the Oklahoma City bombing? A23 LETTER FROM A SERIAL BOMBER Federal officials said that the serial bomber in the Unabom case sent two letters to the East Coast, shortly before a package bomb killed a timber trade group executive in California.A1 QUESTIONS OVER BOMB'S TARGET Federal officials said the bomb that killed the executive was apparently intended for the former head of the organization. A16 PRISTINE LAND MAY BE AT RISK More than 500 acres of untouched land in Maryland may not remain so much longer. St. Barnabas Episcopal Church wants to sell the land to a developer for $9.4 million. A14 NEW 'CREW-PAIRING' RULES The F.A.A. now requires airlines to stop matching inexperienced pilots with inexperienced co-pilots. A14 HIGH COURT HEARS PARADE CASE The Supreme Court heard arguments on whether the organizers of Boston's St. Patrick's Day parade can exclude gay marchers. A15 HOW TO LOBBY EFFECTIVELY Special Pleaders: Georgia Pacific, a wood products company, set out to use new legislation to derail a pending Federal inquiry. A18 Education Page B8 H. Patrick Swygert returns to Howard University as its new president. Term papers get a new-age look (and sound) with CD-ROMs. Metro Digest B1 DEEPER SPENDING CUTS PREDICTED As Mayor Giuliani put final details on the second budget of his tenure, administration officials said that the city now faces a budget gap of nearly $3.1 billion, forcing still deeper spending cuts. A1 RETHINKING FATHERS' RIGHTS Courts and legislatures are rethinking some tenets of divorce law with fathers' rights in mind. By and large the changes aim to give fathers more access to their children and sometimes to reduce their child support payments. title: Replacing Rap's Anger With a Sense of Humor
description: "Friday," a high-energy comedy starring the rap artist Ice Cube, isn't aimed at anyone much over the age of 18, but it would be a mistake for wider audiences to dismiss it. This is a ruder, cruder version of the hip-hop movie "House Party," and it offers a fascinating glimpse at the way street life enters pop culture. Like rap and much stand-up comedy, "Friday" is based on opened-eyed acceptance of drug use and guns as part of its characters' lives. The film, written by Ice Cube and D. J. Pooh, makes fun of those realities and replaces rap's anger with humor.

title: Players and the Umpires Present United Stance
description: As locked-out major league umpires picketed the first game of the season tonight, a game worked by replacement umpires, the heads of the umpires' and players' unions adopted an uncharacteristic joint stance against the owners.

title: Upheaval in China: Real Recollections, False Flashbacks
description: One legacy of the 1989 uprising in Tiananmen Square was a vision of absolute courage: one man, many tanks and the kind of fierce determination that changes the world. It is an image of such simple dignity that it haunts "Moving the Mountain," Michael Apted's inexplicably snazzy documentary about China's recent upheaval.

title: Law-Enforcement Agencies Differ on Need for More Power to Spy on Terror Suspects
description: Sharp differences between the Justice Department and the Treasury Department are hampering the Clinton Administration's campaign for broad new powers to investigate and monitor organizations suspected of plotting terrorist attacks, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Triangle Pacific (TRIP,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Montana Joins Racing Team
description: JOE MONTANA didn't waste time finding a way to spend his retirement. A week after leaving the National Football League, Montana announced yesterday that he has become a partner in the Target-Chip Ganassi Racing Team. The team is based in Indianapolis and is sponsored by Target discount stores based in Minneapolis.

title: Don't Make Bill of Rights a Victim of Bombing; Arabs as Scapegoats
description: To the Editor:

title: Legal Aide in Terror Trial Faces Deportation
description: A paralegal working on the defense of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, who is charged with plotting to blow up major New York City buildings, was arrested on Monday as an illegal alien and could be deported, immigration officials said yesterday.

title: A-Waste Ship, Briefly Barred, Reaches Japan
description: In an embarrassing mix-up for Japan's sensitive plutonium-based energy program, a Japanese Governor on Tuesday temporarily barred a ship carrying highly radioactive nuclear waste from docking and unloading its cargo.

title: Avery Dennison Corp.(AVY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
Bomb Meant for Predecessor Of Victim, Officials Say
description: Federal officials said today that a mail bomb that killed the chief lobbyist for a forest-products trade group in Sacramento, Calif., was apparently intended for a retired executive who had headed the group until a year ago.

title: After West's Pressure, Turkey Begins Big Pullout From Iraq
description: Turkey has withdrawn 20,000 of its troops from northern Iraq, leaving 12,000 behind to continue operations against base camps used by the rebel Kurdistan Workers Party, a military spokesman said today.

title: Transactions
description: Football National Football League

title: A Bombing Foretold, In Extreme-Right 'Bible'
description: The scene is eerily familiar: a rented truck filled with ammonium nitrate fertilizer blows up in front of a Federal Government building shortly after 9 A.M., killing hundreds of people.

title: Beneficial Corp.(BNL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a loss of $ 39 million, or 74 cents a share, to reflect the company's best current estimate of possible losses from the tax refund anticipation loan business in 1995.c-Included after-tax RAL profits of about $ 18 million, or 34 cents a share.

title: Foster Wheeler Corp.(FWC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Chevron Corp.(CHV,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $ 63 million, which included a charge of $ 10 million for environmental remediation provisions, a charge of $ 7 million for restructuring and reorganizations and a gain of $ 80 million on other special items, principally a gain related to sale of land by a Caltex affiliate in Japan.c-Included a special charge of $ 36 million, which included a charge of $ 21 million for environmental remediation provisions, and an unspecified charge of $ 15 million.Share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1994.

title: United Dominion Industries(UDI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Eating Well
description: AMERICANS have significantly reduced their consumption of red meat, from 126 pounds in 1980 to 114 pounds in 1992, according to figures from the United States Department of Agriculture.

title: U.S. Surgical Corp.(USS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss(Loss)The latest first quarter was after $ 4.9 million in preferred stock dividends, compared with $ 200,000 in preferred stock dividends, for year-ago period.

title: Poulin Is New Coach of Irish
description: DAVE POULIN, a 12-year National Hockey League veteran and a former Notre Dame star, will become the Irish's new hockey coach. Poulin will replace RIC SCHAFER, who resigned on March 24 after eight seasons. Poulin, 36, is retiring as the Washington Capitals' center. He played for Notre Dame from 1978 to 1982. (AP)

title: With Budget Due, Giuliani Faces Gap Of Over $3 Billion
description: As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani prepares to present his second city budget tomorrow, administration officials said yesterday that New York City's budget gap now exceeds $3 billion, forcing the Mayor to propose still deeper cuts in spending by the city's agencies.

title: Consolidated Edison Co. of New York (ED,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Brooklyn Hails Its Bard, Norman Rosten, May 17
description: To the Editor:

title: Burdened by Yen, Mazda Will Cut Production Further in Quarter
description: With the surging yen hindering its car sales in the United States, the Mazda Motor Corporation said today that it would slash production in the current quarter more than twice as much as it had anticipated.

title: Woman Is Raped and Beaten
description: A 39-year-old West New York woman has told the police that she was forced into a van at gunpoint, then raped and beaten for 13 hours before escaping yesterday morning. She said she jumped from the van just before 8 A.M. when the driver slowed for a stop sign only six blocks from where he picked her up.

title: Tecumseh Products Co.(TECUA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Israel Bonds Live On
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 College Students Plead Guilty In Cross-Burning Outside Home
description: Two college students have pleaded guilty to Federal civil rights charges in the burning of a cross in the front yard of a black family in Dutchess County last year, Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, announced today.

title: McNamara Took a Long Step to Heal Our Vietnam Wound
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES AND FLIGHT ATTENDANTS IN ACCORD
description: American Airlines and its flight attendants' union have settled a series of longrunning noneconomic disputes stemming from a strike in late 1993. The agreement covers weight restrictions, work rules and retribution by either side against flight attendants who walked off the job or crossed picket lines. Both sides are waiting for a panel of arbitrators to resolve the disputes about wages, vacations and contributions to retiree health plans and scheduling rules that caused the strike. American, a unit of the AMR Corporation, based in Fort Worth, and the Association of Professional Flight Attendants, which has about 20,000 members at the airline, said the deal would improve labor relations.

title: National Steel Corp.(NS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included $ 3.6 million charge for reduction in salaried workforce.c-Included $ 107.9 million gain from judgment in favor of the company in an antitrust suit against Bessemer & Lake Erie Railroad.Results for both first quarters were after preferred dividends of $ 2.7 million.

title: Hearing Begins in Shooting
description: Tensions ran high here in February after a white police officer fatally shot an unarmed black teen-ager. Yesterday a grand jury began hearing testimony to determine what happened. The police have said that Ronald Cohen's pistol discharged accidentally when 16-year-old Lawrence Meyers resisted arrest during a drug bust; others have said Mr. Meyers was not struggling with the police when he was shot.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: DEEPER CUTS NEEDED TO CLOSE BUDGET GAP

title: Russia Revokes Visa Of U.S. Journalist
description: The Russian Government has revoked the visa of an American journalist in what may be the first such case since the collapse of the Soviet Union.

title: Tambrands Inc.(TMB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Rangers Exercise Their Patience as Kovalev Grows Up on the Job
description: With four games left in the regular season, including Wednesday night against Tampa Bay at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers could still use a little help from anybody not on Mark Messier's top line.

title: Doctor Caused Doris Duke's Death With Overdoses, Report Says
description: A court-appointed investigator looking into the death of Doris Duke, the billionaire tobacco heiress, has concluded that her doctor caused her death with a fatal overdose of morphine and that the principal executor of her estate had squandered hundreds of thousands of dollars since she died.

title: White House Nod for Pageant
description: Miss America contestants performed 226,237 hours of community service last year. That was enough to win the equivalent of an honorable mention in the Presidents Service Award program.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title:
Business Travel;
Buying ticket-free travel in just a few seconds. You can do it on the Delta and USAir shuttles.
description: TWO air carriers, Delta Air Lines and USAir, are making life easier this spring for passengers on their shuttles between New York, Washington and Boston with the introduction of ticket-free travel.

title: Times Names Men's Fashion Editor
description: Robert E. Bryan, men's fashion director of W magazine and senior fashion features editor of The Daily News Record, a trade publication, has been named men's style editor of The New York Times Magazine. The appointment, which was announced by Jack Rosenthal, editor of the magazine, is effective May 8.

title: No Golf Course for State Park
description: Liberty State Park is not going to get a golf course. State Senator Bernard F. Kenny Jr., who never wanted golfers to tee off in the shadow of the Statue of Liberty, said he got the news yesterday. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will make an official announcement today, her spokeswoman, Rita Manno, said.

title: President Is Criticized By Oklahoma Senators
description: The debate over whether provocative free speech has fostered domestic terrorism sharpened today as Oklahoma's two Senators criticized some of President Clinton's remarks in the aftermath of the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the execution of a white supremacist in Arkansas last Wednesday referred imprecisely to one of his murder victims. (The error was repeated in another article on Saturday and in a chronology box on Sunday.) The victim, William Stumpp, was not Jewish, but the convict, Richard Wayne Snell, believed that he was.

title: Sale of Forest Is Seen as Threat to Songbird Haven
description: Standing perfectly still with his eyes closed, surrounded by oak trees and tulip poplars more than 140 feet tall and nearly 300 years old, Hobson Calhoun shot out his right arm and pointed. "Over there. An ovenbird." Then his left arm extended. "A wood thrush." In the next few minutes, he heard chickadees, cardinals, vireos and, way over there, a tufted titmouse.

title: Northern Telecom Ltd.(NT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $ 72 million, or 29 cents a share, related to the sale of a fiber optic manufacturing plant.Preferred-share dividends were $ 1 million in the latest first quarter and $ 1 million in year-ago period.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Increase 4.3% on Nasdaq
description: In a short sale, an investor borrows shares from a brokerage firm and sells them, hoping to buy them back at lower prices and make a profit. If the shares rise in price, the short-seller faces a loss.

title: W. L. Eisenberg, 74, A Labor Mediator In 2,000 Disputes
description: Dr. Walter L. Eisenberg, an economics professor emeritus at Hunter College who helped settle many labor disputes at the city, state and Federal levels, died on Saturday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 74.

title: Dieting, Bite by Sound Bite
description: DR. STEPHEN GULLO has spent the last 20 years talking excess poundage off the rich and famous. His is an interdisciplinary approach: one part common sense, one part cognitive psychology, one part fire-and-brimstone diet coaching.

title: Excerpts From Letter by 'Terrorist Group,' FC, Which Says It Sent Bombs
description: Following are excerpts of the letter received by The New York Times on Monday from the self-designated terrorist group FC, claiming responsibility for the serial bombings that the Federal Bureau of Investigation attributes to a single person or group in the case known as Unabom. The document is presented verbatim, with original spelling, emphasis and punctuation. Three passages have been deleted at the request of the F.B.I. [ Passage deleted at the request of the F.B.I. ]

title: RJR Nabisco Shares Fall On First-Quarter Earnings
description: Shares of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation fell yesterday to their lowest level in a year after the company announced disappointing first-quarter earnings showing declining domestic tobacco sales and lackluster international cigarette revenues as well.

title: Chief of Hudson River Conservancy Ousted
description: The president of the agency seeking to create a park system along Manhattan's Hudson River shoreline resigned yesterday under pressure from the Pataki administration, and a corporate real estate manager was named to replace him.

title: From the Soviet Archives, Revelations and Problems
description: Since the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, thousands of documents have emerged from behind the long-impenetrable walls of the Soviet archives.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Chicago Finally Wins Murray Craven's goal two minutes into overtime last night snapped Chicago's 13-game streak without a victory and lifted the Blackhawks to a 4-3 victory over the visiting Vancouver Canucks. The Blackhawks were 0-10-3 during their free fall, their worst streak since 1959. Craven, acquired by the Hawks from Vancouver earlier this year, beat Canucks goaltender Kirk McLean after taking a feed from Sergei Krivokrasov. Going into the game, the two teams were tied for fifth in the Western Conference playoff race. (AP) BLUES 8, STARS 4: Brendan Shanahan scored twice in St. Louis's five-goal third period as the Blues spoiled Dallas's regular-season home finale. Shanahan scored his 16th and 17th goals of the season against the relief goalie Darcy Wakaluk as the Blues scored five goals on eight third-period shots. (AP)

title: Only a Scant Increase in Employee-Benefit Costs
description: After years of absorbing hefty increases in what they pay for health care and other fringe benefits, the nation's employers seem to have regained control of this prominent business expense.

title: Israel Begins Inquiry on Death Of Palestinian Held for 3 Days
description: A Palestinian prisoner died today in an Israeli hospital three days after his arrest, prompting an investigation by the Justice Ministry into possible abuses by his interrogators.

title: 14-Year-Old Tests Positive
description: A 14-year-old South African runner has tested positive for steroids, making her the youngest track and field competitor anywhere in the world to be accused of using performance enhancers. BERNARD ROSE, chief executive of Athletics South Africa, said the girl's identity would not be released because she is a minor. She has been suspended from competition pending a hearing.

title: American General Corp.(AGC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Latest results included Franklin Life Insurance Co., which the company acquired on Feb. 1, and its 40 percent stake in Western National Corp., acquired on Dec. 23.Latest quarter's shares outstanding reduction caused by stock buybacks in 1994.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHS ELECTRONICS INC., Miami, will acquire four other distributors of computers, computer peripherals and software from Comtrad Inc., one of its big shareholders, in a deal valued at $17.5 million. KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN INDUSTRIES INC., Kansas City, Mo., a railroad company, said it planned to buy back from investors up to six million of its common shares, partly with the proceeds from the sale of its majority interest in DST Systems Inc.

title: Market Place; Rewarding shareholders at the expense of bondholders.
description: IF someone is going to owe you money, wouldn't you rather that that someone had a lot of cash on hand?

title: What the Court Guards Really Guard
description: Courtroom guards are deployed to protect juries that are sequestered in sensational cases, as all avid watchers of the O. J. Simpson trial well know. But in New York State they also guard their own interests and plunder the system for overtime pay. Uniquely in the United States, the criminal courts of New York are obliged, whether the case is sensational or ordinary, to sequester juries whenever they deliberate, watching over them at mealtimes and keeping them overnight in hotels.

title: A Boy's Long Brush With Death; A Toddler Survives After Hours Without Oxygen or a Pulse
description: In the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, a chunky dark-haired toddler named Jesus Dennis lies strapped to a bed, with an array of tubes delivering pain killers and sedatives into his veins and a thick white liquid for nourishment into his stomach. But he is alive.

title: Don't Make Bill of Rights a Victim of Bombing
description: To the Editor:

title: Madison Avenue Is Throwing Out Its First Pitches
description: Baseball's delayed return from the living dead marks the start of its remarketing as a viable, breathing organism. As more games are played, baseball will breathe even easier.

title: Ingersoll-Rand Co. (IR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about a report recommending more versatility in the doctoral training of scientists and engineers misidentified the research institute at which one author, Phillip A. Griffiths, is director. It is the Institute for Advanced Study based in Princeton, N.J.; it is not the Institute for Advanced Research at Princeton University. The two institutions are not affiliated.

title: Wood Products Company Helps Write a Law to Derail an E.P.A. Inquiry
description: A few weeks ago, some of Washington's top lawyer-lobbyists were closeted in a Senate office building with Republican staff members, reworking a bill by the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, to limit the powers of Government regulators.

title: GIDDINGS & LEWIS BUYS FADAL ENGINEERING
description: Giddings & Lewis Inc., a maker of machine tools based in Fond du Lac, Wis., said yesterday that it had bought the Fadal Engineering Company for $180 million in cash. Fadal, a closely held concern based in Chatsworth, Calif., produces about 54 percent of all the vertical machining centers made in the United States and about 33 percent of those sold. The centers make machine parts. Shares of Giddings & Lewis rose $1.375, to $16.75, in Nasdaq trading yesterday.

title: Ginger Rogers, Who Danced With Astaire and Won an Oscar for Drama, Dies at 83
description: Ginger Rogers, the vivacious actress whose supple grace in the arms of Fred Astaire lifted the spirits of Depression-era moviegoers in some of the most elegantly romantic musical films ever made, died yesterday at her home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. She was 83.

title: Equitable Resources Inc.(EQT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Equitable Resources said exceptionally warm weather in the latest first quarter cut deeply into heating sales, which cost the company $ 3 million in utility earnings and helped drive down gas wellhead prices 36 perent from the year-ago period.

title: CHAIRMAN OF USX SAYS HE WILL RETIRE
description: The chairman and chief executive of the USX Corporation, Charles Corry, said yesterday at the company's annual meeting that he would retire. Mr. Corry, 63, will leave USX, which is based in Pittsburgh, on June 30, after six years as chairman and chief executive. The company's board named Thomas Usher, 52, to succeed him. Mr. Usher, a 30-year employee of USX, was promoted in December to president and chief operating officer, after serving as president of USX-U.S. Steel Group for four years. Mr. Corry will reach USX's mandatory retirement age of 65 in 1997.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Cold Peace
description: Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev of Russia delivered a remarkable speech here the other day on Russian foreign policy -- a speech that was at the same time illuminating, troubling and pathetic.

title: Motel of Ill Repute to Be Razed
description: For more than a decade, neighbors say, the Lord Stirling Motel was a place where drug pushers and prostitutes plied their trades in the heart of a residential area. No more. Last week, the city bought the 22-room motel and immediately shut it. The motel will be razed soon to help make way for a $100 million redevelopment project.

title: Quartet Inaugurates a Hall
description: There is an odd dearth of really decent chamber-music venues in New York. The best-known groups tend to appear at high-profile halls that are truthfully a bit too large or diffuse for the full sound of a string quartet or piano trio to make itself felt. It is a pleasure to hear a good ensemble in a space like the 92d Street Y or Florence Gould Hall, where acoustics are ideally suited to intimate voices.

title: Private Chefs for Busy People Who Like Their Meatloaf
description: WHEN Stephanie Hersh got her first job as a private chef for a family of four in Milton, Mass., in 1989, she did what she thought private chefs do: she spent each day preparing haute cuisine for dinner. At the end of the first week, her employer sat her down and said they needed to talk about menus.

title: Bally Entertainment Corp.(BLY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a gain related to debt extinguishment of $ 326,000, or 1 cent a share.c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $ 5,007,000, or 11 cents a share, and an extraordinary charge of $ 20,735,000, or 44 cents a share, related to debt extinguishment.Share earnings is after preferred dividend payments of $ 694,000.(Loss)

title: A 50th Anniversary in Italy Reflects Continuing Divisions
description: Only blocks from the piazza in Milan where the bodies of Mussolini and his mistress were hanged for public derision after their execution by Italian resistance fighters near the end of World War II, Italian officials today marked the 50th anniversary of Italy's liberation by the Allies.

title: Where Traffic School Is a Laugh a Minute
description: THE dozen people gathered in a small room at the Marriott Hotel here appeared to have little in common, apart from their grim expressions and the Problem. A man in tennis clothes shuffled up front to confess his crime. "I'm Dave Yobs," he said, "and I did not come to a complete stop at a stop sign."

title: Working Women Gain Slowly at Best
description: To the Editor:
